Values are shown as mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM and were analysed using \nWelch\u2019s t-test. *Indicates P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.05, ***indicates P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.001.\nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n4\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nimmobility between E13\u201317 significantly reduced both femur (24%, P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.001) and tarsometatarsus (TMT; 38%, \nP\u2009<\u200b\u20090.001) lengths while the tibiotarsus (TBT) was not significantly affected (Fig.\u00a03). The TMT was most affected \nby immobilization between E15\u201318 (16% shorter compared to 12% in the TBT, P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.05), whereas in contrast the \nfemur was not significantly reduced at this late time point.\nMRI allows for non-invasive, longitudinal monitoring of chick development39,40. We used daily MRI scans to \nachieve repeat measures of limb growth between E14 to E18 in individual chicks immobilized from E10. These \nmeasures of limb and skeletal element length confirmed the existence of a period between E10\u201313 when lack of \nmotility does not modify chick limb growth (see Fig.\u00a02). Immobilisation between E15\u201318 achieved reductions in \nlimb length without modification in eye diameter (a gross index of chick skull development41; note that HH-based \nstaging after E13 relies on beak and 3rd digit lengths which are both affected by immobilization. Such staging was \nthus not appropriate). We therefore staged only control chick embryos upon euthanasia after the final scan at E18 \nto assess whether cooling of eggs during MR imaging had an impact on development. Measurements of beak and \n3rd digit lengths from these chick embryos corresponded to those of E16 embryos42, indicating that these methods \nintroduce a level of developmental delay. The altered limb proportions seen in MR-imaged embryos do however \ncorrespond closely with measurements made using microCT at E17; their altered limb proportions are consistent \nwith selective modification of longitudinal growth by embryo movement.\nLongitudinal MRI scans were used to explore the differing effects of chick immobilisation seen in individual \nlimb elements at E13\u201317 and E15\u201318, and revealed that modifications in growth of each element in response \nto altered movement first emerge at different stages in each element. Longitudinal growth of the TBT showed \nsignificant reliance on movement only after E17, and the femur prior to E17, whereas TMT length was markedly \nmodified by E15 (Fig.\u00a03). Together these data indicate that different elements exhibit differential sensitivity to the \nremoval of normal chick motility, which is seemingly unrelated to the proximo-distal sequence of limb element \nemergence.\nGrowth plate dynamics are influenced by embryo movement.\u2003\nWe next sought to relate the \nimmobilisation-induced changes in limb proportions to modifications in the dynamics of specific growth \nplates. We quantified the widths of the distinct growth plate zones (proliferative/maturing, pre-hypertrophic \nand hypertrophic) in proximal and distal ends of the femur, TBT and TMT in sections from control and \nFigure 2.\u2002 Total hindlimb length is reduced by removal of embryo movement at selected time-points during \ndevelopment. Mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM total limb length in control (n\u2009=\u200b\u20095) and immobilized (n\u2009=\u200b\u20094) chicken embryos is \nunchanged by (a) immobilization between E10\u201314. Total limb length is reduced by immobilization between  \n(b) E13\u201316 and (c) E15\u201318 when compared by Mann-Whitney U-tests (P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.05 and 0.001 respectively).  \n(d) MRI monitoring of mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM limb length daily in control (n\u2009=\u200b\u20096) and immobilized (n\u2009=\u200b\u20094) chicks. \n*Indicates P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.05.\nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n5\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nimmobilized (from E10 onwards) chick pelvic limbs. Zone width was expressed as a percentage of the total \ngrowth plate width. Immobilization altered growth plate dynamics selectively in the distal region of both the \nfemur and TMT, but not TBT, at E18 (Fig.\u00a04). In contrast, the proximal regions of all elements were unaffected. \nEach growth plate in a given element does not contribute equally to longitudinal growth, and the changes we \nobserved were targeted to the growth plate deemed responsible for >\u200b50% longitudinal growth43. No signifi-\ncant impact on either TBT growth plate was observed. Thus, differences in sensitivity to external input may be \nintrinsic to different limb regions.\nThe impact of chick immobility in the affected growth plates at E18 was characterised by a relative expansion \nin the proliferative/maturing zone, with a corresponding narrowing of the pre-hypertrophic zone in femur and \nTMT (Fig.\u00a05). We observed no impact of immobilization in any growth plate at E14 (Fig.\u00a04f). These data suggest a \ncorrelation between modified growth plate dynamics and the changes in longitudinal growth of specific elements \nand limb proportions observed in immobilized chicks.\nMovement drives cellular progression in the growth plate.\u2003\nWe tested the hypothesis that there is a \ncorrelation between chick embryo motility and changes in growth plate dynamics by examining cellular behav-\niour in the growth plate in response to immobilisation. We examined the regulation of chondrocyte proliferation, \napoptosis and hypertrophy in the distal femoral growth plate of chicks immobilized from E10 onwards in com-\nparison with control chick embryos. We compared the distribution of cells positive for proliferating cell nuclear \nantigen (PCNA, an S-phase marker) and phosphohistone H3 (a marker of mitosis), expressed as a percentage of \nthe total number of cells (DAPI labelled).\nImmobility from E10 produced a loss of PCNA labelling at the articular surface, little change in the prolifer-\native zone and an increase in the number of PCNA positive cells in the prehypertrophic/hypertrophic zone, thus \nwidening the region of PCNA labelling (normally restricted to the proliferative zone) by E14 (Fig.\u00a05a\u2013e). This \nwas accompanied by a diminution in the number of phosphohistone H3-positive cells (Fig.\u00a05f\u2013j), indicating that \nFigure 3.\u2002 Limb proportions are altered by immobilization of embryonic chicks at selected time-points \nduring development. PCNA expression in (a) control and (b) immobilized distal femur at E14. The mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM % total \ncells which express PCNA in the 1) articular cartilage, 2) \u201cresting zone\u201d cartilage, 3) proliferative zone and \n4) prehypertrophic/hypertrophic zone was quantified in (c) control and (d) immobilised (n\u2009=\u200b\u20095 for each \ngroup) limbs at E14, after 4 days of treatment. The mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM % total cells that are \nphosphohistone H3 positive was quantified from a representative view of the epiphysis of (h) control and (i) \nimmobilized limbs at E14, after 4 days of treatment, and E18, after 8 days of treatment (n\u2009=\u200b\u20095 in each group).  \n(j) Mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM % total cells phosphohistone H3 positive. The \nmean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM % total cells which are BrdU positive in the proliferative zone (shown by dotted lines) or \nthe prehypertrophic/hypertrophic zones of (m) control and (n) immobilised limbs (n\u2009=\u200b\u20095 in each group; \nindicated by yellow squares) 4\u2009hours after BrdU administration was quantified. (o) Mean\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u2009SEM % total cells \nphosphohistone positive in these regions. Mean values from the two treatment groups were analysed by Mann-\nWhitney U test. *Indicates P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.05. Scale bars represent 200\u2009\u03bc\u200bm.\nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n8\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nthe enlarged population of PCNA-positive cells do not complete the cell cycle and advance normally through the \ngrowth plate but rather accumulate. These changes were observed at E14, before any measurable impact of motil-\nity on femur length was evident, and were still apparent at E18 (see Supplementary\u00a0Fig.\u00a0S1).\nTracking of proliferating cells by BrdU incorporation in E16 chick limbs, 6 days after the onset of immobiliza-\ntion, confirmed that immobilisation slowed cellular progression through the growth plate; BrdU-positive cells in \nnormal limbs had progressed to the prehypertrophic zone within 4\u2009hours of BrdU administration, but were largely \nrestricted to the proliferating zone in immobilised limbs (Fig.\u00a05k\u2013o). The rate of uptake of BrdU (cells per hour) \nwas unchanged with immobilisation, suggesting that proliferative arrest in these cells occurs after completion of \nS-phase but prior to mitosis (Supplementary\u00a0Fig.\u00a0S2).\nWe found no alteration in number or distribution of TUNEL-positive cells in control and immobilized chick \nlimbs at any time-point (Supplementary\u00a0Fig.\u00a0S3), indicating no impact on apoptosis. Measurement of chon-\ndrocyte cell area in regions of the hypertrophic zone adjacent to the chondro-osseous junction also showed no \nmodification in hypertrophic expansion after 4 days of immobilization at E14. However, chondrocyte size was \nreduced by more prolonged lack of movement at E18 (21% reduction, P\u2009<\u200b\u20090.05, see Supplementary\u00a0Fig.\u00a0S4). These \ndata indicate that movement initially targets specific growth plates by driving completion of the cell cycle within \nthe proliferative zone.\nMolecular features of the growth response to mechanics.\u2003\nOur data suggest that longitudinal growth \nof embryonic limb elements is initially intrinsically regulated; \u201cmechano-sensitive\u201d limb growth is not always a \nfeature of ontogeny but is acquired relatively late in development. Our data also suggest that, in the embryonic \nchicken, limb growth becomes responsive to altered embryo movement between E13\u201315 in the femur, but growth \nof the TBT is affected less severely by mechanics, and not until later time-points. This was exploited in an attempt \nto identify the molecular factors responsible for mechanical regulation of cartilage growth. Transcriptional profil-\ning was performed to identify changes in coordinated gene expression associated with the switch from intrinsic to \nmechanical regulation of cartilage growth. Transcriptional profiles were compared in the distal femur and prox-\nimal TBT growth plates of control chicks at E12, 13 and 15 to explore whether changes in gene expression occur \nduring the time period when femur growth becomes sensitive to movement but the growth of the TBT does not. \nAdditionally, gene expression was compared in the distal femur and proximal TBT of chicks immobilised between \nE10\u201315 and compared to E15 controls, to explore whether any genes identified by the previous comparison were \nalso regulated in expression by embryo movement.\nA comparison of control femur and TBT limb elements at E12 and E13 did not reveal any differentially \nexpressed genes or pathways between these limb elements. Gene expression in pooled TBT and femur elements \nat E12 and E13 (to maximise statistical power) revealed a small number of modestly differentially expressed \ngenes between the two time-points, 4 of which, namely Scube2, BTF3L4 and indirectly HMBG3 (via HMBG2) \nand IGF2BP3 (via links with IFG2), have known associations with endochondral ossification (Table\u00a01). However, \ngene ontology (GO) analysis of these genes revealed enrichment of no distinct pathways or cellular components, \nsuggesting this was a stochastic observation. Differences in expression specific to individual limb regions did, \nhowever, emerge by E15; 58 genes (4 upregulated and 54 downregulated) were found to differ in expression in \nthe femur relative to the TBT at this time-point, and belong to specific biological pathways. GO analysis revealed \nenrichment of genes associated with Mechanistic Target of Rapamycin (mTOR) signalling among those down-\nregulated specifically in the femur at E15 (Fig.\u00a06a,b). The mTOR complex has diverse roles in the regulation of cell \nproliferation and growth and in our analysis appears to be the primary pathway altered between the femur and \nTBT elements at E15, suggesting it may regulate the emergence of limb proportions by specifically modulating the \ngrowth of those elements sensitive to movement.\nWe further sought to identify whether the genes which are associated with the acquisition of \n\u201cmechano-responsive\u201d cartilage growth are also involved in the mechano-sensory process, and in coordinating \nthe growth response to mechanical stimuli. We compared gene expression in the femur and TBT elements in \ncontrol and DMB-treated limbs at E15. The mTOR associated genes identified by the previous comparison were \nnot significantly altered in their expression in either the femur or TBT in response to drug-induced immobilisa-\ntion. In contrast, we found that a number of traditionally \u2018myogenic\u2019 genes associated with MEF2c were down-\nregulated in both the femur and TBT in response to immobilisation (Fig.\u00a07a). These genes are associated with \nactin-mediated cell contraction and have previously been implicated in the mechano-transduction process during \nembryonic limb growth44. However, although the skeletal muscle genes downregulated in response to immobi-\nlisation were very similar between limb elements, a number of genes associated with the regulation of chondro-\ngenesis were altered in expression in the femur but not the TBT. Upstream analysis, which statistically links a \ncombined pattern of up/down regulated set of RNAs with pre-existing signatures of drug or protein induced tran-\nscriptional responses45,46, identified that these changes are consistent with increased Wnt3a activity in the femur \nin response to immobilisation (Figs\u00a05 and 7b,c). Our data suggest that genes associated with actin-mediated cell \ncontraction are regulated in chondrocytes by embryo movement and may, as previously suggested44, contribute \nto sensing and transducing mechanical signals. Our data also suggest that Wnt3a is involved in coordinating \nchondrocyte responses to embryo movement in growth plate cartilage. However, such regulation of growth by \nmovement only occurs in limb elements which have lower intrinsic mTOR pathway activity. Our analysis did not \nreveal which effectors of mTOR were responsible for the differences in intrinsic activity.\nDiscussion\nOur data provide evidence to support the hypothesis that the environment influences developmental pathways \nto produce phenotypic variation in limb form during embryonic development. Altered embryo behaviour and \ngrowth in response to incubation temperature in West African Dwarf crocodiles results in the emergence of \nhindlimb proportions that may, in turn, influence locomotor performance upon hatching, as well as survival in \nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n9\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nvarying environments9,12,47. There are unfortunately no studies describing adaptive differences in extant crocodil-\nian morphology to warmer or cooler environments. Nonetheless, similar correlation between limb length relative \nto body size and latitude (which is strongly linked to climate) has been observed in extant lizards7, suggesting \nthat there is scope for such adaptive prenatal changes to occur in ectothermic, oviparous species. We observed \nthat hind limbs in less motile embryos incubated at 28\u2009\u00b0C were shorter when corrected for overall body size, with \nrelatively shorter tibiae but longer digits compared to those incubated at 32\u2009\u00b0C. Extant crocodilian embryos have \nbeen shown to scale limb proportions isometrically with body size after the very earliest stages of development, \nwith negative allometry in the zeugopod (ulna) and positive allometry of the forelimb autopod providing the \nexceptions to this general isometric scaling48. A study which quantified the contribution of the femur, tibia and \n3rd metatarsal to total limb length (digits were excluded) in Alligator mississippiensis from 8 days into incubation \nuntil hatching age (~70 days) showed that throughout prenatal ontogeny, the femur consistently contributes 43%, \ntibia 36% and 3rd metatarsal 21% to limb length, suggesting that their proportions do not to change39. Applying \nthese methods of comparison to our data, we find that the values calculated from Osteolaemus embryos incubated \nat 32\u2009\u00b0C are similar, with the femur contributing 40\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u20090.3%, tibia 39\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u20090.7% and metatarsal 21\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u20090.8% to total limb \nlength. There are some differences in the values calculated from embryos incubated at 28\u2009\u00b0C, in which the femur \ncontributes 41\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u20091.1%, tibia 34\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u20090.9% and metatarsal 24\u2009\u00b1\u200b\u20090.9%. It remains to be established whether all autopod \nelements adhere to such isometric scaling during Osteolaemus ontogeny, but we speculate that it is unlikely that \nthe differences observed in the relative length of the digits between embryos incubated at 28\u2009\u00b0C and 32\u2009\u00b0C can be \nexplained solely on the basis that development is delayed.\nThe number of crocodile embryos available limited our study to a single time-point. To date, most studies into \nthe embryonic development and limb scaling of crocodilians have focused on Alligator mississippiensis, likely \ndue to their availability. Further studies to monitor limb growth throughout prenatal ontogeny in other species \nlike Osteolaemus are required to fully understand how incubation temperature influences limb scaling in other \ncrocodilians. However, the trend for isometric scaling of hindlimb proportions in Alligator suggests that the \nshorter tibiae and longer digits of Osteolaemus incubated at relatively cool temperatures may be due to differential \nregulation of limb growth at this temperature.\nThe observed reduction in hindlimb length relative to body size, and the proportional shortening of zeugopod \nand lengthening of autopod elements in crocodile embryos incubated at low temperatures, could be extrapolated \nto produce more \u201cpaddle-like\u201d limbs in an extreme case. This has remarkable correspondence to limb adaptations \nto more aquatic environments observed in extinct crocodylomorphs (e.g. those adapted to more aquatic environ-\nments such as thalattosuchians show a trend for reduced zeugopod elements, including ulna, tibia and fibula49). \nThe fossil record indicates that climate may have driven phenotypic diversity in crocodilian-line archosaurs, \nwith less diverse, more terrestrial adaptations occurring at latitudes closer to the equator, while a greater range of \ndiversity was associated with higher latitudes18. Correlation between morphology (i.e. limb length) and latitude/\nclimate has also been reported in other reptiles and is reminiscent of Allen\u2019s rule in mammals7,8,50. Direct regula-\ntion of cartilage growth by temperature has recently been proposed as a potentially comprehensive explanation \nfor reduced extremity length and altered limb proportions in cooler climates51. Expression patterns of these \nmTOR associated genes were unaltered by immobilisation. Femur data are in red and TBT in blue. Analysis of changes in gene expression from E12/13 to E15 in both femur and TBT identified a \nrobust expression of skeletal muscle genes at E12/13 followed by a strong down-regulation. Up-stream analysis \nof these genes identified that this included inhibition of MEF2c (p\u2009<\u200b\u20091E-10) (a) Plotting the 17 \u2018myogenic\u2019 genes \ndirectly associated with MEF2c finding, we noted these were further down-regulated during immobilisation in \nboth the femur and TBT at E15 (plotting all muscle genes would have yielded a similar pattern). (b) Analysis \nof gene expression differences between DMB treated E15 femur and DMB treated E15 TBT (SAMR analysis) \nrevealed that genes regulated by greater Wnt3a activity (Z\u2009=\u200b\u20092.1, p\u2009<\u200b\u20091E-10) and greater CTNNB1 (Z\u2009=\u200b\u20092.1, \np\u2009<\u200b\u20091E-9) activity, were expressed at a greater level in the femur than TBT. Genes expressed at a higher level \nin DMB treated E15 femur are shown in red and lower-level are shown in blue. (c) The genes down-stream of \nWnt3a are plotted using data from femur and TBT in growth cartilage from control and immobilised (DMB \ntreated) chicks. Horizontal black lines indicate mean expression values for each gene.\nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n12\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nregulation of limb element growth does not fully explain the proportions we observe in the less motile crocodile \nembryos incubated at cooler temperatures. Although absolute growth of all elements was reduced at the lower \n28\u2009\u00b0C incubation temperature and a proportional reduction was seen in zeugopod length, the most peripheral \nautopod elements, which we would expect to be most severely \u2018shortened\u2019 by temperature regulation of cartilage \ngrowth, are instead proportionally elongated, rather than shortened. We suggest that mechanical regulation of \nembryonic bone growth also contributes to the variation in limb form seen in different climates by differentially \nregulating the growth of individual limb regions.\nPharmacological immobilization of embryonic chickens revealed that modulation in pelvic limb growth can \nbe achieved by alteration of embryo motility alone, independent of incubation temperature. Our data suggest \nthat this can be achieved via selective targeting of chondrocyte proliferation and progression in specific growth \nplates by embryo movement, to achieve changes in limb proportions. Our findings suggest that embryo motil-\nity acts to regulate limb proportions by exerting a differential impact on the growth of individual limb regions. \nThis supports the findings of previous studies which showed that the impact of immobilisation on the growth of \nembryonic limb elements is complex, differs in individual limb regions and is partially dependent on the day at \nwhich immobilisation commences23,24,35,36,52\u201354. Previous studies by Lamb, et al.36 and Heywood, et al.21 which also \nreported an impact on limb length at E14 or later are consistent with this view. In contrast, Hosseini and Hogg23 \nreported an impact on femur and TBT/tibia length from E11 but did not observe any alteration in growth carti-\nlage volume until 3 days later, at E14. Germiller and Goldstein55, on the other hand, showed an impact on element \nlength and proliferation, without any changes in growth plate zone widths later than E11, from E13 onwards. Our \nuse of 5\u03bc\u200bm resolution microCT to make measurements of element length found a significant impact of embryo \nmovement only after E14. Despite examining limb growth in response to immobilisation across a very extensive \nperiod spanning E8\u2013E20, these studies together appear to identify a comparatively short developmental period \n(potentially from E11 to E14) when sensitivity to movement commences. This variation may reflect inaccuracies \nintroduced by the different methods used for measuring limb length, variation in the incubation temperature \nmaintained between studies, the difficulty of accurately staging immobilised embryos (to allow for consistency) \nor even variation in growth rate between strains of domestic chicken used.\nWe observed that in limb elements which are not growing rapidly (e.g. the chicken femur between E15\u201318, \nFig.\u00a03), there is little scope to alter growth in response to immobilization. However, the differential impact of \nmovement on each limb region cannot be fully explained by the region\u2019s growth rate alone; e.g. the length of the \nTMT in chicks is severely affected by immobilization, even at developmental stages when other elements are \ngrowing more rapidly. Furthermore, our data suggest that \u201cmechano-responsiveness\u201d of longitudinal limb growth \nis not always a feature of ontogeny but is acquired during development. Our longitudinal data gathered from \nMRI analysis support the notion that different limb elements acquire mechanically-driven plasticity in growth \nat different stages. The developmental delay introduced by our imaging protocol means that we cannot ascertain \nexactly when mechano-sensitive growth is likely acquired in each limb element during normal chick develop-\nment, but it certainly seems to differ within each of the individual stylopod, zeugopod and autopod limb regions. \nThis developmental delay was ascertained by staging of control embryos after 4 days of MRI imaging, at E18, \naccording to the Hamburger and Hamilton staging series42. Staging of DMB-treated embryos using this method \nwas not possible as the growth of the traditional anatomical landmarks upon which the grading of late stages is \nbased (beak and 3rd digit length) is influenced by embryo immobilisation. However, we observed no difference \nin eye diameter (chosen as a gross index of skull development, as previous studies have identified that the growth \nof craniofacial bones is not influenced by embryo paralysis54) between control and immobilised embryos, which \nsuggests that embryo paralysis does not cause an overall developmental delay but rather influences the growth of \nselected musculoskeletal elements. Investigating the impact of immobility on chick growth plate dynamics con-\nfirmed an impact of altered movement in the distal femur and TMT, but not in either TBT growth plate by E14, \nsuggesting that differences in responsiveness to mechanical stimuli are instead intrinsic to different limb regions. \nThe impact of altered motility on each individual element, however, differs between the chicken and crocodile \nspecies considered in this study.\nOur analysis identified a population of cells in the proliferative zone of specific growth plates which progress \nslowly through the cell cycle in the absence of movement, and that cell cycle progression is accelerated to com-\nplete mitosis, and later differentiate, upon embryonic limb movement. A deficit in hypertrophic expansion, which \nappears to be secondary to the impact on proliferation, is also observed in the absence of normal mechanical \ninput. The IGF-1-dependent phase of hypertrophy in particular is known to underpin the differential growth of \nlimb elements in species which exhibit dramatic differences in limb proportions56; our data highlight that this \nmay also be subject to regulation by movement depending on the intrinsic level of activation of canonical growth \nregulating pathways.\nTranscriptional profiling by microarray analysis offers an explanation for why the growth of some elements \nis more severely affected by embryo immobilisation than others at the time-points chosen for this study. The \ninducible nature of pharmacological immobilisation of embryonic chicks, coupled with longitudinal monitoring \nof limb growth, allowed us to identify factors that determine whether a limb element is capable of responding \nto mechanics during prenatal growth. Previous embryo immobilisation studies have identified genes potentially \ninvolved in mechano-sensation and transduction and the response of embryonic limb growth to paralysis44. It \nwas not possible in this study to separate the influence of spontaneous neuronal activity on gene expression from \nthe consequent muscle activity that it stimulates. There are compounds which may be used to increase the fre-\nquency of embryonic movement, such as 4-aminopyridine, but these also provoke actions at the neuromuscular \njunction. However, the cytoskeleton-associated genes which we found to be altered in expression in immobilised \nlimbs (Fig.\u00a07a) have previously been implicated in chondrocyte mechano-transduction in vitro57,58, suggesting \nthat this response at least is not dependent upon neuronal activity. Perhaps with the advent of newer methods for \nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n13\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nnon-invasive imaging and monitoring of embryo movement in ovo39,59,60 it will be possible to better distinguish \nthe contributions from muscle-induced mechanical stimuli from those induced by spontaneous neuronal activity.\nOur analysis suggests that mechano-sensation and the growth response to mechanical stimuli can be \nde-coupled, and that additional factors exist which determine whether a growth response to mechanical stimuli \nwill occur in individual limb regions. One such factor appears, on the basis of our transcriptional profiling of \nthese elements, to be the intrinsic degree of mTOR pathway related activity.mTOR is a known regulator of the \ncell cycle and forms two multi-protein complexes known as mTORC1 and mTORC2, which perform different \nfunctions (Rokutanda, Fujita et al. 2009, Guan, Yang et al. 2014). mTORC1 is known to regulate protein syn-\nthesis in response to intrinsic factors such as nutrient and growth factor availability (Chen and Long 2014). \nThe function of mTORC2 is less well characterised, but is also thought to regulate cellular metabolism through \nactivation of Akt/PKB, and may play a role in cell adhesion or cytoskeletal organisation due to its stimulation of \ncytoskeletal-associated genes including paxillin and F-actin (Chen, Holguin et al. 2015). These complexes there-\nfore function to integrate aspects of energy metabolism with the translation of mRNA during cell division. mTOR \nhas previously been implicated as a regulator of chondrocyte proliferation and differentiation; the Akt-mTOR \npathway positively regulates chondrocyte proliferation, maturation, matrix production and growth during skel-\netal development (Rokutanda, Fujita et al. 2009). There are, however, conflicting reports on the role of mTORC \nin the growth plate, with some studies reporting that inhibition of mTORC results in impaired chondrocyte \nproliferation, while others report only an impact on hypertrophy (Yang, Yang et al. 2013, Guan, Yang et al. 2014). \nThese differences may reflect the relative impact on mTORC1 and mTORC2 signalling following mTOR inhibi-\ntion. In our analysis, evidence for significantly lower mTOR pathway activity in the femur but not the TBT at E15 \ncoincides with our findings showing onset of mechanosensitive growth in the femur only. These analyses also \nreveal a lack of any significant modification in transcriptional signature across E12 and E13 in the TBT and femur, \nsuggesting that no marked change in their behaviour is likely to have occurred during this earlier timeframe. \nWe propose that reduced mTOR-stimulated growth, likely to occur in response to other intrinsic factors such as \nnutrient availability, confers the ability for cells to be influenced by external, mechanical cues.\nActivation of mTOR itself has also been shown by previous studies to be regulated by mechanical stimuli. \nIts activation is stimulated by cyclic loading in primary growth plate chondrocytes, and has been shown to be \nreduced in growth cartilage of pharmacologically immobilised chicks at E17 and in cases of postnatal limb immo-\nbilisation in humans52,61,62. However, while mTOR activation status appeared lower in the control femur relative to \nTBT at E15, the expression of genes associated with the mTOR pathway were not altered by immobilisation at E15 \nin our study; i.e. the difference between E15 femur and TBT was intrinsic to the femur and appears insensitive to \ngross changes in movement. This suggests that mTOR is likely not directly responsible for mechano-responsive \ngrowth. Rather, reduction in its activation in the femur may instead allow the influence of other factors, such as \nmovement, to impact on growth. This is consistent with our observed changes in the expression of cytoskeletal \ngenes associated with actin-mediated cell contraction with immobilisation in both TBT and femur, which previ-\nous studies have identified as a potential mediator in \u2018sensing\u2019 or transducing altered mechanical stimuli44. Our \nexamination of changes in gene expression by immobilisation are also consistent with previous studies44 in that \nthey suggest that the growth response to immobilisation is likely coordinated via Wnt3a activity. Indeed, these \nWnt-related changes in expression occur in only the femur with immobilisation, consistent with Wnt\u2019s proposed \nfunction in coordinating the growth response to embryo movement.\nThus, differential intrinsic mTOR activity in individual growth plates appears to help determine whether \ngrowth responds to external mechanical cues or is regulated only by intrinsic factors such as amino acid availabil-\nity and growth factors. mTOR\u2019s known regulation of protein synthesis during the cell cycle points to its potential \nto impact events in the growth plate proliferative zone. Our exploration of immobilisation-induced changes in \nthe proliferative zone suggest that chondrocytes are arrested in the G2 phase of the cell cycle, which involves \nrapid protein synthesis in preparation for mitosis. Our observation that proliferative zone chondrocytes in the \nfemur reach S phase at a normal rate (they incorporate BrdU during DNA replication) but fail to, or take longer \nto undergo mitosis strengthens this connection. We therefore propose that developmental downregulation of \nintrinsic mTOR activity results in reduced growth in the absence of embryo movement, and appears to allow the \ncapacity for mechanical stimuli to instead drive cell cycle progression in the proliferative zone. Previous studies \nindicate that selection for intrinsic growth regulation can indeed occur at the expense of adaptability to mechan-\nical loading63,64, although it is currently not clear how mTOR signalling would interact with Wnt3a mediation of \nthe growth response (this need not be a direct interaction). Selection for different levels of intrinsic mTOR activity \nmay offer an explanation for why different elements are more susceptible to growth regulation by mechanical \nstimuli in different species, such as the chicken and crocodile considered in this study.\nIn mammals, and to a lesser extent birds, the embryonic environment is controlled by a parent and, in the \nabsence of pharmacological intervention or pathology, this appears to secure an optimal range of embryo motility \nto produce suitable limb forms, although at a major metabolic cost to the mother65. Many ectothermic oviparous \nspecies adopt a different reproductive strategy by producing larger numbers of eggs that are not incubated by a \nparent66. The incubation conditions of these eggs are dependent upon the environment and a single animal may \nproduce multiple clutches of eggs in a season, and/or bury a single clutch of eggs in a nest containing a temper-\nature gradient67, thereby increasing the chance that at least some embryos will experience \u2018optimal\u2019 incubation \nconditions. However, our data suggest that the reproductive strategy of these animals does not rely entirely on \nchance, but that developmental plasticity during the embryonic phase may also engender a robust capacity for \nthe embryos of reptiles such as crocodiles (and perhaps other tetrapod species) to adapt their limb proportions \nin ways that may be beneficial in their post-hatching environment. Our findings also suggest that regulation of \nprenatal growth in response to embryo motility is achieved by the control of proliferation in limb growth plates \nwhich are specified by a mechanism involving intrinsic reduction in mTOR pathway activation.\nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n14\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nMaterials and Methods\nManipulation of embryo movement.\u2003\nAll procedures complied with the Animals (Scientific Procedures) \nAct 1986 and were approved by the RVC animal welfare and ethical review body.\nCrocodiles.\u2003 Crocodile (Osteolaemus tetraspis) eggs from a single clutch were obtained from Crocodiles of the \nWorld conservation and education centre (Witney, UK) at E10. They were randomly assigned into groups and \nincubated at 28\u2009\u00b0C or 32\u2009\u00b0C (n\u2009=\u200b\u20093 per group) with 90% relative humidity. Osteolaemus are a threatened spe-\ncies not commonly bred in captivity, which limited the number of fertilised eggs available. Prior data indicate a \nsmall degree of variation in the limb element lengths of wild crocodilians sampled from the same geographical \nlocation68. Dupont and Plummer\u2019s method for power and sample size calculations69 therefore indicate that the \nnumber of embryos required per group to detect a 10% change in limb element length with a power of 0.8 and \ntype I error of 0.05 with varying temperature is \u2265\u200b1. The chosen temperatures are within the ranges which produce \nviable, predominantly female hatchlings in captivity.\nEmbryo movement was monitored at intervals throughout incubation by candling the eggs and recording the \nnumber of visible movements during a 3\u2009minute period20. Mean frequency of movement values were compared \nusing Welch\u2019s t-test. Embryos were euthanised at E70. Snout to cloaca length was measured with a tape measure \nand mean values compared by Welch\u2019s t-test. The hindlimbs were removed and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde.\nChickens.\u2003 Fertilised eggs were incubated at 37\u2009\u00b0C with 45% relative humidity. Eggs were \u2018windowed\u2019 on E4 using \nstandard protocols70,71: briefly, a small section of shell and shell membrane were removed using sterile forceps and \nthe shell was resealed with adhesive tape. Chicken embryos were immobilized with decamethonium bromide \n(DMB), which induces rigid paralysis35. Embryos were immobilized between E10\u201314, 10\u201318 13\u201316 and15\u201318. \nSterile filtered 5\u2009mg/ml DMB in 100\u2009\u03bc\u200bl Tyrode\u2019s solution was injected through the egg window onto the cho-\nrioallantoic membrane to induce immobilization. On each subsequent day, 100\u2009\u03bc\u200bl of 1\u2009mg/ml DMB in TS was \nadministered to maintain paralysis. Embryos were monitored by viewing through the egg window on each day of \ntreatment and any DMB-treated embryos which were not fully paralysed were excluded from the study. Control \nanimals received equivalent volumes of TS. The embryos were euthanized on the final day of treatment, hind-\nlimbs removed and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde. The sex of chicken embryos used for this study was unknown, \nbut previous studies indicate that sexual dimorphism in the growth of domestic chickens only occurs postnatally; \nbody mass and growth hormone expression do not diverge between males and females until 2\u20134 weeks post \nhatching72,73.\nEx vivo measurements of limb length from microCT scans.\u2003\nLimbs from crocodiles incubated at 28\u2009\u00b0C \nor 32\u2009\u00b0C (n\u2009=\u200b\u20093) and chickens treated with DMB or TS between E10\u201314, 13\u201316 and 15\u201318 (n\u2009=\u200b\u20095 per group) were \nstained with the contrast agent phosphotungstic acid (PTA) by immersing in a solution of 1% PTA 70% etha-\nnol for 72\u2009hours, to allow visualisation of cartilage by micro-computed tomography (microCT)74. Limbs were \nscanned with a SkyScan 1172 microCT system (Bruker, Belgium) with a resolution of 5\u2009\u03bc\u200bm, voltage of 40\u2009kv, \ncurrent of 250\u2009\u03bc\u200bA, exposure time of 1600\u2009ms and a 0.5\u2009mm aluminium filter. Images were reconstructed using \nNRecon and whole limb lengths and length of the femur, TBT and TMT elements measured using DataViewer \nsoftware (Bruker, Belgium). Limb measurements from the different chicken and crocodile groups were compared \nusing Mann-Whitney U-tests and Welch\u2019s t-tests, respectively.\nNoninvasive monitoring of embryonic limb growth in ovo.\u2003\nChicken embryos treated with TS (n\u2009=\u200b\u20096) \nor DMB (n\u2009=\u200b\u20094) between E10\u201318 were imaged daily between E14\u201318 with a Philips Intera 1.5\u2009T MR system with \na SENSE flex spinal coil (Philips Medical Systems). The eggs were cooled for 10\u2009minutes at 4\u2009\u00b0C prior to imaging \nto temporarily reduce embryo movement in TS treated chicks. The eggs were imaged in the dorsal plane using a \nfast field echo sequence with a flip angle of 60\u2009\u00b0C, echo time of 3.41\u2009ms and repetition time of 7.62\u2009ms. Time out of \nthe incubator for imaging did not vary between TS and DMB treated groups. The embryos were euthanized after \nthe final scan on E18 and staged according to the Hamburger and Hamilton staging series42 to assess the impact \nthat removing the eggs from the incubator daily and cooling had on embryonic development; staging was based \non third digit and beak length, which were measured with digital callipers. The scan images were imported into \nImageJ75 as image stacks and total limb length and element length were calculated by identifying the most prox-\nimal and distal bone points in the image stack76. Mann-Whitney U-tests were used to compare the DMB-treated \nembryo values to controls at each timepoint.\nSectioning and growth plate histology.\u2003\nFixed, dissected limbs from embryonic chicks treated with TS/\nDMB between E10\u201314 and E10\u201318 were processed to paraffin for embedding and sectioning. 6\u2009\u03bc\u200bm sections were \nstained with Toluidine blue. Sections were imaged using a DM4000B upright microscope and DC500 colour cam-\nera, both controlled through Leica Application Suite software version 2.8.1 (all from Leica Microsystems, Milton \nKeynes, UK). The objective used was a 10x HC PL FLUOTAR PH1 (NA\u2009=\u200b\u20090.3). Growth plate zones (proliferating/\nmaturing, prehypertrophic and hypertrophic) were identified based on cell morphology and organisation, meas-\nured and expressed as a proportion of the total growth plate width77 using ImageJ. All growth plate zones were \nidentified and measured by the same observer, and the growth plate images were temporarily assigned a random \nID number unrelated to treatment group during analysis to minimise bias. Mean growth plate widths were com-\npared using Welch\u2019s t-test.\nAssessment of cellular kinetics in the growth plate.\u2003\nWe performed immunohistochemistry to detect \nproliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and phosphohistone H3 using sections from the distal femoral growth \nwww.nature.com/scientificreports/\n15\nScientific REPOrTS | 7:41926 | DOI: 10.1038/srep41926\nplate of embryonic chicks treated with TS/DMB between E10\u201314 and \u2212\u200b18 (n\u2009=\u200b\u20095 per group, full method includ-\ning antibody dilutions in Supplementary\u00a0Methods). The epiphysis was divided into 4 zones to assess distribution \nof PCNA-labelled cells: the articular cartilage, \u201cresting\u201d zone, proliferating zone and prehyperophic/hypertrophic \nzone. The proportion of PCNA labelled cells to total DAPI labelled cells was calculated in each zone for PCNA, \nand in a representative view of the growth plate for phosphohistone H3. BrdU incorporation by proliferating cells \nwas assessed in TS/DMB treated embryos at E16, in embryos euthanised 4\u2009hours after BrdU administration (see \nSupplementary\u00a0methods). We quantified the number of BrdU-positive cells, expressed as a proportion of total \nDAPI-labelled cells, in the proliferative zone and prehypertrophic/hypertrophic zones using Image J. Sections \nwere imaged using a DM4000B upright microscope with samples illuminated using an EBQ100 light source and \nfilter cubes A4, L5, and TX2 (all from Leica Microsystems, Milton Keynes, UK) and an AxioCam MRm mon-\nochrome camera controlled through Axiovision software version 4.8.2 (Carl Zeiss Ltd, Cambridge, UK). The \nobjectives used were: 5x HC PL FLUOTAR (NA\u2009=\u200b\u20090.15); 10x HC PL FLUOTAR PH1 (NA\u2009=\u200b\u20090.3). Mean values \nfrom control and immobilized limbs were compared using Mann-Whitney U-test.\nThe size of chondrocytes from the distal femoral hypertrophic zone adjacent to the chondro-osseous junction \nwas assessed in freshly killed chicken embryos treated with TS or DMB between E10\u201314 and E10\u201318 (n\u2009=\u200b\u20096 in \neach group). One femur from each chick was removed and bisected sagitally78. The tissue was maintained at \n37\u2009\u00b0C in standard culture media until required, then incubated with 5\u2009\u03bc\u200bM calcein AM for 15\u2009minutes at 37\u2009\u00b0C to \nfluorescently label viable cells. A representative area from the base of the hypertrophic zone was then collected \nas an image stack in 3D using an SP5 confocal microscope using Leica Application Suite advanced fluorescence \nsoftware version 2.6 (Leica Microsystems, Milton Keynes, UK). The objective used was a 40x HCX PL FLUOTAR \nPH2 (NA\u2009=\u200b\u20090.75). The average maximum cell area of calcein AM labelled hypertrophic chondrocytes was quanti-\nfied from image stacks from representative regions from the hypertrophic zone in control and immobilized chicks \n(\u2009>\u200b\u200920 cells per growth plate) using ImageJ and compared using Mann-Whitney U-test. Apoptosis was evaluated \nusing TUNEL assay (see Supplementary\u00a0Methods).\nRNA extraction and Microarray analysis.\u2003\nThe hindlimbs were dissected from freshly killed embryos \ntreated with either TS or DMB from E10 onwards. The growth cartilage from the distal femur and proximal \nTBT was dissected. Any fully ossified bone, bone marrow and red blood cells were excluded. The tissue was \nsnap-frozen by immersing in liquid nitrogen and stored at \u2212\u200b80\u2009\u00b0C until required. The tissue was not allowed \nto thaw prior to RNA isolation. The following samples were collected: control femur and TBT RNA from E12, \ncontrol femur and TBT RNA from E13, control femur and TBT RNA from E15, immobilised femur and TBT \nRNA from E15 (n\u2009=\u200b\u20093 biological replicates in each group. Each biological replicate contained the pooled growth \ncartilage from 4 individual chicken embryos.\nTotal RNA was isolated using TRizol\u00ae\u200b (Life Technologies). RNA was dissolved in 20\u2009\u03bc\u200bl RNAse-free water. \nAffymetrix DNA microarrays (Chicken) were processed according to the manufacturer\u2019s protocol (BEA Core \nfacility, Huddinge Hospital, Sweden). From the twenty four samples processed, 1 sample was excluded as an \noutlier by visually evaluating principal component analysis prior to down-stream analysis. The raw data has been \ndeposited at the Gene Expression Omnibus (accession no.: GSE77412). Aroma.affymetrix79 and Bioconductor80 \npackages in R were used to preprocess the CEL files and generate summarized expression matrices. A standard \ndeviation filter (SD\u2009=\u200b\u200910) was applied to remove low expressed invariant probe-sets (which reflect background \nsignal or poorly functioning probesets) and this value is array type specific (obtained by first plotting the distri-\nbution of SD values). For annotation, the Chicken_Gg_ENST, binary.cdf was used. For comparing various groups \nan unpaired SAMR (significance analysis of microarrays) analysis was used to estimate the false discovery rate \n(FDR) using 5,000 permutations. The nearest FDR value to 5% was utilized in the pathway or ontology analysis. \nThere are limitations to the usefulness of pathway or gene ontology (GO) analysis for identifying enrichments \nof biological functions among genes in a list of regulated genes81. Thus, to interpret a significant p-value for GO \nanalysis as being evidence of specific enrichment, the \u2018regulated gene list\u2019 (in this case genes with AEU events) \nmust be contrasted with a list of the detectable genes in the experiment (and not all the genes in the genome or on \nthe gene-chip). Only when the experimentally regulated list contains enriched p-values well above those observed \ndue to bias did we consider the observation reliable. As well as Ingenuity IPA analysis we utilized GOstats package \nin R with current GO categories (GO.db) to confirm the IPA analysis. Input gene lists, and related background \nexpression gene lists were used in IPA and GO with an ~5% FDR and no-fold change filter. The latter is used \nbecause it is well established that a large number of coordinated but modest gene expression changes can mean-\ningfully underlie shifts in pathway regulation.\nReferences\n1.\t Towers, M. & Tickle, C.
