Mace2\n1 Division of Biology, Imperial College London, Silwood Park, United Kingdom, 2 Centre for Population Biology, Imperial College London, Silwood Park, United Kingdom\nSummary\nMany species are experiencing sus-\ntained environmental change mainly due\nto human activities. The unusual rate and\nextent of anthropogenic alterations of the\nenvironment may exceed the capacity of\ndevelopmental, genetic, and demographic\nmechanisms that populations have evolved\nto deal with environmental change. To\nbegin to understand the limits to popula-\ntion persistence, we present a simple\nevolutionary model for the critical rate of\nenvironmental change beyond which a\npopulation must decline and go extinct.\nWe use this model to highlight the major\ndeterminants\nof\nextinction\nrisk\nin\na\nchanging environment, and identify re-\nsearch needs for improved predictions\nbased on projected changes in environ-\nmental variables. Two key parameters\nrelating the environment to population\nbiology have not yet received sufficient\nattention. Phenotypic plasticity, the direct\ninfluence of environment on the develop-\nment of individual phenotypes, is increas-\ningly considered an important component\nof phenotypic change in the wild and\nshould be incorporated in models of\npopulation\npersistence.\nEnvironmental\nsensitivity of selection, the change in the\noptimum phenotype with the environ-\nment, still crucially needs empirical assess-\nment. We use environmental tolerance\ncurves and other examples of ecological\nand evolutionary responses to climate\nchange to illustrate how these mechanistic\napproaches can be developed for predic-\ntive purposes.\nIntroduction\nGlobal climate change, over-exploita-\ntion, and habitat alteration are causing\nsustained and consistent pressures on wild\npopulations [1]. Because of habitat frag-\nmentation, many species will not be able\nto track their preferred environment in\nspace, and must therefore adapt in situ to\navoid extinction. What determines the\nmaximum rate of environmental change\nthat populations can cope with? Under-\nstanding this will inform both models and\nmanagement plans about where critical\nthresholds lie or what might affect the\npotential resilience of particular species or\necological communities.\nTwo main approaches exist for studying\nthe impact of environmental change on\nspecies persistence\u2014niche modelling and\nmechanistic population modelling. On the\none hand, \u2018\u2018climate envelope models\u2019\u2019 (or\n\u2018\u2018niche models\u2019\u2019) are correlative and fo-\ncused on the environment. Their concep-\ntual background traces to Hutchinson\u2019s\nmultidimensional representation of the\nniche [2]. They use measurements of\nenvironmental variables and records of\nspecies presence and absence to infer\nabiotic correlates of the realized niche of\na species. By projecting this niche on a\nmap with environmental data, the spatial\nlocations that satisfy the basic require-\nments of the species are identified. Niche\nmodels have been combined with climate\nprojections to predict range shifts and\nextinction\nrates\n[3].\nAside\nfrom\nthe\nmethodological caveats of this approach\n(changing covariance of environmental\nvariables [4], population demography not\nin equilibrium with changing climate [5],\nspatial scale of the analysis [6,7], and\nsource-sink dynamics allowing individuals\nto exist outside their niche [8]), its major\ndrawback is that it does not account for\nthe biological processes underlying adap-\ntation of a species to its environment. It\ncannot identify or incorporate the biolog-\nical differences among species that deter-\nmine whether or not they can persist in\nsitu. While a new generation of \u2018\u2018process-\nbased\u2019\u2019 (or \u2018\u2018mechanistic\u2019\u2019) niche models is\nbeing developed to overcome these limi-\ntations [9\u201311], they currently rely on\nsimplified\ndemographic\nprocesses\nand\ngenerally overlook evolution in response\nto climate change (but see [12]). Niche\nmodelling is thus currently more suited to\nunderstand changes in the distribution of\nsuitable environments for a species at a\ncontinental scale than to predict popula-\ntion persistence or guide conservation\nplans.\nOn the other hand, mechanistic popu-\nlation modelling focuses on the biological\nprocesses that underlie population persis-\ntence. By combining evolutionary genetics\nand\ndemography,\nthe\nconditions\nthat\nallow a population to maintain a positive\nintrinsic\ngrowth\nrate\nin\nthe\nface\nof\nenvironmental change can be predicted\ntheoretically [13,14] and studied empiri-\ncally [15]. The main focus of mechanistic\npopulation studies is not environmental\nvariables, but ecologically important phe-\nnotypic traits (morphology, physiology,\nphenology, or behaviour) that affect pop-\nulation growth through their influence on\nlife history. In contrast to niche modelling,\nthis\napproach\nallows\nidentification\nof\nEssays articulate a specific perspective on a topic of\nbroad interest to scientists.\nCitation: Chevin L-M, Lande R, Mace GM (2010) Adaptation, Plasticity, and Extinction in a Changing\nEnvironment: Towards a Predictive Theory. PLoS Biol 8(4): e1000357. doi:10.1371/journal.pbio.1000357\nAcademic Editor: Joel G. Kingsolver, The University of North Carolina, United States of America\nPublished April 27, 2010\nCopyright: \u0002 2010 Chevin et al. This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative\nCommons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium,\nprovided the original author and source are credited.\nFunding: L-MC is supported by a Newton International Fellowship (http://www.newtonfellowships.org/the-\nfellowships.html) and RL by a Research Professorship (http://royalsociety.org/Research-Professorships/), both\nfrom the Royal Society of London. GM acknowledges support from Natural Environment Research Council\n(http://www.nerc.ac.uk/funding/) and the Grantham Institute for Climate Change (http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/\nclimatechange), Imperial College London. The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis,\ndecision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.\nCompeting Interests: The authors have declared that no competing interests exist.\n* E-mail: l.chevin@imperial.ac.uk\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n1\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\nfactors that potentially limit population\npersistence in a changing environment.\nHowever, unless environmental variables\nare included, as well as phenotypic traits,\nthis approach cannot be used to project\nthe fate of populations.\nHere, we propose a model of evolution\nand population growth to address how\ndemographic and evolutionary constraints\nlimit the persistence of a geographically\nisolated population under sustained envi-\nronmental change. This model generaliz-\nes an earlier one by Lynch and Lande\n[13] by including phenotypic plasticity\n(see Box 1\u2013Glossary) and an explicit\nenvironmental variable such as tempera-\nture. We use it to highlight the determi-\nnants of extinction risk and to identify\nresearch needs for a more predictive\napproach to population persistence in a\nchanging environment. Research directed\ntowards key determinants of extinction\nrisk that are often overlooked in current\nempirical work may allow population\nbiologists to take advantage of abundant\nenvironmental data in order to begin\ndeveloping predictions about population\npersistence under alternative scenarios of\nclimate change [16], which can help to\nguide conservation policies and manage-\nment plans.\nExtinction Risk under Sustained\nEnvironmental Change\nThere are three mechanisms by which a\npopulation can persist when its local\nenvironment changes: dispersal to track\nits preferred environment in space, genetic\nevolution to the new local conditions, or\nphenotypic plasticity [17,18]. Using the\nmodel in Box 2 and Text S1, we give an\noverview of the determinants of extinction\nrisk for an isolated population with a\nrestricted geographic range under sus-\ntained environmental change, assuming\ndispersal is not possible. We consider cases\nwhere all other possible factors influencing\nextinction risk (demographic and environ-\nmental stochasticity, inbreeding depres-\nsion, genetic drift [19]) can be ignored\nrelative to the impact of sustained envi-\nronmental change. The determinants of\nextinction risk then belong to three main\nclasses.\n(1) Demographic properties of the population.\nThese are components of the population\ngrowth rate that are not affected by\nadaptation to the changing environment.\nThey include the generation time, T, and\nthe maximum intrinsic rate of increase rmax\n(per unit time) of a population with\noptimum mean phenotype. Even if these\nparameters are not affected by the envi-\nronmental change, they do constrain the\nrate of adaptation. Populations with longer\ngenerations must evolve faster per gener-\nation to adapt to a given rate of environ-\nmental change, and populations with a\nlow rmax will reach extinction before they\ncan adapt to rapid environmental change\n[13\u201315,20]. The specific influence of each\nof these variables on extinction risk across\ntaxa also depends on their covariation.\nBroad-scale studies of life-history traits\nindicate that the per-generation intrinsic\nrate of increase is of the same order of\nmagnitude across several taxa, whereas\nrmax per unit time is roughly inversely\nproportional\nto\nthe\ngeneration\ntime\n[21\u201323]. As a consequence, the critical\nrate of environmental change should be\ngenerally lower for species with longer\ngeneration times, which will be at greater\nextinction risk.\n(2) Evolutionary potential. This measures\nhow fast genetic evolution occurs for a\ngiven deviation of the mean phenotype\nfrom\nthe\noptimum.\nThe\nstrength\nof\nstabilizing selection c measures how the\nmean fitness decreases with the squared\ndeviation from the optimum and also\ndetermines the strength of directional\nselection for a given deviation from the\noptimum. Stronger stabilizing selection\n(larger\nc),\nalthough\ncausing\nincreased\nmortality,\nallows\nfaster\nenvironmental\nchange to be tolerated by causing faster\nevolution [13]. The genetic variance, the\nproduct of phenotypic variance s2 and\nheritability\nh2,\ndetermines\nhow\nmuch\ngenetic evolution is caused by a given\nstrength of selection. Higher genetic var-\niance allows persistence under stronger\nenvironmental change, because it allows\nthe population to track its phenotypic\noptimum more closely. Although we focus\non a single trait for simplicity, this may\nactually\nbe\na\nlinear\ncombination\nof\nmeasurable traits. In this case, the genetic\nvariances of the original traits and their\ngenetic covariances affect the magnitude\nBox 1. Glossary\ncritical\nrate\nof\nenvironmental\nchange:\nmaximum\nrate\nof\nsustained\nenvironmental change that allows long-term persistence of a population,\ndenoted as gc.\nenvironmental sensitivity of selection: change in the optimum phenotype\nwith the environment. For a linear relationship, it is measured by the slope B.\ngeneration time: the average age of parents of a cohort of newborn individuals,\ndenoted as T. With discrete non-overlapping generations, T is the mean time\nbetween successive reproductive episodes in the population.\ngenetic variance: the genetic component of phenotypic variance s2, or more\nprecisely, \u2018\u2018additive genetic variance\u2019\u2019 h2s2, the statistically additive component of\nphenotypic variance determining the resemblance between offspring and\nparents, and the genetic response to selection.\nheritability: the proportion of phenotypic variance in a trait due to additive\ngenetic effects, denoted as h2.\nintrinsic rate of increase: population growth rate in the absence of intra- or\ninter-specific competition. For a perfectly adapted population with mean\nphenotype at the optimum, the intrinsic rate of increase is denoted as rmax.\nnorm of reaction: the expected phenotype of a given genotype as a function of\nthe environment.\nphenotypic plasticity: direct influence of the environment on individual\nphenotypes through developmental mechanisms. For a linear norm of reaction\nplasticity is measured by the slope b.\nquantitative\ntrait:\ncontinuously\ndistributed\nphenotypic\ncharacter,\nwith\nphenotypic variance in a population determined by multiple polymorphic genes\nand environmental effects.\nstabilizing selection: natural selection such that individual fitness decreases\nwith increasing phenotypic deviation from an optimum. Its strength is measured\nby c.\ntolerance curve: fitness or performance as a function of the environment.\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n2\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\nof the genetic response to selection in any\nphenotypic direction [24,25].\n(3) Biological impact of the environment. This\nlinks the environment to the biology of\nindividuals\nin\nthe\nspecies.\nPhenotypic\nplasticity describes the direct impact of\nthe environment on the development of\nindividual phenotypes. It may involve\nmorphological, physiological or behav-\nioural responses, which can occur on\ndifferent\ntime\nscales.\nFor\ncontinuous\nenvironmental variables, plasticity usually\nis modelled using reaction norms, where\nthe phenotype of a given genotype is\nplotted as a function of the environment\n[26]. We focus on linear reaction norms\nfor simplicity, although reaction norms\ncan be non-linear [27,28] (see below).\nWith linear reaction norms, the slope b\nquantifies the degree of plasticity. The\nenvironmental sensitivity of selection, B,\nmeasures how the optimum phenotype\nchanges with the environment, which for\nsimplicity we also assume is a linear\nrelationship. With no cost of plasticity,\npopulations with b closer to B are likely to\npersist under higher rates of environmen-\ntal change.\nA Research Program\nThis model can be combined with\nenvironmental projections to ask whether\nfuture rates of environmental change will\nthreaten\nthe\npersistence\nof\nparticular\npopulations or species. Application of the\nmodel\nrequires\nmultiple\nsteps,\nwhich\npreviously have been undertaken in isola-\ntion or in combination, although all have\nrarely been completed together.\nIdentify Ecologically Important Traits\nAffecting Population Growth\nEcological investigation in the field is\nneeded to identify traits that potentially\ndetermine adaptation to a specific envi-\nronment. For instance, for ectotherms\nsuch\nas\ninsects\nand\nreptiles,\nthermal\nadaptation may occur not only through\nphysiological traits governing energy me-\ntabolism, but also through behavioural\nand\nmorphological\ntraits\ninvolved\nin\nmovement between shaded and sunny\npatches [29]. For many bird species,\nadaptation to global warming involves\nadjusting their breeding date so that\nreproduction coincides with a peak in\nprey density [30].\nThe strength (and direction) of natural\nselection c has been estimated in many\nplant and animal taxa by regressing the\nfitness of individuals on their phenotypes\n[31,32]. Most of these studies focus on\nrelative fitness, which determines the evo-\nlutionary dynamics. However, absolute\nfitness and rmax are needed to understand\nhow phenotypic traits influence population\ndynamics. Analysis of natural selection has\nbeen extended to age- or stage-structured\npopulations, allowing identification of parts\nof the life cycle where phenotypes most\nstrongly influence demography [33\u201336].\nBox 2. A Model of Phenotypic Evolution and Persistence under\nSustained Environmental Change\nWe assume that a continuous environmental parameter e (e.g., temperature or\nprecipitation) changes at a constant rate g in time. Adaptation to this changing\nenvironment is mediated by a quantitative trait z that determines fitness. Selection\non multiple correlated traits also can be incorporated [20], but for simplicity we focus\non single trait. Population growth is assumed to be density-independent, which can\nbe a good approximation even with density dependence, if the population remains\nwell below the carrying capacity because of maladaptation. In contrast to the original\nmodel and its recent extensions [13,20], we include phenotypic plasticity in the trait z,\nsuch that a given change in the environment directly modifies the phenotype of each\nindividual by a constant amount. The rate of environmental change is expressed per\nunit time (e.g., uC per year) instead of per generation.\nUnder\nsustained\nenvironmental\nchange,\nassuming\nconstant\ngenetic\nand\nphenotypic variance and strength of stabilizing selection, the rate of phenotypic\nevolution eventually reaches a steady state where the mean phenotype lags a\nconstant distance behind the changing optimum phenotype (Text S1). If this\ndistance is such that the population has a negative growth rate, extinction occurs.\nThe maximum rate of environmental change that allows long-term persistence of\nthe population (or critical rate of environmental change) is\ngc~\n\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\ufb03\n2rmaxc\nT\nr\nh2s2\nB{b\nj\nj :\n\u00f01\u00de\nThe original model [13] revealed how the phenotypic variance s2 and heritability\nh2 of the trait, the strength of stabilizing selection c, and the maximum intrinsic\nrate of population growth rmax determined the critical rate of environmental\nchange in the absence of phenotypic plasticity.\nThree other parameters included here emphasize important factors affecting\npersistence\nwhen\nthe\ndirectional\nenvironmental\nchange\nis\nexpressed\nin\nenvironmental units per unit time. First is the generation time T. The remaining\ntwo parameters are the environmental sensitivity of selection B, which measures\nhow changes in the environment influence the optimum phenotype, and\nphenotypic plasticity b, which quantifies the direct impact of the environment on\ndevelopment of individual phenotypes. The critical rate of environmental change\nfor long-term persistence increases with decreasing absolute difference between\nthe environmental sensitivity of selection and phenotypic plasticity. Although\nplasticity causes weaker natural selection on the trait and smaller genetic\nresponse to selection, this is more than compensated by the plastic phenotypic\nchange that brings the mean phenotype closer to the optimum (Text S1).\nPlasticity may also entail a fitness cost [59]. The cost of plasticity decreases rmax,\nwhich can then be formulated as\nrmax~ r0{b2\u0003\n2v2\nb\n\u0004\n\u0005\nT\n\u00f02\u00de\nwhere r0 is the per-generation growth rate of a population with optimum\nphenotype and no plasticity, and 1\n\u0003\nv2\nb quantifies the magnitude of the cost for a\ngiven plasticity b. By decreasing rmax, the cost of plasticity decreases the critical\nrate of environmental change, thus opposing the beneficial effect of plasticity on\ngc. The overall effect of phenotypic plasticity on the critical rate of environmental\nchange is shown in Figure 2 for several values of the cost of plasticity. When the\ncost of plasticity is above a threshold (v2\nbvv2\nlim), there is an intermediate value of\nplasticity that maximizes the critical rate of environmental change.\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n3\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\nEstimate Genetic Variance and\nPlasticity\nThe question of whether genetic varia-\ntion (h2s2) along the direction of natural\nselection limits the rate of evolution has\nmotivated many studies. For instance, in\nthe North American prairie plant Chamae-\ncrista fasciculate, small genetic variance for a\nlinear combination of traits has been\npredicted to limit the response to selection\ncaused by climate change [25]. Similarly,\nit was suggested that lack of genetic\nvariation for desiccation and cold resis-\ntance restricts the geographic range of\nseveral Drosophila species [37] and would\nlimit the response to projected climate\nchange in one of them [38]. Changes in\nthe genetic and phenotypic variation with\nthe environment may also be important.\nFor example, the response to selection on\nbody weight in wild Soay sheep is reduced\nbecause of lower heritability in environ-\nments where selection is stronger [39].\nThe importance of phenotypic plasticity\nfor rapid evolution in response to direc-\ntional environmental change has only\nrecently been fully appreciated. Many\nauthors have observed adaptive phenotyp-\nic evolution without being able to firmly\nattribute it to genetic change (reviewed in\n[40]), but relatively\nfew studies have\nprogressed from considering plasticity as\na nuisance parameter to measuring norms\nof reaction, and their slopes b, in the\ncontext of climate change [41]. This was\ndone recently for reproductive timing in\nmammals [42] and birds [43,44].\nMeasure the Environmental\nSensitivity of Selection\nFew investigators have measured the\nenvironmental sensitivity of phenotypic\nselection as described by parameter B in\nBox 2. The most relevant studies have\nmeasured selection in a small number of\ndiscrete environments. This approach has\nbeen applied to birds to describe the\ninfluence of changing seasonality on selec-\ntion on breeding date [45], and in plants\nto examine the impact of drought on\nselection on physiological traits [46,47]. It\nhas also been combined with experimental\nmanipulation of the environment, mainly\nin plants, using either abiotic [48] or biotic\nfactors,\nsuch\nas\ncrowding\n[49,50]\nor\nnatural enemies [51,52]. Other studies\nhave employed ecological criteria to iden-\ntify changes in the optimum phenotype\nwithout actually measuring selection. For\ninstance, the optimum egg-laying date for\nbirds can be deduced from the temporal\npeak in food availability determined by the\npopulation dynamics of insects on which\nthey feed [53].\nWhat emerges from this brief outline is\nthat two key areas of study are lacking: the\nquantification of the environmental sensi-\ntivity of selection across continuous envi-\nronments and the detailed investigation of\nphenotypic plasticity, including its costs\nand limits under sustained environmental\nchange.\nFurther\nwork,\nsuch\nas\nthat\noutlined below, would begin to make\npredictive approaches possible.\nPhenotypic Selection along an\nEnvironmental Gradient\nA relationship between an environmen-\ntal variable and a measure of selection,\neither observed in the wild or derived from\nan experiment, has been argued to be the\nstrongest evidence for the cause of natural\nselection [54]. Quantification of this rela-\ntionship is required to predict population\nevolution and persistence in a changing\nenvironment. Most of the studies high-\nlighted above compared selective pressures\namong discrete environmental states, often\ninterpreted\nas\nstresses\n(but\nsee\n[39]).\nenvironment \ntrait\nenvironment \nfitness\nReaction \nnorms\nAdaptive \nlandscape\nTolerance \ncurves\nfitness\nenvironment \ntrait\nFigure 1. Tolerance curves and phenotypic plasticity. First row: norms of reaction for three genotypes (colored lines); second row: generalized\nadaptive landscape depicting fitness as a function of the phenotype and the environment, with the reaction norms projected up onto the fitness\nsurface from the lower plane; third row: environmental tolerance curves representing slices through the adaptive landscape along the lines defined\nby the reaction norms. The three columns represent alternative scenarios described in the text. In the lower left panel, the dashed green and dashed\nred tolerance curves include costs of plasticity.\ndoi:10.1371/journal.pbio.1000357.g001\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n4\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\nCurrent global change, however, mainly\ninvolves continuous environmental vari-\nables for which precise time series and\nprojections are available. The environ-\nmental\nsensitivity\nof\nselection\nshould\ntherefore\nbe\nestimated\nby\nmeasuring\nphenotypic selection along a continuous\nenvironmental gradient. Apart from mea-\nsuring a fundamental parameter of the\nmodel, this would also allow its basic\nassumptions to be tested. In particular, our\nmodel (like previous ones) assumes that\nenvironmental change primarily alters the\noptimum phenotype with little impact on\nthe width of the fitness function (Figure 1),\nbut this assumption has hardly ever been\ntested empirically.\nMeasurement of selection in several\nenvironments may be difficult to carry\nout in the field because of lack of con-\ntrol over environmental parameters. For\nsome species such measurements could be\nperformed in controlled laboratory con-\nditions, provided the relationship between\nfitness in the laboratory and in the wild\ncan be established. Alternatively, perfor-\nmance can be measured in the laboratory\nand\nthe\nrelationship\nbetween\nperfor-\nmance and fitness assessed in the wild\n[55].\nStudies of thermal tolerance curves in\nectotherms commonly measure fitness in\ncontinuous environments. However, these\nstudies generally relate fitness (or perfor-\nmance)\ndirectly\nto\nthe\nenvironment,\nwhich\nmakes\nit\ndifficult\nto\nproduce\nevolutionary predictions and to test them\nexperimentally [56]. Modelling tolerance\ncurves with an underlying phenotypic\ntrait subject to natural selection and\nphenotypic plasticity may prove more\nfruitful, since it should allow predictions\nabout the dynamics of tolerance curve\nevolution (Box 3).\nCosts and Limits of Plasticity in\na Changing Environment\nPlasticity in Extreme Environments\nThe model in Box 2 assumes a linear\nreaction norm, implying that a given\namount of environmental change always\nproduces\nthe same plastic phenotypic\nchange. Plasticity is generally studied in\nthe context of environments that vary in\nspace or fluctuate in time with a stationary\ndistribution, but little is known about\nplastic responses outside the usual range\nof variation. Extreme environments may\ndisrupt the plastic response, such that the\nreaction norm may take any shape in\nenvironments that were rarely encoun-\ntered before [57]. This argument is based\non the theory of the evolution of reaction\nnorm\nin\nheterogeneous\nenvironments,\nassuming little genetic constraint on reac-\ntion norm shape. However, reaction norm\nshapes are likely to be genetically con-\nstrained. For many traits, plastic pheno-\ntypic responses should reach a physiolog-\nical\nlimit\nand\n\u2018\u2018saturate\u2019\u2019\nin\nextreme\nenvironments [58]. For instance, body size\nor metabolic rate obviously cannot in-\ncrease\nor\ndecrease\nindefinitely\nunder\nsustained environmental change. For oth-\ner traits, disruption of homeostasis may\ncause the plastic response to be amplified\nin extreme environments. Both of these\nmechanisms could generate skewed toler-\nance curves like those observed for re-\nsponse to temperature, even when pheno-\ntypic selection is symmetric (Box 3).\nCosts of Plasticity and the Generalist\nversus Specialist Trade-Off\nPhenotypic plasticity may entail several\ntypes of fitness costs to the organism\nindependent of the expressed phenotype\n[59]. Here, we shall only distinguish two\nkinds of costs of plasticity: constitutive and\ninduced. A constitutive cost reduces indi-\nvidual\nfitness depending only on the\ndegree of plasticity. This includes the cost\nof maintaining physiological machinery\nthat allows phenotypic plasticity or acquir-\ning information about the environment\n[59]. The model in Box 2 focuses on such\ncosts. In contrast an induced cost is a\nreduction in fitness that depends on the\namount of plastic phenotypic change. This\nkind of cost is physiological and can be\nBox 3. Tolerance Curves and Phenotypic Plasticity\nEnvironmental tolerance curves relating fitness (or performance) to abiotic\nenvironmental variables such as temperature [56] or salinity [77] have been\nstudied for a wide variety of organisms, ranging from reptiles and amphibians to\ninsects and plants [56]. They are generally characterized by a few descriptive\nvariables, such as critical environments (where fitness or performance vanishes),\noptimum environment (where fitness is maximized), and skewness. Previous\nmodels investigated the benefits of broad versus narrow tolerance curves under\nseveral forms of environmental change [61,62,78], but they failed to produce\npredictions about the dynamics of and constrains on tolerance curve evolution.\nRecently there have been calls for new theoretical developments with clearer\nempirically testable outcomes [56].\nWe propose that incorporating phenotypically plastic traits, which are under\nstabilizing selection through their influence on lifetime fitness [33,34,79], can\nclarify how tolerance curves emerge and evolve (Figure 1). With linear reaction\nnorms and constant strength of stabilizing selection across environments (ridge\nwith constant width in the adaptive landscape), the reaction norm slope\ndetermines tolerance breadth, while the reaction norm intercept (or elevation)\ndetermines the optimum environment (first column in Figure 1). With genetic\nvariation in the slope of reaction norms, the tolerance breadth may evolve as a\nconsequence of evolving phenotypic plasticity in the underlying trait. Including a\ncost of plasticity, where fitness decreases with reaction norm slope regardless of\nthe trait value [80,81], produces a generalist\u2013specialist trade-off between\ntolerance breadth and maximum fitness, corresponding to the intuitive idea that\na \u2018\u2018Jack-of-all-trades is a master of none.\u2019\u2019 This is illustrated in the bottom left\npanel of Figure 1\u2014with cost an increasing function of plasticity (dashed lines), the\nred dashed tolerance curve has a lower maximum fitness than the green dashed\ncurve, because the former reaction norm has greater plasticity. This approach can\nbe used to make testable predictions in specific cases based on measures of the\nvariability, inheritance, and plasticity of phenotypic traits.\nThermal tolerance curves generally are strongly skewed, with fitness decreasing\nsteeply as temperature approaches the critical thermal maximum [56]. This could\nbe caused by non-linear reaction norms for underlying traits, as illustrated by the\nsecond column in Figure 1. Plastic phenotypic responses that saturate (yellow\ngenotype) or increase exponentially (green genotype) in extreme environments\ncould both induce skewed tolerance curves. Alternatively, skewed tolerance\ncurves could be caused by the strength of stabilizing selection (width of the\nfitness ridge) changing with the environment (third column in Figure 1). Finally,\nthe fitness function acting on the trait may itself be skewed in all environments,\nthe height of the fitness ridge may depend on the environment, or the optimum\nphenotype may change non-linearly with the environment (not shown). These\nfive possible causes of skewness have different implications for the evolution of\nthermal tolerance in a changing environment, and need to be tested empirically.\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n5\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\nunderstood in terms of constraints on\nenergy allocation. It applies mainly to\nlabile traits that may change repeatedly\nduring the lifetime of an individual, such\nas breeding date for birds [60].\nIn the literature on tolerance curves, the\ncost of plasticity is generally expressed as a\ntrade-off between tolerance breadth and\nfitness\nin\nthe\noptimum\nenvironment,\ncorresponding to the intuitive idea that\nthe\n\u2018\u2018Jack-of-all-trades\nis\na\nmaster\nof\nnone.\u2019\u2019 This has been modelled [61,62],\nbut the empirical evidence is still contro-\nversial\n[56,63]\nand\nbased\nmainly\non\ncomparative data among taxa rather than\non within-species variation (but see [64]).\nWe propose that this trade-off may be a\nconsequence of the cost of plasticity for an\nunderlying\nphenotypic\ntrait\n(Box\n3,\nFigure 1).\nIn the model of Box 2 and Figure 2, we\nshow how a constitutive cost of plasticity\ncan limit the critical rate of environmental\nchange for population persistence. An\ninduced cost would yield a similar result\nin\nthis\nmodel\nsince\nthe\nenvironment\nchanges at a constant rate. The cost of\nplasticity may thus limit population per-\nsistence in a changing environment, yet\nlittle is known about its importance in\nnatural\npopulations.\nA\nrecent\nreview\nshowed that such costs may be widespread\nbut weak [65]. Further research is needed\nto measure costs of plasticity for organisms\nwith\nlong\ngenerations\n(such\nas\nlarge\nmammals and trees) or with life cycles\nthat depend on seasonal timing (e.g.,\ninteraction of temperature and photoperi-\nod [66]), which rely most on plasticity to\npersist in a rapidly changing environment.\nLimitations of the Model\nOur\nmodel\nincludes\na\nnumber\nof\nsimplifying assumptions. We assume a\nconstant shape of the fitness function\nacross environments, allowing only the\noptimum phenotype to change with the\nenvironment. However, the strength of\nstabilizing selection around the optimum\nphenotype c may depend on the environ-\nment (Figure 1, third column, second row).\nFurthermore the maximum fitness rmax\nmay generally be lower in more extreme\nenvironments\nbecause\nof\nphysiological\nconstraints,\nsuch\nthat\nthe\nridge\nin\nFigure 1 would have an intermediate\nmaximum. This was shown to occur in a\nrecent\ncomparative\nstudy\nof\nthermal\ntolerance curves among several insect\ntaxa, where the maximum fitness was\nlower for species that had their optimum\nat\na\nlower\ntemperature\n[67].\nOther\ndemographic parameters including the\ngeneration time T may change with the\nenvironment. Genotype 6 environment\ninteraction (or genetic variance in plastic-\nity) can cause the genetic variance (h2s2) to\ndepend\non\nthe\nenvironment\n[68\u201371].\nAlthough these mechanisms are not in-\ncluded in our simple model, they all can be\nanalyzed theoretically and studied empir-\nically, and should be included where they\nare suspected to be important.\nPlasticity itself may evolve if it varies\ngenetically, and new environments can\ncause directional selection on plasticity\n[72,73]. However, more information is\nneeded about plasticity and its inheritance\nin extreme environments before the evo-\nlution of plasticity can be included in the\nanalysis of persistence under sustained\nenvironmental change.\nFinally, we considered a population that\ncannot disperse nor receive migrants from\nother populations experiencing different\nenvironments. We focused on this situa-\ntion\nbecause\nit\nis\none\nthat\nis\nmost\ncommonly overlooked in niche modelling\nstudies. Our model thus applies best to\nspecies with habitats restricted by dispersal\nbarriers or species which disperse slowly\nrelative to the rate of environmental\nchange [74]. At the other extreme, a\npopulation may be able to persist by\nfollowing its preferred environment in\nspace without any evolution, as assumed\nin niche modelling, but this is very unlikely\nfor species occupying fragmented habitats.\nFor populations that can both disperse and\nevolve in response to a changing environ-\nment, gene flow among populations with\ndifferent environments may limit local\nadaptation and restrict the geographic\nrange of the population or even cause\nextinction [74,75].\nConclusion\nOur aim was to describe an approach\nbased on evolutionary and demographic\nmechanisms that can be used to make\npredictions on population persistence in a\nchanging environment and to highlight\nthe most important variables to measure.\nWhile this approach is obviously more\ncostly and time-consuming than niche\nmodelling, its results are also likely to be\nmore useful for specific purposes because it\nexplicitly incorporates the factors that limit\npopulation\nresponse\nto\nenvironmental\nchange.\nThe feasibility of such a mechanistic\napproach has been demonstrated by a few\nrecent studies. Deutsch et al. [76] used\nthermal tolerance curves to predict the\nfitness consequence of climate change for\nmany species of terrestrial insects across\nlatitudes, but without explicitly consider-\ning phenotypic plasticity or genetic evolu-\ntion.\nKearney\net\nal.\n[12]\ncombined\nbiophysical models of energy transfers\nwith\nmeasures\nof\nheritability\nof\negg\ndesiccation to predict how climate change\nFigure 2. Critical rate of environmental change with costly phenotypic plasticity. The\nmaximum rate of environmental change allowing long-term persistence of a population, gc, is\nplotted against plasticity b, for several values of the cost of plasticity. For a given plasticity b, the\ncost increases with decreasing vb. For each vb, rates of environmental change higher than the\ncorresponding line cause population extinction. Parameters: rmax = 0.140, T = 1, c = 1/51, B = 2,\ns2 = 1, and h2 = 0.5.\ndoi:10.1371/journal.pbio.1000357.g002\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n6\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\nwould affect the distribution of the mos-\nquito\nAedes\naegiptii\nin\nAustralia.\nEgg\ndesiccation was treated as a threshold\ntrait, but the possibility of phenotypic\nplasticity or evolution of the threshold\nwas not considered. These encouraging\nefforts call for more empirical studies\nwhere genetic evolution and phenotypic\nplasticity are combined with demography\nto make predictions about population\npersistence in a changing environment.\nThe simple approach we have outlined is a\nnecessary step towards a more specific and\ncomprehensive understanding of the influ-\nence of environmental change on popula-\ntion extinction.\nSupporting Information\nText S1\nA model of plasticity, evo-\nlution, and extinction in a changing\nenvironment.\nFound\nat:\ndoi:10.1371/journal.pbio.\n1000357.s001 (0.48 MB PDF)\nAcknowledgments\nWe thank A.P. Evolution 64:\n1143\u20131150.\nPLoS Biology | www.plosbiology.org\n8\nApril 2010 | Volume 8 | Issue 4 | e1000357\n"}, "28": {"title": "Plasticity of CD4+ T Cell Lineage Differentiation", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1016/j.immuni.2009.05.001", "text": null}, "29": {"title": "Plasticity of Adult Stem Cells", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1016/s0092-8674(04)00208-9", "text": null}, "30": {"title": "Evolutionary and plastic responses to climate change in terrestrial plant populations", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1111/eva.12112", "text": null}, "31": {"title": "Studying global change through investigation of the plastic responses of xylem anatomy in tree rings", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1469-8137.2009.03030.x", "text": null}, "32": {"title": "Systemic Deletion of the Myelin-Associated Outgrowth Inhibitor Nogo-A Improves Regenerative and Plastic Responses after Spinal Cord Injury", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1016/s0896-6273(03)00226-5", "text": null}, "33": {"title": "Climate change in the oceans: evolutionary versus phenotypically plastic responses of marine animals and plants", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1111/eva.12109", "text": null}, "34": {"title": "Evolutionary and plastic responses of freshwater invertebrates to climate change: realized patterns and future potential", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.1111/eva.12108", "text": null}, "35": {"title": "Delayed plastic responses to anodal tDCS in older adults", "doi": "https://doi.org/10.3389/fnagi.2014.00115", "text": "ORIGINAL RESEARCH ARTICLE\npublished: 06 June 2014\ndoi: 10.3389/fnagi.2014.00115\nDelayed plastic responses to anodal tDCS in older adults\nHakuei Fujiyama1,2*, Jane Hyde1, Mark R. Hinder 1, Seok-Jin Kim1,3, Graeme H. McCormack 4,\nJames C. Vickers 4 and Jeffery J. Summers1,5\n1 Human Motor Control Laboratory, School of Medicine, University of Tasmania, Hobart, TAS, Australia\n2 Movement Control and Neuroplasticity Research Group, Department of Kinesiology, KU Leuven, Leuven, Belgium\n3 Motor Behavior Laboratory, Department of Physical Education, Seoul National University, Seoul, South Korea\n4 Wicking Dementia Research and Education Centre, University of Tasmania, Hobart, TAS, Australia\n5 Research Institute for Sport and Exercise Sciences, Liverpool John Moores University, Liverpool, UK\nEdited by:\nGeorge E. Barreto, Ponti\ufb01cia\nUniversidad Javeriana, Colombia\nReviewed by:\nLutz J\u00e4ncke, University of Zurich,\nSwitzerland\nJared Cooney Horvath, University of\nMelbourne, Australia\n*Correspondence:\nHakuei Fujiyama, Movement Control\nand Neuroplasticity Research Group,\nDepartment of Kinesiology, KU\nLeuven, Tervuurse Vest 101, B-3001\nHeverlee, Leuven, Belgium\ne-mail: hak.fujiyama@faber.\nkuleuven.be\nDespite the abundance of research reporting the neurophysiological and behavioral effects\nof transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) in healthy young adults and clinical\npopulations, the extent of potential neuroplastic changes induced by tDCS in healthy older\nadults is not well understood. The present study compared the extent and time course\nof anodal tDCS-induced plastic changes in primary motor cortex (M1) in young and older\nadults. Furthermore, as it has been suggested that neuroplasticity and associated learning\ndepends on the brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) gene polymorphisms, we also\nassessed the impact of BDNF polymorphism on these effects. Corticospinal excitability\nwas examined using transcranial magnetic stimulation before and following (0, 10, 20,\n30 min) anodal tDCS (30 min, 1 mA) or sham in young and older adults. While the overall\nextent of increases in corticospinal excitability induced by anodal tDCS did not vary reliably\nbetween young and older adults, older adults exhibited a delayed response; the largest\nincrease in corticospinal excitability occurred 30 min following stimulation for older adults,\nbut immediately post-stimulation for the young group. BDNF genotype did not result in\nsigni\ufb01cant differences in the observed excitability increases for either age group. The\npresent study suggests that tDCS-induced plastic changes are delayed as a result of healthy\naging, but that the overall ef\ufb01cacy of the plasticity mechanism remains unaffected.\nKeywords: aging, plasticity, transcranial direct current stimulation, transcranial magnetic stimulation, brain-derived\nneurotrophic factor\nINTRODUCTION\nTranscranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) is a non-invasive\nbrain stimulation (NIBS) technique that induces transmem-\nbrane neuronal potential and thus in\ufb02uences the level of cortical\nexcitability (see review Nitsche et al., 2008; Zaghi et al., 2010). It is\nthought that the neuronal changes associated with the persisting\neffects of tDCS are analogous to activity-dependent synaptic plas-\nticity, i.e., long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression\n(LTD; Di Lazzaro et al., 2012). There are a number of lines of\nevidence for the induction of LTP by DC stimulation. Fritsch\net al. (2010) showed that the synaptic effects of direct current\nstimulation which induced LTP in mouse motor cortex (M1)\nslices is dependent on N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor\nactivation. Ranieri et al. (2012) further demonstrated that DC\nstimulation applied to rat brain slices modulated LTP in a polar-\nity speci\ufb01c manner, i.e., modulation of LTP was increased by\nanodal and reduced by cathodal DC stimulation. Pharmacolog-\nical studies have also shown that tDCS after-effects are affected\nby NMDA receptor antagonist dextromethorphane (Nitsche et al.,\n2003a; Ranieri et al., 2012). These results strongly indicate that the\neffects induced by tDCS share similarities with activity-dependent\nsynaptic plasticity, such as LTP and LTD (Di Lazzaro et al., 2012).\nFurthermore, DC stimulation also modulates LTP induced by\nother NIBS techniques and interferes with learning and mem-\nory processes which are strongly associated with LTP (Kim and\nLinden, 2007). Thus tDCS is considered to have capacity to induce\nLTP/LTD-like plasticity.\nThe application of tDCS over M1 elicits changes in corti-\ncospinal excitability in a polarity speci\ufb01c manner: motor evoked\npotentials (MEPs) evoked by transcranial magnetic stimulation\n(TMS) are potentiated by anodal tDCS and suppressed by catho-\ndal tDCS (Nitsche and Paulus, 2000). Furthermore, the technique\nis extremely well tolerated by most individuals and allows an easily\napplied sham condition to which the participant is readily blinded.\nFinally, it has been shown that tDCS can be combined with motor\nand cognitive tasks to facilitate learning.\nDespite the abundance of research on the behavioral effects\nof tDCS on motor function (see review Reis and Fritsch, 2011)\nshowing increased levels of performance in both healthy (Nitsche\net al., 2003b; Antal et al., 2004; Vines et al., 2006) and clini-\ncal populations, such as stroke patients (Hummel et al., 2005;\nKim et al., 2009), only a limited number of studies have inves-\ntigated the effects of tDCS over M1 in healthy older adults\n(Hummel et al., 2010; Zimerman et al., 2013). These two studies\ndid not, however, assess the tDCS-induced changes in corti-\ncospinal excitability. While the behavioral improvements suggest\nthat the plastic changes within M1 induced by tDCS were sub-\nstantial enough to elicit behavioral change, it is unknown whether\nthese neural changes varied relative to the changes expected in\nyoung adults. Indeed, there is some evidence that older individuals\nFrontiers in Aging Neuroscience\nwww.frontiersin.org\nJune 2014 | Volume 6 | Article 115 | 1\nFujiyama et al.\nIs aging brain plastic?\nmay have reduced neuroplasticity (Fathi et al., 2010), at least when\nassessed by the paired-associative stimulation (PAS) technique.\nThe overall conclusion that can be drawn is that there is no con-\nsensus on the degree to which neuroplasticity is affected by healthy\naging (Oliviero, 2010).\nRecently, brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) a neu-\nrotrophin within the secretory protein family, has been suggested\nto play a crucial role in neuroplasticity and associated learning\n(Pascual-Leone et al., 2011). The most common forms of BDNF\npolymorphism are Val66Met and Val66Val (Lu, 2003). These\nBDNF polymorphisms have been shown to differentially mod-\nulate human cortical plasticity as a response to training (Kleim\net al., 2006), brain stimulation (Cheeran et al., 2008), and motor\nlearning (Fritsch et al., 2010). Thus, the BDNF example suggests\nthat individuals with a certain genetic predisposition may show a\ndifferent response to interventions that modulate brain plasticity \u2013\neither in a use-dependent manner (i.e., motor or cognitive train-\ning) or induced via NIBS techniques. The relationship between\ntDCS induced aftereffects and BDNF genotype, however, is still\nunclear.\nGiven the current uncertainty as to the effects of aging on neu-\nroplasticity in M1 and its interaction with BDNF genotype, the\npresent study investigated, for the \ufb01rst time, age-related changes\nin the degree of plasticity following anodal tDCS (facilitatory)\nand the in\ufb02uence of BDNF gene polymorphisms on neuroplastic-\nity in the aging brain. Recently, large inter-individual variability\nin response to NIBS techniques has been recognized (M\u00fcller-\nDahlhaus et al., 2008; Datta et al., 2012; Hamada et al., 2012;\nL\u00f3pez-Alonso et al., 2014; Wiethoff et al., 2014). Of further inter-\nest in the present study, therefore, was to determine whether the\nresponsiveness to anodal tDCS is affected by age and explore\nwhether this inter-individual variation is associated with BDNF\ngenotype.\nMATERIALS AND METHODS\nPARTICIPANTS\nForty healthy volunteers, consisting of 20 older adults recruited\nfrom the local community (7 males, 13 females, age M = 68.3,\nSD = 7.9 years) and 20 young adults recruited from stu-\ndents at the University of Tasmania (10 males, 10 females, age\nM = 22.7, SD = 3.3 years), participated in the study. Within\nthe older group, participants had similar socio-economic sta-\ntus and were involved in active social activities and/or paid\nemployment. All participants completed at least high school\neducation. The Mini-Mental State Examination (Dick et al.,\n1984) was used to screen for cognitive de\ufb01cits in the sam-\nple of older adults. All participants scored within the normal\nrange (score \u226526) and were free of any neurological, symp-\ntomatic cardiovascular disease, diabetes or hypertension. Ethics\napproval for the study was obtained from the Human Research\nEthics (Tasmania) Network and written informed consent was\nobtained prior to participation in the study. All participants\nwere screened for contra-indications to TMS. We also consid-\nered the effect of physical activity on the response to tDCS.\nParticipants completed the International Physical Activity Ques-\ntionnaire (IPAQ) which assesses the amount of time during\nthe previous seven days spent engaging in a range of physical\nactivities. The IPAQ has been shown to produce reliable and\nrepeatable measures of physical activities in young (Craig et al.,\n2003; Hagstromer et al., 2006) and older adults (Tomioka et al.,\n2011).\nBDNF GENOTYPING\nThree young and one older participant did not feel com-\nfortable undergoing the characterization of the genotype.\nThe remaining 36 participants gave written informed con-\nsent prior to participation in the DNA sampling. ARMS-PCR\n(Sheikh et al., 2010) was performed to amplify the BDNF gene\nregion containing rs6265.\nUsing the four primers P1 for-\nward CCTACAGTTCCACCAGGTGAGAAGAGTG, P2 (reverse)\nTCATGGACATGTTTGCAGCATCTAGGTA, P3 (G allele speci\ufb01c)\nCTGGTCCTCATCCAACAGCTCTTCTATAAC and P4 (A allele\nspeci\ufb01c) ATCATTGGCTGACACTTTCGAACCCA we could dis-\ntinguish two allele speci\ufb01c amplicons 253 bp (val) and/or 201 bp\n(met) along with the 401 bp amplicon (entire rs6265 region\nas internal control). The ARMS-PCR reaction was carried out\nin a total volume of 12 \u03bcl containing 1\u00d7 REDExtract-N-\nAmpTM PCR ReadyMixTM (Sigma-Aldrich, USA), 1 \u03bcM of\neach of the four primers (P1, P2, P3, and P4) and 10 ng\nof genomic DNA. Thermocycling conditions were:\ndenatu-\nration at 94\u25e6C for 3 min,\n30 cycles of 95\u25e6C for 45 s,\n62\u25e6C for 60 s and 72\u25e6C for 60 s,\nwith a \ufb01nal exten-\nsion at 72\u25e6C for 2 min.\nARMS-PCR products were then\nresolved on a 4% agarose gel. The samples could then be\nclassi\ufb01ed as Val/Val (253/253 bp), Val/Met (253/201 bp), or\nMet/Met (201/201 bp) based on the observed banding pat-\ntern.\nAll samples should have the rs6265 internal control\n(401 bp) band present. Every sample was genotyped from at\nleast two independent PCR reactions to ensure \ufb01delity. Par-\nticipants were divided into two groups according to their\ngenotype, either (i) homozygous for the val allele (Val/Val)\nor (ii) homozygous and heterozygous for the Met allele\n(Met/Met, Val/Met), respectively. Participants and examiner were\nblinded with respect to the genotype at the time of examina-\ntion.\nTMS PROCEDURE AND EMG RECORDING\nTMS was used to compare corticospinal excitability of projections\nfrom the cortical representation of the right forearm \ufb02exor, \ufb02exor\ncarpi radialis (FCR),within the left M1, before (baseline), immedi-\nately after and at 10, 20, and 30 min intervals following tDCS (see\nTranscranial Direct Current Stimulation section below). Single-\npulse TMS was applied using a standard \ufb01gure of eight coil (7 cm\ndiameter of each wing) connected to a Magstim 200 (Magstim\nCompany, Dyfed, UK). The TMS coil was held tangentially over\nthe scalp to induce a posterior\u2013anterior current \ufb02ow and to opti-\nmally elicit MEPs in the right FCR. We chose a forearm \ufb02exor\nmuscle rather than an intrinsic hand muscle, as proximal muscles\nof the upper limb are often the targets of rehabilitation (Carson\net al., 2013). EMG surface electrodes (Ag/AgCl) were placed over\nthe right FCR in a belly tendon montage and signals were ampli\ufb01ed\nwith a gain of 1000, band pass \ufb01ltered (10\u2013500 Hz) and sampled\nat 2000 Hz using a 16-bit AD system (CED 1902, Cambridge, UK).\nEMG data were fed to disk for of\ufb02ine analysis. At the beginning\nFrontiers in Aging Neuroscience\nwww.frontiersin.org\nJune 2014 | Volume 6 | Article 115 | 2\nFujiyama et al.\nIs aging brain plastic?\nof each session each individual\u2019s resting motor threshold (rMT)\nwas determined as the lowest intensity that evoked MEPs of greater\nthan 50 \u03bcV in at least three out of \ufb01ve consecutive trials for the FCR\n(e.g., Carroll et al.,2008). The optimal scalp position for induction\nof MEPs in the right FCR was marked on the participant\u2019s head\nusing a felt tip pen. With both upper limbs relaxed and resting on\na pillow in the participant\u2019s lap, baseline MEP recruitment curves\nwere constructed by applying stimuli in steps of 10% between 90%\nand 160% of rMT. At each intensity, six pulses were delivered with\nan inter-stimulus interval of 5 s (Carson et al., 2013); thus each\nrecruitment curve took approximately 4 min to collect. For thirty\nparticipants, the order of stimulus intensities was randomized;\nhowever, due to a technical problem, for the 10 participants (\ufb01ve\nmales), the randomization of intensities was replaced with coun-\nterbalanced intensity steps. As no differences between recruitment\ncurves obtained in a ramping (systematically increased stimu-\nlus intensity) and random manner have been observed (Pearce\net al., 2013), it is unlikely that the changes to recruitment curve\nacquisition in\ufb02uenced the results obtained.\nTRANSCRANIAL DIRECT CURRENT STIMULATION (tDCS)\nThe direct current was generated by a battery-driven constant-\ndirect current stimulator (Magstim Company, Dyfed, UK).\nThe current was delivered to the participant through anodal\n(5 cm \u00d7 5 cm) and cathodal (6 cm \u00d7 8.5 cm) conductive rub-\nber electrodes that were placed inside pre-saline soaked and gelled\nsponges with conductive gel. Following the baseline measure-\nment, either anodal stimulation or sham stimulation was applied.\nThe anodal stimulation involved an initial two-second \u201cramp-\nup\u201d period during which the current was brought from 0 to\n1 mA. The current then remained at 1 mA for 30 min (Lin-\ndenberg et al., 2013). The sham stimulation involved the same\ninitial ramp. However, the current was then immediately ramped\ndown to zero over a 30 s period (Nitsche et al., 2008). The\nparticipants were blinded to tDCS conditions and were instructed\nin both sessions that they may feel a mild itching sensation\nunder the electrodes. That is, the participants were led to believe\nthey were receiving tDCS in both sessions (Kessler et al., 2012).\nFor both anodal tDCS and sham conditions the center of the\nanodal electrode was placed over the FCR representation in the\nleft primary motor cortex, the location of which was identi\ufb01ed\nin the initial setup phase of the experiment, while the catho-\ndal electrode was positioned over the contralateral supraorbital\nregion.\nPROCEDURE\nParticipants received sham and anodal tDCS in two separate ses-\nsions, one week apart at a similar time of day. The order of sham\nand anodal tDCS was counterbalanced across participants. Dur-\ning each session the participants were comfortably seated in a chair\nwith their left arm supported and stabilized on a pillow with the\nelbow in a semi-\ufb02exed position to ensure no muscle activations\nin the forearm and hand muscles. After establishing the rMT, the\nbaseline MEP recruitment curve was recorded. This was followed\nby 30 min of either sham or anodal tDCS. MEP recruitment curves\nwere then obtained immediately (0 min), 10, 20, and 30 min after\ncessation of tDCS (Figure 1).\nDATA PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS\nIn presenting the results,\nthe data are expressed as mean\n(M) \u00b1 95% con\ufb01dence intervals (CI). Using spearman\u2019s bivariate\ncorrelations we investigated whether IPAQ score was linearly cor-\nrelated with normalized area under the recruitment curve (AURC)\nvalues. We also considered gender in responses to tDCS, given\nthat there is evidence that PAS-induced neuroplasticity may be\nreduced in older females (Tecchio et al., 2008). Resting motor\nthresholds were examined by a 2(AGE: Young, Older) \u00d7 2(SEX:\nmale, female) \u00d7 2(GENOTYPE:Val66Val, met-carrier) \u00d7 2(STIM:\nanodal tDCS, Sham) repeated measures ANOVA.\nFIGURE 1 | Example of motor evoked potentials (MEPs) evoked in the right \ufb02exor carpi radialis (FCR) at pre and post (0, 10, 20, and 30 min) anodal\ntDCS from a typical young (top) and older (bottom) participant. Average MEPs at each stimulus intensity (90\u2013160% of rMT) were overlaid on top of each\nother.\nFrontiers in Aging Neuroscience\nwww.frontiersin.org\nJune 2014 | Volume 6 | Article 115 | 3\nFujiyama et al.\nIs aging brain plastic?\nMEP amplitude was measured by calculating the peak-to-peak\namplitudeinatimewindow20\u2013100msfollowingTMS.MEPswere\nsubsequently averaged across all trials at each stimulation intensity\nat each time point (pre, post 0, post 10, post 20, post 30) and for\neach participant. Trials in which root mean square (RMS) EMG\nexceeded 10 \u03bcV (Carson et al.,2004) during the 40 ms immediately\npreceding the TMS pulse were discarded. The mean MEP ampli-\ntude at each intensity and time point was then used to calculate\nthe AURC for each time point. The curve was bounded by TMS\nintensity using the trapezoidal rule (Potteiger et al., 2002; Carson\net al., 2013). More speci\ufb01cally, the following formula was used,\n\u0002 10(a+b)\n2\n,wherea andb representMEPamplitudesatconsecutive\nstimulus intensities, e.g., 90% rMT and 100% rMT. AURC for each\npost-stimulation time point was then normalized for each partici-\npant to AURC obtained at the baseline pre stimulation (anodal or\nsham) for that participant.\nA mixed factorial ANOVA was undertaken to assess post-\nstimulation normalized AURC (dependent variable) using AGE\n(Young, Older), SEX (Male, Female), GENOTYPE (Val66Val, met-\ncarrier), STIM (anodal tDCS, Sham), and TIME (post 0, post\n10, post 20, post 30) as independent variables. If the sphericity\nassumption was violated, Greenhouse-Geisser\u2019s degrees of free-\ndom adjustment was applied. Planned contrasts between groups\n(AGE, SEX, and GENOTYPE) at each time point and across\ntime points for each group separately were conducted to explore\nsigni\ufb01cant main and interaction effects.\nWe performed chi-square tests to evaluate the percentage of\nresponders and non-responders in two groups divided on the basis\nof BDNF, age, or sex. Non-responders were de\ufb01ned operationally\naccording to the ratio between pre and grand average of the post-\nanodal tDCS AURC values across time points (post 0, 10, 20,\nand 30) below 1 (Hamada et al., 2012). We chose this criterion to\naccept any increases in AURC as a possible neuroplastic response\nto anodal tDCS.\nThe critical p-value was set at 0.05. Cohen\u2019s d, Cramer\u2019s V and\npartial eta squared (\u03b72\np) values are provided as measure of effect\nsize, where appropriate. Cut-offs \u22650.1 small, \u22650.3 medium, \u22650.5\nlarge were applied for Cramer\u2019s V, \u22650.2 small, \u22650.5 medium, \u22650.8\nlarge were applied for Cohen\u2019s d and \u22650.01 small, \u22650.06 medium,\nand \u22650.14 large were applied for \u03b72\np (Sink and Stroh, 2006).\nRESULTS\nDue to a technical error resulting in MEPs not being recorded,\ndata from one young participant was excluded from all analyses.\nTable 1 summarizes demographic information, BDNF geno-\ntype, and motor thresholds in each session. The BDNF genotype\nanalysis for the remaining 35 participants for whom we had\ngenetic data revealed that 24 were homozygous for the Val allele\n(Val66Val), while 11 were Met-carriers including seven Val66Met\nheterozygotes and four homozygous for the Met allele.\nRESTING MOTOR THRESHOLD\nResting motor threshold (de\ufb01ned as a percentage of maxi-\nmum stimulator output) was signi\ufb01cantly higher in Met car-\nriers (51.27 \u00b1 3.25%) than Val66Val group (46.48 \u00b1 2.01%),\nF1,30 = 4.83, p = 0.04, \u03b72\np= 0.14. rMTs did not vary reli-\nably as a function of age group (Young, 48.37 \u00b1 2.87%; Older,\nTable 1 | Summary of demographic information and BDNF genotype.\nAge\nSex\nBDNF genotype\u2217\nM \u00b1 SD\nMale\nFemale\nVal66val\nVal66Met\nMat66Met\nYoung\n22.7 \u00b1 3.2\n11\n9\n11\n3\n2\nOlder\n68.3 \u00b1 7.9\n7\n13\n13\n4\n2\n\u2217Three young and one older participant did not consent to genotype determina-\ntion.\n49.10 \u00b1 2.03%) or session (anodal, 48.63 \u00b1 2.32%; sham,\n48.93 \u00b1 2.49%), Fs < 0.91, ps > 0.34, \u03b72\np = 0.02.\nTHE EFFECT OF AGE AND GENOTYPE ON PLASTICITY INDUCED BY\nANODAL tDCS\nRepeated measures ANOVA for normalized AURC data revealed\nthat there was a main effect of STIM, F1,30 = 4.97, p = 0.03,\n\u03b72\np = 0.12, indicating, as expected, that the increase in AURC\ninduced by anodal tDCS (1.34 \u00b1 0.16; +34%, signi\ufb01cant increase,\np < 0.001, d = 0.70) was signi\ufb01cantly larger than AURC changes\nfollowing sham tDCS (1.14 \u00b1 0.16). The main effect of AGE\nwas not signi\ufb01cant, F1,30 = 0.11, p = 0.74, \u03b72\np = 0.002, indi-\ncating that overall the magnitude of changes in post-tDCS AURC\nvalues were not statistically different between young and older\nadults. However, young and older adults showed different pat-\nterns in the modulation of AURC post-tDCS as indicated by a\nsigni\ufb01cant interaction of AGE x TIME, F3,90 = 4.68, p = 0.004,\n\u03b72\np = 0.11, which is best interpreted with reference to the signi\ufb01-\ncant three-way interaction of AGE x STIM x TIME, F3,90 = 2.84,\np = 0.04, \u03b72\np = 0.07. For young adults, although within the\nanodal condition AURC values were not signi\ufb01cantly differ-\nent between the different time points (ps > 0.17, ds < 0.32),\nAURC values at only post 0 and post 10 following tDCS were\nsigni\ufb01cantly higher than respective time points in the sham\ncondition (ps < 0.008, ds > 0.41). A different response pat-\ntern was observed in older adults with AURC values at post\n20 (1.40 \u00b1 0.33) and post 30 (1.53 \u00b1 0.35) being signi\ufb01cantly\nhigher than post 0 (1.04 \u00b1 0.14) and post 10 (1.13 \u00b1 0.20;\nps < 0.02, ds > 0.58) as well as at the respective post-sham time\npoints (ps < 0.02, ds > 0.34; Figure 2). Within the sham con-\ndition, AURC values at each time point were not signi\ufb01cantly\ndifferent, ps > 0.13, ds < 0.22. Finally, an important \ufb01nd-\ning was that the only between-group difference was observed\nat post 0 where the AURC value in young adults was signif-\nicantly larger than the value obtained for older adults at that\ntime point (p = 0.01, d = 0.85; Figure 2). Thus, the interaction\nbetween AGE and TIME was predominantly driven by older group\nshowing AURC value changes in time-dependent manner (i.e.,\ndelayed response to anodal stimulation), whereas the responses\nin young group were unchanged across time points following\nstimulation.\nInterestingly, all main effects and interactions including SEX\nand/orBDNFasafactorwerenotstatisticallysigni\ufb01cant,Fs<1.47,\nps > 0.23, \u03b72\np < 0.04, and all were associated with small effect\nsizes, suggesting that these factors may not be associated with the\nneuroplastic changes following anodal tDCS.\nFrontiers in Aging Neuroscience\nwww.frontiersin.org\nJune 2014 | Volume 6 | Article 115 | 4\nFujiyama et al.\nIs aging brain plastic?\nFIGURE 2 | Mean normalized AURC for young and older adults across post-stimulation [(A) anodal tDCS and (B) sham] time points. Error bars (95% CI)\nwhich include the value 1 (baseline: dotted horizontal line) indicate non-signi\ufb01cant differences at that time relative to baseline. Asterisks indicate a signi\ufb01cant\ndifference between groups (**p < 0.01).\nINTER-INDIVIDUAL VARIABILITY OF RESPONSES TO ANODAL tDCS\nInspection of each individual\u2019s data revealed that despite group\neffects indicating a signi\ufb01cant effect of stimulation, there were\nsome individuals who did not display the anticipated increase in\nAURC following anodal tDCS (Figure 3). Approximately 20% of\ntotal participants, speci\ufb01cally four young (two males, two females,\nM = 24.5, SD = 3.3 years) and four older females (M = 69.0,\nSD = 9.3 years), were identi\ufb01ed as non-responders exhibit-\ning AURC values across post-anodal tDCS time points below\n1. Responders consisted of 16 (seven males and nine females)\nolder adults (age range: 60\u201388 years, M = 67.7, SD = 7.8)\nand 15 young (nine males and six females) participants (age\nrange: 19\u201329 years, M = 23.0, SD = 3.1). Response to anodal\ntDCS did not differ by BDNF genotype (17 Val66Val and 10\nMet-carriers in responders), \u03c72(1, N = 35) = 1.72, p = 0.19,\nV = 0.22, age, \u03c72(1, N = 39) = 0.01, p = 0.94, V = 0.01,\nor sex, \u03c72(1, N = 39) = 0.82, p = 0.37, V = 0.15. In non-\nresponders, normalized AURC values between anodal and sham\nconditions at each time point were not statistically different\n(ps > 0.16, ds < 0.41). In both older and younger respon-\nders, there were no signi\ufb01cant correlations between total IPAQ\nscore and AURC values at any time point following anodal tDCS\n(rs < 0.38, ps > 0.16). Physical activity, therefore, did not appear\nto be associated with corticospinal excitability changes induced\nby tDCS.\nDISCUSSION\nThe present study was designed to investigate the age-related\nchanges in the extent of neural plasticity of the corticospinal pro-\njections from primary M1 in response to anodal tDCS. For young\nFIGURE 3 | Mean (black square with error bars denoting SD) and individual AURC ratios (pooled AURC across post-time points divided by baseline\npre stimulation) in the anodal tDCS condition for young and older adults. A ratio larger than 1 indicates AUC increase following anodal tDCS.\nFrontiers in Aging Neuroscience\nwww.frontiersin.org\nJune 2014 | Volume 6 | Article 115 | 5\nFujiyama et al.\nIs aging brain plastic?\nadults the largest potentiation in excitability was observed imme-\ndiately following a 30 min application of anodal tDCS. Although\nAURC values were not signi\ufb01cantly different between the post-\nstimulation time points, only up to 10 min post-anodal tDCS\nshowed signi\ufb01cantly higher corticospinal excitability than sham\ncondition. Although this result is inconsistent with a recent \ufb01nd-\ning (Monte-Silva et al., 2013), in which a reduction in corticospinal\nexcitability relative to baseline was observed following a 26 min\nperiod of anodal stimulation, consistent with the present data is\na report of increased corticospinal excitability following a 40 min\nbout of anodal tDCS (Williams et al., 2010). Although we believe\nit is extremely unlikely that the single-blinded approach utilized\nin the current study affected the results, it may be desirable to\nuse double-blinded approach in the future studies to remove the\npossibility of any confound.\nFor older adults, in contrast, post-stimulation potentiation was\ndelayed with the largest response occurring 30 min after the stim-\nulation. Indeed, potentiation immediately after stimulation and\n10 min thereafter was signi\ufb01cantly different to neither sham nor\nbaseline. Importantly, neither BDNF nor sex appeared to in\ufb02uence\nthe neuroplastic changes induced by anodal tDCS. In light of this\n\ufb01nding, implications for the use of tDCS in older populations are\ndiscussed below.\nDELAYED INCREASE IN CORTICOSPINAL EXCITABILITY FOLLOWING\nANODAL tDCS IN OLDER ADULTS\nWe found that the magnitude of anodal tDCS-induced plasticity\nin older adults was not signi\ufb01cantly reduced (as inferred by way of\ninferential statistics) relative to young adults. Although the aver-\nage level of potentiation (averaged over the four post-tDCS time\npoints) was lower in older adults (29% relative to pre-stimulation\nlevels) than younger adults (41%), the difference was not statisti-\ncally signi\ufb01cant. What was most striking, however, was our novel,\nand potentially important, \ufb01nding that older adults exhibited a\ndelayed response to anodal tDCS relative to young adults. As seen\nin Figure 2, corticospinal excitability in older adults did not peak\nuntil 30 min after cessation of stimulation, whereas young adults\nexhibited their peak potentiation immediately following stimula-\ntion. Indeed, at 0 and 10 min after tDCS older adults\u2019corticospinal\nexcitability was not different from baseline, while young adults\nshowed signi\ufb01cant potentiation at these early time points. At 20\nand 30 min post-anodal tDCS both groups exhibited signi\ufb01cant\npotentiation relative to baseline.\nA number of previous studies have reported a decreased capac-\nity for neuroplastic changes within the motor network with\nadvancing age, both in response to motor training (Sawaki et al.,\n2003; Rogasch et al., 2009 ) and in response to NIBS techniques\nincluding PAS (Fathi et al., 2010) and repetitive TMS (rTMS;\nM\u00fcller-Dahlhaus et al., 2008; Fathi et al., 2010; Todd et al., 2010).\nWhile PAS and rTMS, including theta burst stimulation (TBS),\nprotocols are thought to elicit LTP- or LTD-like plasticity by\nchanging NMDA-dependent glutamatergic transmission (Stefan\net al., 2000; Wolters et al., 2003; Huang et al., 2005, 2007; Zie-\nmann et al., 2008), tDCS in\ufb02uences resting membrane potentials\nby affecting sodium and calcium channels or by shifting electri-\ncal gradients which in\ufb02uence the electrical balance of ions across\nthe neural membrane (Liebetanz et al., 2002). It could therefore\nbe the case that the delayed, but not diminished, tDCS-induced\nplastic changes evident in older adults is a result of the stimula-\ntion targeting different plasticity mechanisms than those targeted\nby rTMS, TBS and PAS, where age-related declines in plasticity\nhave been observed. That said, it must be noted that age-related\ndecline in plasticity is not a ubiquitous \ufb01nding, as a number of\npapers indicate preserved neural plasticity in response to motor\ntraining (Cirillo et al., 2010, 2011; Hinder et al., 2011, 2013a,b) or\nNIBS paradigms (e.g., TBS; Di Lazzaro et al., 2008). These dis-\ncrepancies between individual studies may perhaps re\ufb02ect large\ninter-individual variability in response to training programs or\nbrain stimulation interventions.\nVARIABILITY OF INDIVIDUALS\u2019 RESPONSE TO tDCS\nConsistent with recent reports using tDCS (Datta et al., 2012;\nL\u00f3pez-Alonso et al., 2014; Wiethoff et al., 2014), rTMS (Maeda\net al., 2000; Hamada et al., 2012; L\u00f3pez-Alonso et al., 2014), and\nPAS (M\u00fcller-Dahlhaus et al., 2008; L\u00f3pez-Alonso et al., 2014), we\nobserved that a number (8 out of 39, or approximately 20% of par-\nticipants) of participants did not show the expected corticospinal\nexcitablity increase following anodal tDCS. The aftereffects of\nrTMS protocols including TBS have also been reported to be\nhighly variable between individuals, irrespective of age (Hamada\net al., 2012). As a consequence, some recent studies have separated\nparticipants into responders and non-responders (e.g., M\u00fcller-\nDahlhaus et al., 2008; Hamada et al., 2012). It should be noted that\nall those participants in the current study who exhibited reduc-\ntions in excitability following anodal tDCS lie within 2 SDs of\nthe mean response for their age group. As such, given a spread\nof responses within a normal distribution, it might be that these\nparticipants did not necessarily display atypical responses. That is,\nthere was not a bimodal distribution in the present data re\ufb02ecting\nthose individuals who responded to tDCS in the expected manner,\nand those who showed the opposite effect. We suggest, therefore,\nthat rather than indicating a clear pattern of \u201cresponders\u201d and\n\u201cnon-responders,\u201d the present data indicate variability around the\nexpected response.\nRecently, it has been hypothesized that the inter-individual\nvariability in response to NIBS may be the result of different popu-\nlations of neurons being stimulated more easily in different people\nat different times (Hamada et al., 2012). Variability in the response\nto TMS may not be due to differences between individuals in the\nplasticity of cortical synapses, but instead may result from indi-\nvidual differences in the recruitment of cortical neurons (Hamada\net al., 2012). Furthermore, recent modeling analysis has shown\nthat the current \ufb02owing from anodal tDCS is highly in\ufb02uenced by\nvariations in cortical gyri/sulci, suggesting that the effects may not\nbe homogeneous throughout the stimulated area for an individual\nand depend on the anatomical characteristics in the individual M1\n(Datta et al., 2012). Therefore, the observed variability to anodal\nstimulation in the present study could, at least in part, be explained\nby individual differences in the anatomical structure of the brain.\nIn addition, we cannot rule out a possibility that other factors\nplayed roles in the inter-individual variability in the response to\nanodal stimulation. Since, for example, emotional states (Baum-\ngartner et al., 2007; Coombes et al., 2009) and motor activities\n(Koeneke et al., 2006) modulate corticospinal excitability, it may\nFrontiers in Aging Neuroscience\nwww.frontiersin.org\nJune 2014 | Volume 6 | Article 115 | 6\nFujiyama et al.\nIs aging brain plastic?\nbe useful to apply a questionnaire to investigate emotional state\nand activities prior to the assessment.\nWe also examined whether BDNF gene polymorphism affects\nthe ef\ufb01cacy of anodal tDCS to induce plasticity. In the human\nbrain, BDNF is thought to modulate NMDA receptor-dependent\nLTP and LTD (Antal et al., 2010). Neuronal activity in response\nto experience and environmental demand appears to enhance\nthe local synthesis/secretion of neurotrophins, which in turn\nregulates synaptic ef\ufb01cacy or growth (Rossini et al., 2007). In\ncontrast to Antal et al. (2010), we did not \ufb01nd that individu-\nals carrying the Val66Met polymorphism had enhanced anodal\ntDCS-induced plasticity compared to Val66Val carriers. Rather,\nour results are consistent with two previous studies showing no\ndifference between BDNF genotypes with regard to corticospinal\nexcitability changes following cathodal tDCS over M1 (Cheeran\net al., 2008; Di Lazzaro et al., 2012). In the present study, the only\ngroup difference observed was in rMT, with Met carriers showing\nsigni\ufb01cantly higher rMT than theVal66Val group. Similarly, we did\nnot \ufb01nd any sex difference in response to anodal tDCS. Although\nthe present sample was larger than previous studies examining the\nrelationshipbetweenNIBSinducedplasticityandBDNFgenotype,\nstudies using much larger sample sizes with a balanced number of\nparticipants across the polymorphism are clearly required before\na de\ufb01nite conclusion can be drawn regarding the impact of BDNF\non neuroplasticity mechanisms.\nPOSSIBLE MECHANISMS UNDERLYING DELAYED RESPONSE TO tDCS\nAND IMPLICATIONS\nAlthough the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying the\ndelayed response to anodal stimulation in older adults are\nunknown, one possibility is that deterioration at the microstruc-\ntural level in the aging brain may contribute to the delayed\nresponse. During aging there is progressive accumulation of dam-\naged molecules and impaired energy metabolism in brain cells (Yu\net al., 2002). The aging process compromises neuroprotective and\nneurorestorative mechanisms involving glial cells (Yu et al., 2002).\nRecently, it has been speculated that tDCS may affect glial cells\nrather than neurons directly (Ruohonen and Karhu, 2012). There-\nfore, the degradation process with advancing age in glial cells may\nbe associated with the delayed response to anodal stimulation in\nolder adults. The next important question is whether the observed\nresponse to anodal tDCS in older adults is as long lasting as the\nincreased corticospinal excitability relative to baseline in young\nadults which persisted for up to 30 min after the stimulation.\nRecent studies investigating the effect of tDCS on motor learn-\ning have utilized a \u201cgating\u201d strategy in which the excitability of\nM1 is transiently increased via DC stimulation concurrent with\nmotor task performance(Ziemann and Siebner, 2008). In gating\nstudies, tDCS is often applied at the initial stage of the learning\n(e.g.,Waters-Metenier et al.,2014). Given that older adults showed\ndelayed potentiation in corticospinal excitability, it may be worth\nconsidering the application of stimulation prior to motor training\nin older adults to elicit greatest changes in behavior during motor\nperformance.\nIn summary, young adults exhibited the largest potentiation in\ncorticospinal excitability immediately after the anodal tDCS,while\nthe potentiation in corticospinal excitability was delayed in older\nadults. Notably, we failed to observe differences in neuroplastic\nchanges following atDCS by BDNF subtypes and sex, suggesting\nneuroplastic response following atDCS is possibly independent\nfrom these factors. Future work is warranted to investigate the\nassociation between neuroplasticity induced by NIBS techniques\nand skill acquisition in older adults. Further understanding of\nthe neurophysiological mechanisms underlying neuroplasticity in\nolder adults has signi\ufb01cant clinical implications for the improving\nof motor function in aging populations and recovery following\nstroke.\nACKNOWLEDGMENTS\nThis research was supported under Australian Research Coun-\ncil (ARC)\u2019s Discovery Projects funding scheme (DP0770568).\nMark Hinder is supported by an ARC DECRA fellowship\n(DE120100729).
