Amato2, Jacinta C. Beehner3,4, Thore J. Bergman3,5, Arianne Mercer6,\nRachel F. Perlman7, Lauren Petrullo7, Laurie Reitsema8, Sierra Sams6, Amy Lu1*\u2020 and Noah Snyder-Mackler6,9,10,11*\u2020\nAbstract\nBackground: Adaptive shifts in gut microbiome composition are one route by which animals adapt to seasonal\nchanges in food availability and diet. However, outside of dietary shifts, other potential environmental drivers of gut\nmicrobial composition have rarely been investigated, particularly in organisms living in their natural environments.\nResults: Here, we generated the largest wild nonhuman primate gut microbiome dataset to date to identify the\nenvironmental drivers of gut microbial diversity and function in 758 samples collected from wild Ethiopian geladas\n(Theropithecus gelada). Because geladas live in a cold, high-altitude environment and have a low-quality grass-based\ndiet, they face extreme thermoregulatory and energetic constraints. We tested how proxies of food availability\n(rainfall) and thermoregulatory stress (temperature) predicted gut microbiome composition of geladas. The gelada\ngut microbiome composition covaried with rainfall and temperature in a pattern that suggests distinct responses to\ndietary and thermoregulatory challenges. Microbial changes were driven by differences in the main components of\nthe diet across seasons: in rainier periods, the gut was dominated by cellulolytic/fermentative bacteria that\nspecialized in digesting grass, while during dry periods the gut was dominated by bacteria that break down\nstarches found in underground plant parts. Temperature had a comparatively smaller, but detectable, effect on the\ngut microbiome. During cold and dry periods, bacterial genes involved in energy, amino acid, and lipid metabolism\nincreased, suggesting a stimulation of fermentation activity in the gut when thermoregulatory and nutritional stress\nco-occurred, and potentially helping geladas to maintain energy balance during challenging periods.\nConclusion: Together, these results shed light on the extent to which gut microbiota plasticity provides dietary\nand metabolic flexibility to the host, and might be a key factor to thriving in changing environments. On a longer\nevolutionary timescale, such metabolic flexibility provided by the gut microbiome may have also allowed members\nof Theropithecus to adopt a specialized diet, and colonize new high-altitude grassland habitats in East Africa.\nKeywords: Gut microbiome, Graminivory, Seasonality, Thermoregulation, Theropithecus gelada, Primates\n\u00a9 The Author(s). 2021 Open Access This article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License,\nwhich permits use, sharing, adaptation, distribution and reproduction in any medium or format, as long as you give\nappropriate credit to the original author(s) and the source, provide a link to the Creative Commons licence, and indicate if\nchanges were made. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nhttps://doi.org/10.1186/s40168-020-00977-9\nBackground\nObtaining sufficient nutrients is a fundamental challenge\nfor most animals. Yet, the availability and nutritional\ncontent of food can vary temporally and spatially in re-\nsponse to changes in climate and geography. Nutritional\ndemands further vary in response to thermoregulatory\nneeds and life history processes, such as growth and\nreproduction [1, 2]. Animals have evolved a variety of\nbehavioral and physiological strategies to cope with\nthese shifting demands, including altered feeding and ac-\ntivity patterns and increased mobilization of stored fat to\nfuel energetic demands [3\u20136]. Recently, the gut micro-\nbiome has been proposed as an additional avenue by\nwhich animals can cope with changing dietary land-\nscapes and energetic challenges [7\u20139]. The gastrointes-\ntinal\ntract\nof\nanimals\nharbors\na\ndense\nmicrobial\ncommunity that helps to break down and ferment plant\nstructural carbohydrates, producing short-chain fatty\nacids (SCFAs) that can be used as an energy source by\nhosts [10\u201312]. The absorption of SCFAs in the gut may\nbe particularly important for herbivorous species, such\nas foregut and hindgut fermenters, which obtain as\nmuch as 40-90% of their energy requirements from bac-\nterial degradation of complex plant polysaccharides [13\u2013\n16]. Additionally, variation in gut microbiome compos-\nition affects the efficiency of caloric harvest and the\nmetabolic programming of the host [11, 17\u201320]. For in-\nstance, in mice (Mus musculus) and humans, obese and\nlean individuals have strikingly different gut microbiota\ncomposition, with obese phenotypes being associated\nwith higher energy extraction from diet and increased\nlipogenesis [21\u201323].\nIn wild mammals, the gut microbiome responds rapidly\nto seasonal and dietary changes [7, 24\u201329], presumably to\nbuffer seasonal energetic challenges [7, 26]. For example, a\nsimultaneous increase in bacterial taxa involved in fiber\nfermentation and in SCFA concentrations during the dry\nseason\nmay\nallow\nMexican\nblack\nhowler\nmonkeys\n(Alouatta pigra) to maintain energy balance during ener-\ngetic shortfalls without changes in activity or ranging pat-\nterns [7]. Moreover, gut bacteria increase intestinal\nabsorptive capacity, energy homeostasis, and fat burning\nduring cold periods in mice [30], and improve digestive ef-\nficiency and SCFA production in energetically challenged\nruminants living in cold environments and at high-\naltitude [31, 32]. These microbial shifts likely come at\nsome cost. For instance, increases in microbes that im-\nprove host metabolism under certain conditions may re-\nduce the abundance of microbes that support host\nimmune function [33, 34]. However, in seasonal and nutri-\ntionally challenging environments, enduring these trade-\noffs may be necessary for host survival and reproduction.\nGeladas (Theropithecus gelada) represent an excellent\nsystem to\ninvestigate\nthe\nrelationship between gut\nmicrobiota composition and seasonal variation in host\ndiet and energy needs. Despite being the only graminiv-\norous primate with up to 90% of their diet comprised of\ngrass [35, 36], their gastrointestinal tract appears poorly\nadapted to this specialization (but see [37, 38] for dental,\nmanual, and locomotor adaptations), closely resembling\ntheir\nclosest\nphylogenetic\nrelatives,\nbaboons\n(Papio\nspp.)\u2014a taxon that is omnivorous [39]. To compensate,\ngeladas may rely heavily on their gut microbiota to\nmaximize\nnutrient\nextraction\nfrom\ngrasses,\nlikely\nthrough hindgut fermentation [39, 40]. Moreover, gela-\ndas live in a high-altitude, energetically demanding en-\nvironment that exhibits marked inter- and intra-annual\nfluctuation in rainfall and temperature [35, 41]. During\nrainier months, when grass is abundant, they forage al-\nmost exclusively on aboveground graminoid leaves and\nseeds, and during drier months, when grass availability\ndecreases, they shift heavily to underground foods (rhi-\nzomes, roots, corms, bulbs) [35, 42]. This diet provides\ndistinct challenges. Underground foods are considered a\nfallback food for geladas since they take additional time\nand effort to harvest, are harder to process, and are re-\nlied upon only when grasses are less abundant [35, 38].\nDespite being considered a fallback food, these under-\nground foods are rich in starches and carbohydrates,\nsuggesting that they contain more nutritional energy\nthan grass [43]. This high amount of energy, however,\ncomes at some cost: roots and rhizomes are generally\nhigher in fibers and lignin\u2014and thus harder to digest\nthan grasses. In addition to these nutritional challenges,\nambient temperatures frequently drop to near freezing,\nand the metabolic costs of thermoregulation are known\nto strongly influence gelada physiology [44] and the tim-\ning of reproduction [41, 45]. Thus, seasonal dietary shifts\nand temperature variation may lead to distinct digestive\nand thermoregulatory challenges.\nOne previous study on geladas from Guassa, Ethiopia,\nfound that gut microbial communities of adult females\nshifted across seasons [40], supporting the hypothesis\nthat the gut microbiome may help hosts confront envir-\nonmental challenges. This study focused on adult fe-\nmales and assessed seasonal variation by separating the\nsamples into two categorical seasons (i.e., rainy, dry).\nOur study expands on this study by including adult\nmales, incorporating continuous climatic data across\nseveral years, and examining proxies of thermoregulatory\nstress (in addition to diet) as factors that can influence\nthe composition and function of the gelada gut micro-\nbiome. Indeed, rainfall and temperature vary independ-\nently of each other and represent distinct ecological\nchallenges in gelada ecosystems. Therefore, we were\ninterested in further testing which aspect of gelada\necology more strongly determines seasonal microbiome\nshifts.\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 2 of 20\nWe analyzed the gut microbiome composition and\npredicted microbiome function in 758 fecal samples\nacross 5 years from 48 adult male and 86 adult female\ngeladas living in the Ethiopian highlands in the Simien\nMountains\nNational\nPark.\nThe\nSimien\nMountains\nGelada Research Project (SMGRP) has been collecting\ndetailed climatologic, demographic, and behavioral data\nfrom this study population since 2006, allowing us to\nexamine how ecological (rainfall and temperature) and\nindividual (group membership, sex, reproductive status,\nand age) factors influence gelada gut microbiome com-\nposition. We hypothesized that ecological factors would\nbe more strongly associated with variation in the gelada\nmicrobiome than individual factors, and that rainfall and\ntemperature would have independent effects. In particu-\nlar, we expected that rainfall, which is a good proxy for\ngrass availability [35], would have the strongest effect on\nthe gelada gut microbiome. We predicted that the taxo-\nnomic changes associated with rainfall would mainly re-\nflect a shift to grass-based versus underground food-\nbased diet, in order to allow individuals to maximize en-\nergy extraction from those seasonal foods. We found\nthat the gelada microbiome exhibited drastic shifts re-\nlated to climatological variables; but individual variables,\nlike age and sex, had minimal effects. Rainfall and\ntemperature exerted independent effects on the micro-\nbial composition and predicted function\u2014with rainfall\nhaving a stronger effect on the gelada gut microbiome.\nHigh rainfall, which is correlated with grass availability\n[35], was associated with more cellulolytic and fibrolytic\nbacterial taxa, when graminoid leaves were the main\nfood source. Dry periods, when geladas consume more\nunderground foods [35], were associated with more am-\nylolytic and methanogenic taxa. Cold periods were fur-\nther characterized by more amylolytic taxa, and hot\nperiods by more methanogenic taxa. In both drier and\ncolder periods, the gut microbiome shifted to predicted\nfunctions that suggested increased digestive efficiency,\nincluding energy, amino acid, and lipid metabolism.\nOverall, gelada gut microbial composition covaried with\ndiet and temperature in a pattern that suggests plastic but\ndistinct responses to dietary and metabolic challenges.\nResults\nThe gelada gut microbiome\nWe identified 3295 amplicon sequence variants (ASVs)\nin 758 fecal samples (mean \u00b1 SD = 813 \u00b1 243 ASVs per\nsample, range = 92-1730) using deep 16S rRNA gene\namplicon sequencing. Most ASVs could be taxonomic-\nally assigned to the phylum (100%), class (99%), and\norder level (99%), but assignments decreased substan-\ntially at the family (85%) and genus (61%) levels. These\n3295 ASVs came from 16 different phyla, 65 families,\nand 200 genera (Table S1, Fig. 1, Figures S1-S2). Of the\nFig. 1 Taxonomic composition of the gelada gut at the phylum and family levels. Relative abundance (a) of all bacterial phyla and (b) of the 24\nmost abundant families (relative abundance> 0.02%) in the gelada feces. The median and median absolute deviation (error limit) are represented\nin orange.\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 3 of 20\n3295 ASVs, 170 (5%) were present in at least 90% of\nsamples and form what can be considered the \u201ccore\nmicrobiota\u201d of geladas (Table S2). The four most abun-\ndant bacterial phyla were Firmicutes (32%), Kiritimatiel-\nlaeota (formerly called Verrucomicrobiota subdivision 5;\n26%), Bacteroidetes (23%), and Spirochaetes (5%) (Table\nS1, Fig. 1a). All microbes assigned to Kiritimatiellaeota\nwere part of the RFP12 family and represent almost one\nquarter of the gelada gut microbiome (mean 26%, range\n0.02-70%, Fig. 1b). Despite the abundance of RFP12, the\n78 ASVs belonging to this group could not be assigned\nbelow the family level. We therefore queried these se-\nquences against the NCBI database using BLAST [46, 47].\nThese RFP12 sequences were most similar (~ 97%) to bac-\nterial sequences previously found in the feces of hindgut\nherbivorous species (Asiatic elephant, domesticated horse,\nSomali wild ass, zebra, and black rhinoceros) [48] and, to\na lesser extent, the rumen of several foregut fermenters\n(cattle, yak, red kangaroo; Table S3). Taken together, this\nindicates that the RFP12 family is a key microbe for herb-\nivorous species, particularly hindgut fermenters, and likely\nplays an important fermentative role in plant digestion in\ngeladas. Other taxa found at high frequency in the guts of\nruminants and herbivorous hindgut fermenters were also\nprevalent in the gelada gut, including many cellulolytic/\nfibrolytic (13% Ruminococcaceae, 6% Lachnospiraceae, 4%\nClostridiales vadinBB60 group, 1.5% Fibrobacteraceae)\nand fermentative families (5.3% Rikenellaceae, 5% Prevo-\ntellaceae, 4.1% Bacteroidales F082) (Table S1, Fig. 1b and\nS1). The Spirochaetes phylum was mostly composed of\nTreponema (3.5%), a genus involved in lignocellulose deg-\nradation [49].\nDietary changes\nTo examine how seasonal variation in rainfall and\ntemperature was associated with changes in the gelada gut\nmicrobiome, we used measures of true climatic condi-\ntions, including monthly cumulative rainfall (an appropri-\nate proxy of grass availability in the Simiens: [35]) and\naverage monthly minimum temperature (a proxy of\nthermoregulatory constraint: [41, 44]). At the level of\nwithin-sample community diversity (\u201calpha diversity\u201d), we\nfound that cumulative rainfall was positively associated\nwith Shannon evenness (Table 1, Fig. 2a, c) but had no ef-\nfect on bacterial richness or Faith\u2019s phylogenetic diversity\n(Table S4, Figure S3). Thus, rainfall was associated with\nthe relative abundance of ASVs within a sample but not\nthe absolute number of ASVs or their phylogenetic\ndiversity.\nCumulative rainfall significantly explained 3.3% of the\noverall compositional dissimilarity\u2014or beta diversity\u2014\nbetween samples (as measured by Aitchison distance)\n(Table 2), which was less than that explained by two\ndemographic variables: individual identity and unit (so-\ncial group) membership (20% and 6%, respectively; Table\n2). The first principal component of beta diversity, which\nexplained 15% of variation, was strongly associated with\nrainfall (r = 0.43, t = 12.93, df = 756, p < 0.001, Fig. 2b).\nThe ASVs that loaded positively on PC1 (i.e., correlated\nwith higher rainfall, Fig. 2d) were primarily from the\nfamilies Prevotellaceae, Ruminococcaceae, and Lachnos-\npiraceae (Table S5 and S6). By contrast, the ASVs that\nloaded negatively on PC1 (i.e., more abundant in low\nrainfall, Fig. 2d) belonged to the family RFP12 and a dif-\nferent subset of Ruminococcaceae that were not abun-\ndant during the wet season (Table S5 and S6).\nCumulative rainfall predicted the relative abundance\nof gut microbes at all taxonomic levels and was signifi-\ncantly associated with the relative abundance of 63% of\nbacterial families tested (59-81% of taxa at other taxo-\nnomic levels, Fig. 3, Benjamini-Hochberg corrected p\nvalues: pBH < 0.05). Thus, across most taxa, there was a\nclear contrast in the relative abundance of gut bacteria\nbetween the wet and dry periods (Table S7, Fig. 4). In\nwetter periods, there was an increase in several import-\nant fermentative families from the Bacteroides order (in-\ncluding Prevotellaceae and Bacteroidaceae), as well as in\nseveral\ncellulolytic/fibrolytic\ntaxa\n(Lachnospiraceae,\nFibrobacteraceae, Spirochaetaceae, and several genera\nfrom the Ruminococcaceae; Figs. 4 and 5a), suggesting\nimproved digestive efficiency of plant cell wall polysac-\ncharides at a time when the gelada diet consists mainly\nof grasses. In particular, nine Prevotella genera as well as\nthe Bacteroides genus were at higher abundance during\nwetter periods than drier periods (Table S7, Fig. 4b).\nThere\nwas\nalso\nan\nincrease\nin\nseveral\nproficient\nTable 1 Determinants of alpha diversity, as measured by the Shannon index\nFixed factor\nEstimate\nSE\n95% confidence interval\nLRT\np value\nSex (male)\n\u22120.12\n0.04\n[\u22120.20; \u22120.05]\n9.27\n0.002\nAge\n0.01\n0.02\n[\u22120.02; 0.04]\n0.49\n0.484\nCumulative rainfall\n0.05\n0.02\n[0.02; 0.08]\n12.13\n< 0.001\nMinimum temperature\n0.00\n0.01\n[\u22120.03; 0.03]\n0.04\n0.848\nSequencing depth\n0.07\n0.01\n[0.04; 0.10]\n24.24\n< 0.001\nParameters and tests are based on linear mixed models of 758 samples and 131 individuals, controlling for individual identity and unit membership. By contrast, the dry season was char-\nacterized by an increase in amylolytic genera (Succinivi-\nbrio;\nStreptococcus\nand\nPirellulaceae\np-1088-a5\ngut\ngroup), in several efficient sugar-fermenting families\n(Victivallales vadinBE97, Christensenellaceae), and in\nthe\nmethane-producer\nMethanobrevibacter,\na\ngenus\nknown to increase the rate of fermentation and digestive\nefficiency (Table S7, and Figs. 4 and 5b). Consistent with\nour beta diversity analyses, we also found an increase in\nthe relative abundance of the RFP12 family during the\ndry season (Table S7, Fig. 5b).\nThe taxonomic changes associated with rainfall also\ncorresponded to changes in the predicted function of\nthe gelada gut microbiome (as assessed by PICRUSt2:\n[50]). During wetter periods, functional changes tended\nto reflect the activity of the cellulolytic and fermentative\nbacterial taxa. Microbial pathways involved in the trans-\nport of molecules through bacterial membranes (e.g.,\nions, sugars, lipids, peptides), DNA replication and re-\npair, and cell motility (Tables S8-S9, Figs. 6, S4 and\nS5A) increased. We also found an increase in the metab-\nolism of sugars (e.g., starch and sucrose metabolism,\nfructose, mannose, and galactose) (Figure S4 and S5A).\nSuch activity probably reflects the exportation of sugar-\ncleaving enzymes and cellulosome complex across the\nouter membrane [12, 51] of fibrolytic bacteria (complex\npolysaccharides are too big to penetrate directly inside\nbacteria and have to be cleaved first) and the absorption\nof the soluble oligosaccharides back across the bacterial\nmembrane [12, 51].\nDuring drier periods, the gelada gut harbored a greater\nabundance of bacterial genes involved in energy, amino\nacid, and lipid metabolism (Tables S8-S9 and Fig. 6a, c).\nIn particular, cellular energy production and cellular\nFig. 2 Rainfall structures the gelada gut microbiome. a Partial residual plot of Shannon alpha diversity index according to cumulative rainfall (in mm). Other energy metabol-\nism pathways also increased during drier periods, includ-\ning the methane pathway and the carbon fixation\npathways, which are important for generating energy in\nanaerobic bacteria (Figure S4 and S5B). Finally, drier\nperiods were associated with an increase in functions re-\nlated to the synthesis of proteinogenic amino acids (e.g.,\ntryptophan), the translation and synthesis of proteins\n(Figure S4), and the synthesis of lipopolysaccharide.\nNote, however, that the average weighted Nearest\nSequence Taxon Index (NSTI) value across all samples\n(a measure of how similar bacteria from a sample are to\nreference genome sequences) was relatively high in our\nsample (mean \u00b1 SD = 0.60 \u00b1 0.13) compared to other\nmammals [50]. Our results should therefore be inter-\npreted with caution, in that they provide a general idea\nof the predicted gene family profiles based on bacteria\nthat were functional characterized in previous studies.\nTemperature\nCompared to rainfall, minimum temperature had a\nmuch smaller impact on the gut microbiome. Average\nminimum temperature did not influence any metric of\nalpha diversity (Table 1 and S4, Figure S6A), and ex-\nplained only 0.33% of the variation in beta diversity\n(Table 2, Figure S6B). Changes in temperature were sig-\nnificantly associated with the relative abundance of 5%\nof the families (5-22% at other taxonomic levels; Fig. 3;\npBH < 0.05). More specifically, colder temperatures were\ncharacterized by a greater abundance of two amylolytic\ngenera\n(Lactobacillus\nand\nStreptococcus);\nin\nseveral\nTable 2 Determinants of beta diversity. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 6 of 20\nsugar-fermenting (Hydrogenoanaerobacterium, Clostrid-\nium sensu stricto 1, Coprococcus 1) and cellulose-\ndegrading bacteria (Marvinbryantia and two genera\nfrom the Ruminococcaceae family) (Table S7, Figure S7).\nBy contrast, hotter temperatures were associated with an\nincrease in Verrucomicrobia, in the methane-producer\nMethanobrevibacter, and in several cellulolytic/fibrolytic\ngenera from the Ruminococcaceae and Lachnospiraceae\nfamilies (Table S7, Figure S7).\nSimilar to our taxonomic analysis, we found that\ntemperature had a much smaller effect on the predicted\nfunction of the gelada gut microbiome (Tables S8-S9,\nFigure S8). During colder periods, we found a predicted\nincrease in bacterial pathways involved in lipid metabol-\nism and energy production (notably in oxidative phos-\nphorylation pathway; Figure S8). Other pathways that\nincreased during colder periods involved DNA repair and\nrecombination and the bacterial secretion system. During\nhotter weather, pathways were more poorly characterized\nand less specific, with predicted increases in methane me-\ntabolism and ABC transport (a membrane transporter).\nSex, reproductive state, and age\nThe gut microbiome of females exhibited higher alpha\ndiversity compared to males, regardless of the metric\n(richness, evenness, and Shannon index) (Table 1 and\nS4, Figure S9A). Across samples, however, sex explained\nlittle between-sample variation (i.e., < 1%) (Table 2, Fig-\nure S9B). We detected only a handful of bacterial taxa\nthat were differentially abundant according to sex (Table\nS7, Fig. 3). At the phylum level, females harbored more\nVerrucomicrobia and Proteobacteria (particularly from\nclass Gammaproteobacteria, Deltaproteobacteria, and\nAlphaproteobacteria). At the family and genus levels, fe-\nmales had more taxa involved in lactic acid metabolism\n(Lactobacillaceae, Anaerovibrio), cellulolysis (Saccharo-\nfermentans), and regulation of glucose and fat transport\n(Erysipelatoclostridium). Males, on the other hand, only\nharbored more Pirellulales. No predicted metabolic\npathway differed in abundance between males and\nfemales (Tables S8-S9).\nFemale reproductive state did not influence any alpha\ndiversity metric (Table S10, Figure S10A) and was not a\nsignificant factor influencing beta diversity between sam-\nples (Table S11, Figure S10B). Very few taxa were differ-\nentially abundant according to female reproductive state\n(Table S12 and S13). Pregnant females harbored more\nVerrucomicrobiota (class Verrucomicrobiae) and Epsilon-\nbacteraeota than cycling and lactating females (Table\nS13). In particular, the genus Helicobacter (within the\nfamily Epsiolonbacteroaeto)\u2014a presumed pathogen\u2014was\nhighly prevalent in pregnant females (Table S13). No\nFig. 4 Rainfall predicts the relative abundance of many bacterial taxa. a Families and b Genera that are found differentially abundant according\nto cumulative rainfall. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 8 of 20\npredicted metabolic pathways were found to differ based\non reproductive state (Table S14-S15). Age did not influ-\nence any metric of alpha diversity (Table 1 and S4, Fig-\nure S11A) or beta diversity (Table 2, Figure S11B), and\nno bacterial taxa (Table S7) or predicted metabolic path-\nways (Table S8-S9) were differentially abundant between\nyoung and old adults.\nDiscussion\nOur findings are consistent with the hypothesis that\nchanges in the gelada gut microbiome may help animals\ncope with seasonal changes in food availability and\nthermoregulatory demands. First, the gelada gut micro-\nbiome was highly plastic and responded rapidly to sea-\nsonal fluctuations in climate\u2014particularly rainfall (a\nproxy for available foods). Second, an increase in pre-\ndicted bacterial functions involved in energy, amino acid,\nand lipid metabolism during both drier and colder pe-\nriods suggested increased production of SCFAs, and\nmore\nefficient\ndigestion\nduring\nenergetically\nand\nthermoregulatory challenging periods. We further found\nthat individual identity and social group explained nearly\na third of the variation of the gelada microbiome, while\nother individual traits such as sex, reproductive state,\nand age had little effect on gut microbiome composition\nand function.\nRainfall was the strongest ecological factor influencing\nchanges in the gelada gut microbiome, explaining ~ 3.3%\nof overall microbiome composition. In particular, cellu-\nlolytic/fibrolytic\nand\nfermentative\nbacterial\ntaxa\nin-\ncreased during wetter periods when grass, which is\nmostly composed of cellulose, was the primary food\nsource, while amylolytic and methanogenic bacterial taxa\nincreased during drier periods, when geladas incorpo-\nrated more starch (i.e., amylose) and lignified food into\ntheir diet. This effect of rainfall on the gut microbiome\nwas strong, despite the fact that geladas exhibit only\nmoderate dietary changes across season (i.e., from only\ngrass to less grass and more underground organs\u2014but\nfrom the same plant species) compared to other mam-\nmals living in more seasonal environments, e.g., that\nswitch from ripe fruits to more folivorous diets [7, 52,\n53]. This pattern highlights the importance of the gut\nmicrobiome for geladas in processing their unique diet\nacross seasons.\nThe efficiency of grass digestion in wet periods seems\nto rely on a syntropy between the first cellulolytic de-\ngraders (Ruminococcaceae, Lachnospiraceae, Fibrobac-\nteraceae, Spirochaetes) and a high diversity of secondary\nfermenters (Prevotellaceae and Bacteroidales), which all\nincrease in abundance during the wet season. The first\ndegraders attach to the plant cell walls and hydrolyze\ncellulose, hemicellulose, and xylan into smaller polysac-\ncharides and oligosaccharides [12, 51], while secondary\nfermenters ferment those soluble polysaccharides into\nmore simple sugars [10, 54]. Ruminococcaceae and Lach-\nnospiraceae are the two main cellulolytic taxa in the\nmammalian gut and commonly increase in prevalence\nwhen animals eat more leaves and plants [7, 29]. In\nterms of secondary fermenters, Prevotella are widely\nknown for their role in breaking down non-cellulosic\npolysaccharides and pectin [10, 12]. They are the major\nconstituent (~ 70%) of rumen bacteria [55], and com-\nmonly increase in high fiber or fruit diets [29, 53, 56,\n57]. Members of Bacteroidales\u2014and particularly from\nthe Bacteroides genus\u2014have some of the largest reper-\ntoires of carbohydrate degrading activities and are able\nto ferment a broad range of plant polysaccharides [10,\n58\u201360]. The increase in these cellulolytic/fibrolytic taxa\nand the high versatility of the secondary fermenters\nlikely allow geladas to optimally extract nutrients from\ngrasses eaten during wet periods.\nIn contrast, during drier periods, when geladas relied\nmore on underground storage organs, we found a corre-\nsponding increase in microbial families involved in amy-\nlolytic and saccharolytic activities (Succinivibrionaceae,\nStreptococcaceae, Christensenellaceae). Interestingly, Suc-\ncinivibrionaceae also increased during periods of ener-\ngetic stress in Tibetan macaques (Macaca thibetana)\n[26] and during the dry season in the Hazda hunter\ngatherers of Tanzania [61], suggesting that it might help\nhosts cope with diet-related energy shortfalls. The gelada\nmicrobiome during the dry season was also character-\nized by an increase in Methanobrevibacter, a genus\ncontaining\nhydrogenotrophic\narchaea\nthat\nconverts\nhydrogen and formate into methane [62]. The simultan-\neous enrichment of efficient hydrogen-producers (e.g.,\nChristensenellaceae\n[63],\nHydrogenoanaerobacterium:\n[64]) and formate-producers (Succinivibrionaceae: [65]),\ncombined with methanogens during the dry season sug-\ngest that these taxa work together in syntropy to im-\nprove the efficiency of polysaccharide fermentation from\nstarch in the gut in dry periods [66, 67]. In mice and\nhumans, a higher abundance of methanogenic archaea\nincreases calorie harvest from diet, facilitates SCFA pro-\nduction by other fermentative bacteria, and stimulates\nlipogenesis [66\u201369].\nFinally, drier periods were also characterized by a large\nincrease in the RFP12 family (i.e., ~ 30% versus ~ 18% in\nwetter periods) from the Kiritimatiellaeota phylum. The\nRFP12 family remains poorly characterized but is in-\ncreasingly recognized as being a keystone bacterial group\nin the hindgut of horses (Equus ferus caballus) [70\u201372],\nand a common inhabitant of the rumen of sheep (Ovis\naries) or cattle [73\u201375]. The bacterial sequences belong-\ning to the RFP12 family found in the gelada feces were,\non average, 97% similar to bacterial sequences found in\nthe feces of various hindgut herbivorous fermenters [48]\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 9 of 20\nand, to a lesser extent, in the rumen of foregut fermen-\nters (Table S3). This suggests that the RFP12 family\nplays a particularly important, but thus far uncharacter-\nized, digestive role for herbivorous species. In the case of\ngeladas, it further suggests that it might be a keystone\nbacterial group for the digestion of some underground\nfood components commonly eaten by the geladas during\ndry periods.\nOverall, the gut microbes present in geladas are poorly\nrepresented by reference bacterial genomes in the two\nmost common microbial databases: SILVA (updated\n2017) [76] and Greengenes 13_8 (updated 2013) [77].\nTaxonomic assignment of bacteria beyond the family\nlevel is relatively low (only 65% of our reads were\nassigned to genus level) compared to assignment of se-\nquences found in captive animals and humans. This\npoor taxonomic characterization limits our ability to\nunderstand the metabolic activities of gut microbiome\ncommunities, and highlights the need to generate more\nmolecular microbial data from a wider range of non-\nmodel\nand\nwild\norganisms.\nThe\nKiritimatiellaeota\nphylum (and in particular the RFP12 family) would be a\ngood candidate to focus on.\nAt the functional level, bacterial genes involved in en-\nergy, amino acid, and lipid metabolism increased in\nprevalence during the dry season. In particular, meta-\nbolic pathways linked to cellular respiration, methano-\ngenesis, and carbon fixation pathways of prokaryotes\nbecame more common, strongly suggesting that both\nbacterial energy production and cellular activity were\nstimulated during this time. One interpretation of this\ndata is that the increase in cellular activity simply re-\nflects a dietary switch to starch, which is easier to\nhydrolyze than cellulose, and thus might more readily\nprovoke a stimulation of bacterial activity and carbohy-\ndrate fermentation. Alternatively, the stimulation of bac-\nterial energy metabolism and cellular activity could\nreflect a higher production of SCFAs by gut bacteria,\nsupplying the host with additional energy in periods of\nnutrient restriction (when relying on fallback foods) [31,\n78]. Similar increases in predicted bacterial energy me-\ntabolism have been found in energetically challenging\nenvironments (e.g., high altitude) in several other mam-\nmalian species and were correlated with higher SCFA\nproduction [31, 32]. Analysis of fecal SCFA profiles in\ngeladas would help to identify if this is also the case in\nthis high-altitude species. One caveat to our analysis is\nthat the accuracy of the PICRUSt2 functional predictions\nmay be lower than in other studies, especially when\ncompared to published NSTI values in other mammals\n[50]. Previous studies of mammalian gut microbiomes\nconducted PICRUSt analyses on bacterial sequences\ngrouped by OTUs, instead of ASVs. Because OTUs\ngroup sequences with 97% of similarity together, it\nremoves 3% of genetic variation; and thus by definition\nOTUs will be closer to samples from reference genomes,\npotentially leading to lower NSTI values. Thus, although\nour analyses are reflecting only a limited portion of the\nbacterial community of geladas, it is not necessarily a\nworse representation than found in previous studies\nclustering bacteria by OTUs. Overall, while our pre-\ndicted functions might give us a broad profile of the\ndifferences in metabolic activities of gut bacteria in\nthe dry and wet seasons, they are not as precise as\nfunctional\ncharacterization\nfrom\nmetagenomic\nor\nmetabolomic data.\nWhile it is clear that the gelada diet shifts during drier\nperiods, it remains unknown if (and to what extent)\ngeladas are nutritionally or energetically constrained\nduring this time. Grass availability declines and geladas\nspend more time foraging and digging for underground\nplant parts during the dry season [35, 42]. Such under-\nground foods are usually considered fallback foods be-\ncause individuals rely on them only when grass is less\navailable and because they require long processing times\n[35, 38]. However, one study [42] found that geladas\nobtain just as much, or even more, calories from under-\nground storage organs as they do from grass. Whether\nthis increased caloric intake is offset by increased for-\naging costs is currently unknown. However, even if in-\ncreased foraging costs were demonstrated, our data\nsuggests that the gut microbiota may increase digestive\nefficiency from starchy food and thereby help geladas\nmaintain or improve energetic status during the dry\nseason. Future studies on seasonal changes in energy\nbalance will help resolve this issue.\nIn contrast to the effect of rainfall, we found mixed\nevidence for the effect of temperature on the gut micro-\nbiome. Temperature only explained ~ 0.33% of variation\nin the gelada gut microbiome composition. Furthermore,\nfew taxa shifted in abundance between the coldest and\nhottest months, and most taxa affected by temperature\nwere also affected by rainfall. This might be explained by\nthe fact that rainfall (and thus diet) covaries with\ntemperature to some extent (Pearson\u2019s correlation coeffi-\ncient = 0.20): geladas rely the most on underground\nfoods in the hot-dry season (Feb. to May) and the most\non grass on the cold-wet season (Jun. to Sep.) [35]. The\ncold-dry season (Oct. to Jan.), however, displays a mixed\npattern of diet and temperature: grass availability is still\nhigh in Oct.-Nov. (following the rainy season) but de-\ncreases markedly in Dec.-Jan. [35, 41]. These 2 months\nare thus characterized by the introduction of under-\nground foods in the diet and are also the coldest months\nof the year, making them likely the most challenging\ntimes for geladas (compounding nutritional and thermo-\nregulatory challenges). Accordingly, cold periods were\ncharacterized by an increase in two amylolytic and\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 10 of 20\nlactate-producing\ntaxa\n(Streptococcus,\nLactobacillus),\npresumably to more efficiently extract starch from the\nunderground foods. At the functional level, the energy\nand lipid metabolism of bacteria were also stimulated in\nthe cold months, further suggesting some role of gut\nbacteria in stimulating host digestive efficiency and en-\nergy metabolism during thermoregulatory-demanding\ntimes.\nThese seasonal changes that increase energy pro-\nduction during colder periods may come at some\ncost. Such trade-offs have been proposed where shifts\nthat benefit one aspect of host physiology conse-\nquently lead to a decrease in other microbes that may\nalso be necessary for the host. For example, microbes\nthat promote host digestive efficiency and energy me-\ntabolism may also promote inflammation or even sup-\npress immune function [33, 79]. We did not detect\nany obvious evidence of these tradeoffs in geladas,\nbut future work that incorporates detailed host im-\nmunological and functional microbial data is needed\nto help determine if such trade-offs exist.\nFinally, the present study found that the gelada gut\nmicrobiome was largely explained by individual identity\n(20%), a pattern consistent with data from a range of\nvertebrates [40, 80\u201382], including humans [83, 84].\nHowever, the effect of social group was lower in geladas\nthan reported for other social mammals (geladas: 6.0%\nvs., e.g., yellow baboon, Papio cynocephalus: 18.6% of\nvariation explained [85], black howler monkey: 14% [86],\nring-tailed lemurs, Lemur catta: 21% [87], Welsh Moun-\ntain ponies: 14%: [82]). The combination of large indi-\nvidual effects with weak social group effects closely\nresembles data reported for the Guassa gelada popula-\ntion [40], suggesting a general, but consistent pattern.\nThe weak unit-level effects may result from the unique\nsocial system of geladas: Because social units often ag-\ngregate into large bands whose composition changes\nregularly, geladas may have a higher rate of inter-unit\nmicrobial transmission compared with other primates.\nFuture studies should explore in more detail the intra-\nindividual fluctuation in gut microbiome composition,\nand whether group differences in ranging patterns may\nexplain these differences.\nOther individual predictors, namely, age, sex, and female\nreproductive state, had a very limited effect on the gut\nmicrobiome, mirroring results in other mammals (yellow\nbaboons: [28, 85], ring-tailed lemurs: [87], Verreaux\u2019s si-\nfakas, Propithecus verreauxi: [29], chimpanzees, Pan trog-\nlodytes schweinfurthii: [88], rhesus monkeys, Macaca\nmulatta: [89], Welsh Mountain ponies [82], domestic dog,\nCanis lupus familiaris: [90], but see black howler mon-\nkeys: [34] or Egyptian fruit bats, Rousettus aegyptiacus:\n[80]). Although female geladas harbored higher microbial\nrichness than males, this resulted in minimal differences\nin gut microbial composition and predicted function.\nCompared to males, females had higher abundance of Pro-\nteobacteria and Lactobacillus. These two bacterial taxa\nwere previously reported to increase during pregnancy\nand lactation in humans and non-human primates [27,\n91], and act as early colonizers of the infant gut [92\u201394].\nAdditionally, pregnant female geladas harbored more\nHelicobacter, a potentially pathogenic genus [95, 96]. An\nincrease in potentially pathogenic microbes in pregnant\nfemales was also observed in black howler monkeys [34]\nand was hypothesized to be the consequence of a trade-off\nbetween reproduction and immunity. These dynamics\nwarrant further investigation.\nOverall, the gut microbiome of geladas seems to be\nhighly plastic and can respond rapidly to changes in host\ndiet and thermoregulatory demands. Stimulation of bac-\nteria cellular activity could allow geladas to maintain ad-\nequate or even improved energetic balance during dry\nand cold periods. Our study adds to an increasing body\nof literature suggesting that the gut microbiota is an im-\nportant system providing dietary and metabolic flexibil-\nity for the host and might be a key factor influencing the\nacclimatization to changing environments [8, 48, 97, 98].\nIn addition to fostering phenotypic plasticity, the gut\nmicrobiome is increasingly hypothesized to contribute to\nhost evolution and speciation [97\u201399] given the strong\nhost phylogenetic signal in mammalian microbiome\ncomposition and function [100, 101] and evidence of\nmicrobiome heritability [102\u2013104]. To the extent that\nmicrobiomes affect host phenotypes under selection,\nthey will also affect host evolutionary trajectories. In the\ncase of geladas, a shift in gut microbiome composition\nwas probably an important adaptive mechanism that\nallowed members of the Theropithecus genus to adopt a\nspecialized dietary niche and diversify rapidly from Papio\n~ 5 million years ago [105]. Contrary to host adaptive\ngenetic mutations, which occur over the course of many\ngenerations, the gut microbiota can shift in response to\nchanges in host diet in a matter of days [9]. Given that\nthe common ancestor of Theropithecus and Papio was\nomnivorous [106, 107], dietary flexibility provided by the\ngut microbiome may have been an important first step\nallowing members of Theropithecus to exploit new grass-\nland habitats in East Africa, leading to the evolution of a\nspecialized diet and, ultimately, further genetic and\nphenotypic adaptation.\nConclusion\nThe gut microbiome of geladas is plastic and responds\nrapidly to changes in host diet and thermoregulatory de-\nmands. These shifts appear to help geladas cope with\nseasonal fluctuations in nutrient intake and energy\nhomeostasis, potentially allowing them to maintain en-\nergy balance in challenging seasonal environments. Our\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 11 of 20\nstudy adds to an increasing body of literature suggesting\nthat the gut microbiota is an important system that pro-\nvides metabolic flexibility for the host, and is key to\nhelping hosts adapt and shift to fluctuating environ-\nments. Future research in geladas and other animals will\nfurther uncover how the gut microbiota allows hosts to\noccupy unique dietary niches, potentially allowing host\nlineages to expand into new habitats, and facilitating\nspeciation.\nMaterial and methods\nStudy population and fecal sample collection\nWe collected fecal samples from a wild population of\ngeladas living in the Simien Mountains National Park, in\nnorthern Ethiopia (13\u00b0 15\u2032 N, 38\u00b0 00\u2032 E). Samples were\ncollected over a 4-year period between Jan. 2015 and\nFeb. 2019. Geladas live in multi-level societies, where re-\nproductive units (comprising a leader male, several adult\nfemales, their offspring, and occasionally 1\u20132 follower\nmales) and bachelor groups (comprising between 1 and\n10 adult males) form the smallest levels of the society\nthat forage and sleep together in a \u201cband\u201d sharing the\nsame home range [108]. Since Jan. 2006, the Simien\nMountains Gelada Research Project (SMGRP) has col-\nlected demographic and behavioral data on over 200 in-\ndividuals from two bands. All individuals are habituated\nto\nhuman\nobservers\non\nfoot\nand\nare\nindividually\nrecognizable. Dates of birth of individuals were estab-\nlished using a combination of known (N = 42) and esti-\nmated (N = 89) birth dates. Estimated birth dates were\ncalculated by using the mean individual age at major\nlife-history milestones in our population (e.g., sexual\nmaturation or first birth for females and canine eruption\nfor males) [109, 110]. Birth dates of unknown immigrant\nmales were estimated using an established protocol\nbased on body size and other age-related morphological\ncharacteristics [110]. Here, we focused only on samples\nfrom\nadult\nmales\nand\nfemales.\nAdult\nmales\nwere\nincluded when they reached 7 years of age. At this age,\nmales have reached adult body size in stature but not in\nweight [110, 111], and most males have dispersed into a\nnon-natal group (i.e., 96% of our male samples, males\ncould thus be leaders, followers, bachelors, or natals).\nAdult females were included after they had experienced\ntheir first sex skin swelling, a marker of reproductive\nmaturation (which is around 4.65 years old in our\npopulation [109]).\nFecal samples of known adult and subadult male and\nfemale subjects were collected regularly and opportunis-\ntically\nduring\nthe\nstudy\nperiod.\nImmediately\nupon\ndefecation, approximately 1.5 g of feces was collected in 3\nml of RNA later [112, 113], stored at room temperature\nfor up to 2 months, and subsequently shipped to the Uni-\nversity of Washington (UW). At UW, samples were stored\nat \u221280 \u00b0C until the sequencing libraries were prepared. A\ntotal of 758 samples (620 female samples, 138 male sam-\nples) were collected from 131 individuals (83 females, 48\nmales) (mean \u00b1 SD = 5.79 \u00b1 6.14 samples per individual,\nrange = 1-21) from 28 reproductive units and 4 bachelors\ngroups (mean \u00b1 SD = 4.69 \u00b1 2.97 number of individuals\nsampled per unit, range = 1-11).\nThe reproductive state of females at the date of sample\ncollection was assigned based on daily monitoring of in-\ndividuals for the status of sex skin swellings and the\nbirth of infants. We assigned the three reproductive\nstates as follows: (1) Cycling began at the first sign of\npostpartum sex skin swelling and ended when a female\nconceived\u2014with conception defined as 183 days (mean\ngestation length) before the birth of a subsequent infant\n[109]. (2) Pregnancy started on the date of conception\nand ended the day before parturition. (3) Finally, lacta-\ntion started on the day of parturition and ended the day\nbefore the female\u2019s first postpartum swelling. Lactating\nfemales were further categorized as being in early lacta-\ntion (infant < 1 year old) or late lactation (infant > 1 year\nold). When testing the effect of reproductive state, late\nlactating females were removed from the lactating cat-\negory to include only females that were still nursing at\nthe time of sample collection (females resume cycling\nwhen infants are ~ 1.5 years old in our population, which\nis presumably accompanied by infant weaning around\nthe same time [109]). Furthermore, because pregnant fe-\nmales can abort their fetus during male takeover of their\nreproductive unit [114], some pregnancies might have\nbeen misidentified as cycling based on our method of\nback-calculating from the date of birth. We therefore re-\nmoved cycling females that experienced a takeover in\nthe previous 6 months before the date of sample collec-\ntion (N = 55 samples) to avoid any misclassification of\nreproductive state in our analyses.\nStudy site and climatic data\nThe study area is located at 3200 m above sea level and\nis characterized as an Afroalpine grassland ecosystem,\nconsisting of grassland plateaus, scrublands, and Erica-\nceous forests [115]. Fecal samples were collected across\nthe year, with roughly equal coverage across seasons\n(244 in cold-dry, 298 in cold-wet, and 216 in hot-dry\nseason as defined above). As part of the long-term moni-\ntoring of the SMGRP, daily cumulative rainfall and mini-\nmum and maximum temperature are recorded on a\nnear-daily basis. We used the total cumulative rainfall\nover the 30 days prior to the date of fecal sample collec-\ntion as a proxy for grass availability at the time of sample\ncollection [35]. In addition, we used the average mini-\nmum daily temperatures in the 30 days preceding the\ndate of sample collection as a proxy of thermoregulatory\nconstraints. The average minimum temperature is less\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 12 of 20\ncorrelated with cumulative monthly rainfall than the\naverage maximum temperature in the previous 30 days\n(correlation coefficient: 0.25 versus \u22120.56) and, more im-\nportantly, is more likely to reflect the physiological effect\nof thermoregulation on the body [41, 44].\nDNA extraction, sequencing, and data processing\nWe prepared 16S sequencing libraries using the proto-\ncols developed and optimized by the Earth Microbiome\nProject and the University of Minnesota Genomics Core\n(UMGC [116];). We extracted microbial DNA from the\nfecal samples using Qiagen\u2019s PowerLyzer PowerSoil\nDNA Isolation kit (Qiagen #12855) following the stand-\nard protocol. We amplified the hypervariable V4 region\nof the 16S rRNA gene using PCR primer set 515F\n(TCGTCGGCAGCGTCAGATGTGTATAAGAGACAG\nGTGYCAGCMGCCGCGGTAA) and 806R (GTCTCG\nTGGGCTCGGAGATGTGTATAAGAGACAGGGAC\nTACNVGGGTWTCTAA\nT) from The Human Microbiome Project and a dual-\nindexing approach [116]. Details of the amplification\nprotocol can be accessed at https://smack-lab.com/\nprotocols/. The first PCR round aimed at amplifying the\nV4 region. Each 25 \u03bcl PCR reaction well consisted of\n12.5 \u03bcl of Nebnext Ultra II Q5 mastermix, 1.0 \u03bcl of each\nprimer, and 25 ng of total DNA in 10.5 \u03bcl of nuclease-\nfree water. PCR was performed in an Eppendorf thermo-\ncycler with a 100 \u00b0C heated lid using the following cyc-\nling steps: an initial denaturing for 5 min at 95 \u00b0C;\nfollowed by 15 cycles of 20 s at 98 \u00b0C, 15 s at 62 \u00b0C, 60 s\nat 72 \u00b0C, and a final hold at 4 \u00b0C. We cleaned up the\nPCR reaction with a 2:1 ratio of SPRI beads to PCR\namplified DNA. The second PCR round aimed at adding\na unique index primer combination to molecularly bar-\ncode each sample. We took 4 \u03bcl of product from the first\nPCR and added 6 \u03bcl of Nebnext Ultra II Q5 mastermix\nand 1 \u03bcl of n5 and n7 indexing primers, with each sam-\nple being assigned a unique n5/n7 index primer combin-\nation. This 12 \u03bcl reaction was placed in an Eppendorf\nthermocycler with a 100 \u00b0C heated lid, denatured for 5\nmin at 95 \u00b0C, and amplified with 10 cycles of 20 s at\n98 \u00b0C, 15 s at 55 \u00b0C, and 60 s at 72 \u00b0C with a final hold at\n4 \u00b0C. After a 2:1 SPRI bead clean-up, amplification of the\nV4 region was confirmed in a few samples using an\nAATI fragment analyzer, and all libraries were quantified\nusing a qubit fluorometer. The libraries were then\npooled in roughly equimolar amounts (each with their\nown unique indexing primer combination), spiked with\n10% PhiX to increase library complexity, and sequenced\ntogether on a single Illumina NovaSeq 6000 SP 250 bp\npaired-end sequence flowcell.\nWe analyzed the resulting data using the Quantitative\nInsights Into Microbial Ecology 2 (QIIME2) platform\n[117, 118]. After trimming low-quality bases from the\nde-multiplexed reads, we merged overlapping paired-end\nreads, and denoised the sequencing data by filtering and\ncorrecting Illumina amplicon sequencing errors using\nthe Divisive Amplicon Denoising Algorithm 2 (DADA2:\n[119]) plugin incorporated in QIIME2. DADA2 infers se-\nquences exactly resulting in amplicon sequence variants\n(ASVs). Forward and reverse reads were trimmed to 220\nand 180 bases, respectively, to remove the low-quality\nportion of the sequences. The forward and reverse reads\nwere then merged together and chimeric sequences were\nremoved. Only samples with more than 20,000 reads\nwere retained for analyses (following observation of rar-\nefaction curves, Figure S12). After filtering, trimming,\nmerging, and chimera removal, we retained a total of\n348,390,395 reads across the 758 fecal samples (459,618\n\u00b1 815,020 reads per sample, range = 20,109-10,735,588).\nASVs were taxonomically assigned using the q2-feature\nclassifier in QIIME2 against version 132 of the SILVA\ndatabase (updated December 2017) [76] based on 100%\nsimilarity.\nUninformative\ntaxonomic\nassignments\nof\nASVs found in SILVA (e.g., \u201cwallaby metagenome,\u201d \u201cun-\nassigned bacteria,\u201d etc.) were converted to \u201cNA\u201d to sim-\nplify analyses at higher taxonomic levels. All ASVs\nbelonging to the order WCHB1-41 (phylum Kiritimatiel-\nlaeota) were not assigned at the family level in the\nSILVA classification. However, in the Greengene classifi-\ncation (version 13_8) [77], all ASVs from this order in\nthe gelada gut were assigned to the RFP12 family. Thus,\nwe attribute the family RFP12 to all ASVs from the\norder WCHB1-41 in SILVA classification. The 78 ASVs\nfrom the RFP12 family were found in particular high\nproportion in the gelada feces, but we did not have taxo-\nnomic\ninformation\nabout\nthose bacterial\nsequences\nbelow the family level. We thus mined previously pub-\nlished data to identify bacterial sequences most similar\nto the 78 RPF12 ASVs in geladas by using the NCBI\nBLAST search engine [46, 47]. For each of those 78\nASV, we searched for the most similar nucleotide se-\nquences previously published, extracted its top five hits\n(i.e., most similar sequences based on the E value), and\nsummarized the distribution of those top hits per ASV\nacross the 78 ASVs (including in which animal species\nthose hits were found, see Table S3). The five top hits\nhad an average of 97% nucleotide similarity (range, 93-\n100%) with their respective similar gelada ASVs.\nStatistical analyses\nThe count and taxonomy files generated by QIIME2 were\nimported into R version 3.5.2 [120] using the qiime2R\npackage [121] and analyzed using the phyloseq package\n[122]. The majority of the 19,606 ASVs in our dataset\nwere found at very low frequency or only in one sample\n(71% of ASVs were found in only one sample and 6.2% of\nASVs were not assigned at the phylum level). Thus, we\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 13 of 20\nfurther filtered the count table to retain only ASVs that\nhad at least 500 reads in total in the dataset (i.e., 0.00014%\nrelative abundance) to eliminate potentially artifactual se-\nquences. With this filtering criteria, only 3295 ASVs\nremained, with all of them assigned at the phylum level\nand most (97%) observed in at least two samples (Figure\nS13). The use of rarefaction (i.e., subsampling of the read\ncount in each sample to a common sequencing depth) has\nbeen discouraged due to the loss of information and preci-\nsion [123], as well as the use of count normalization\nmethods from the RNA-seq field (e.g., DESeq2 or edgeR).\nHowever, microbiome datasets are more sparse (zero-in-\nflated) and more asymmetrical than genetic expression\ndatasets [124, 125]. Thus, we used a compositional\napproach\nwhen\npossible\n(e.g.,\ncentered-log-ratio\nnormalization of the counts and Aitchison distance for\nbeta diversity analysis) [125, 126], controlling for sample\nsequencing depth in multivariate analyses to account for\nrepeated samples from the same individual.\nWe replicated alpha- and beta-diversity analyses using\ntraditional rarefaction methods to facilitate comparisons\nwith other studies. To generate the rarefied dataset, we\nrandomly sampled 20,000 reads from the raw fastq files\nof each sample and processed this new rarefied dataset\ninto the DADA2 pipeline. This dataset was further fil-\ntered to remove the low-frequency ASVs (i.e., ASVs not\nincluded in the pool of 3295 ASVs retained in the full\ndataset). This resulted in a dataset containing the same\n758\nsamples,\nwith\n2853\nASVs\nand\nwith\nrelatively\nhomogenous sequencing depth (18205 \u00b1 1415 reads per\nsample, range = 7460-19444). We rarefied reads from\nthe raw fastq files prior to DADA2 processing instead of\nthe traditional approach of rarefying after DADA2 using\nthe rarefy_even_depth function of the phyloseq package\n[122] because the traditional approach did not eliminate\nthe effect of sequencing depth (post-DADA2) on the\nalpha diversity metrics in the rarefied dataset. Sub-\nsampling the raw fastq files allowed us to better gen-\nerate indices of alpha diversity per sample that did\nnot depend on the total number of reads obtained\ninitially for the sample.\nAll mixed models described below were run using\neither the lmer (for linear mixed models, LMMs) or\nglmer (for binomial and negative binomial generalized\nlinear mixed models, GLMMs) functions of the lme4\npackage [127]. All quantitative variables (i.e., cumulative\nrainfall,\naveraged\ntemperature,\nand\nage)\nwere\nz-\ntransformed to have a mean of zero and a standard devi-\nation of one to facilitate model convergence. The signifi-\ncance of the fixed factors was tested using a likelihood\nratio test, LRT (assuming an asymptotic chi-square dis-\ntribution of the test statistic) via the drop1 function. To\ntest for significant pairwise differences between levels of\nmultilevel categorical variables (i.e., reproductive state),\npost hoc Tukey\u2019s Honest Significant Difference tests\nwere carried out using the multcomp package in R\n[128].\nAlpha-diversity analyses\nWe calculated three measures of alpha diversity: observed\nrichness (the total number of different ASVs in a sample),\nShannon diversity index (accounts for both richness and\nevenness of ASVs in a sample), and Faith\u2019s phylogenetic\ndiversity (accounts for phylogenetic distance between bac-\nterial species, using the picante package [129]). We mod-\neled each alpha diversity metric using linear mixed\nmodels: (i) as a function of age, sex, cumulative monthly\nrainfall, average monthly minimum temperature, and se-\nquencing depth of the sample (N = 758 samples), and (ii)\nas a function of reproductive state (cycling, early lactating,\nand pregnant), age, cumulative monthly rainfall, and aver-\nage monthly minimum temperature in samples collected\nfrom females (N = 439). Individual identity and unit mem-\nbership were included as random effects to control for in-\ndividual and unit repetition across samples. We also ran\nthe same models on the rarefied dataset (Table S16).\nBeta-diversity analyses\nWe then assessed how the same predictors were associ-\nated with between-sample community dissimilarity. To\naccount for differences in sequencing depth between\nsamples, the counts were normalized using the centered-\nlog-ratio (CLR) method (and using a pseudo count of\n0.65 for zero counts) from the \u201ccompositions\u201d package\n[130]. We then calculated the Aitchison distance be-\ntween\nsamples\n(i.e.,\nsimply\nthe\nEuclidean\ndistance\nbetween samples after clr transformation of the counts)\n[131] and conducted a Principal Component Analysis\n(PCA)\n(function\n\u201cprcomp\u201d)\nto\nvisually\nrepresent\nbetween-samples dissimilarity according to the predic-\ntors. This approach has been recommended for micro-\nbiome datasets [125] and allows for the projection of\neach sample onto individual principal components (PCS)\nand the variable loadings of ASVs onto each PC. While\nthe first axis of variation correlated mostly with rainfall\n(Fig. 2b), the second PCA axis was correlated with se-\nquencing depth and explained 11% of the variation (Fig-\nure S14). We used Permutational Multivariate Analysis\nof Variance (PERMANOVA) tests to assess the effect of\nthe predictors on the Aitchison distance between sam-\nples (using 10,000 permutations and the \u201cadonis2\u201d func-\ntion from the \u201cvegan\u201d package [132]). We ran three\ndifferent models: (1) including all samples where we\ntested only the effect of individual identity and sequen-\ncing depth, (2) including all samples where we tested the\neffect of unit, age, sex, cumulative monthly rainfall, aver-\nage monthly minimum temperature, and sequencing\ndepth of the sample, and (3) including only female\nBaniel et al. Microbiome            (2021) 9:26 \nPage 14 of 20\nsamples where we tested the effect of unit, reproductive\nstate, age, cumulative monthly rainfall, and average\nmonthly minimum temperature. In models 2 and 3, indi-\nvidual\nidentity\nwas\nincluded\nas\na\nblocking\nfactor\n(\u201cstrata\u201d) to control for repeated sampling. We also rep-\nlicated beta diversity analysis on the rarefied dataset. We\nran PERMANOVA tests using three complementary\npairwise dissimilarity metrics (Bray-Curtis distance, un-\nweighted and weighted UniFrac distances) to assess\nbetween-sample variation according to the same predic-\ntors (the same three models). Beta diversity results\nremained qualitatively similar (Table S17).\nDifferential abundance testing\nWe examined how our predictors were associated with\ndifferential abundance of bacteria (at the phylum, class,\norder, family, and genus levels) using negative binomial\nGLMMs. Compared to LMMs, negative binomial mixed\nmodels are better equipped to handle over-dispersed\nand zero-inflated distributions that often characterize\nmicrobiome datasets [133]. They also facilitate tests of\nseveral independent predictors while taking into account\nlongitudinal designs including random effects. We first\naggregated the counts (i.e., the number of reads per taxa\nand per sample) at the taxonomic level of interest. Only\ntaxa that had an average relative abundance across sam-\nples \u22650.01% were tested. Then, for a given taxa, the\ncount per sample was modeled as a function of (1) age,\nsex, cumulative monthly rainfall and averaged monthly\nminimum temperature (all samples), or (2) female repro-\nductive state, age, cumulative monthly rainfall, and aver-\naged monthly minimum temperature (female samples\nonly). The log-transformed number of reads per sample\nwas included as an offset term to control for variation in\nsequencing depth across samples. Individual identity and\nunit membership were included as random effects in all\nmodels. When negative binomial models failed to con-\nverge in some taxa, we converted the counts in pres-\nence/absence and modeled them with binomial GLMMs.\nBenjamini-Hochberg\ncorrected\np-values\n< 0.05\nwere\nconsidered statistically significant.\nFunctional profiling of microbiota\nWe estimated the bacterial and archaeal genes present\nin the metagenomes of each sample using Phylogenetic\nInvestigation of Communities by Reconstruction of\nUnobserved States version 2 (PICRUSt2) [50]. In brief,\nASVs were aligned to reference sequences using HMME\nR [134] and placed into a reference tree using EPA-NG\n[135] and Gappa [136]. PICRUSt2 normalizes for mul-\ntiple 16S gene copies in bacteria using castor, a hidden\nstate prediction tool [137]. The normalized data were\nused to predict gene family profiles, and mapped onto\ngene pathways using MinPath [138]. We followed the\ndefault protocols outlined on the PICRUSt2 GitHub\npage (https://github.com/picrust/picrust2/wiki). We in-\nvestigated the predicted gene families using the Kyoto\nEncyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) Orthology\n(KO) database. The accuracy of the PICRUSt2 predic-\ntions for each sample was assessed by calculating the\nweighted Nearest Sequence Taxon Index (NSTI) score, a\nmeasure of how similar the bacteria from the sample are\nto reference genome sequences. Five ASVs (out of 3295)\nhad a NSTI score > 2 and were removed from our final\npredictions. The association between the relative abun-\ndance of functional categories as estimated by PICRUSt2\nand the predictors (on all samples or female samples\nonly) were examined using LMMs. Only functional path-\nways that had \u22650.1% relative abundance across samples\nwere tested. Individual identity and unit membership\nwere included as random effects in all models.\nSupplementary Information\nThe online version contains supplementary material available at https://doi.\norg/10.1186/s40168-020-00977-9.\nAdditional file 1: Table S1. The R-squared values indi-\ncate the amount of between-sample variation explained by each variable.\nAdditional file 2: Supplemental Figure 1. For ease of representation on\npanel B, only pathways with effect size > |0.002| were represented. The\nfull list can be found in Table S8. Supplemental Figure 9. Lumeng,1,2 Jennifer L. Bodzin,1 and Alan R. Saltiel1,3\n1Life Sciences Institute, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA. 2Department of Pediatrics and Communicable Diseases and  \n3Departments of Internal Medicine and Physiology, University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA.\nAdipose tissue macrophages (ATMs) infiltrate adipose tissue during obesity and contribute to insulin resis-\ntance. We hypothesized that macrophages migrating to adipose tissue upon high-fat feeding may differ from \nthose that reside there under normal diet conditions. To this end, we found a novel F4/80+CD11c+ population \nof ATMs in adipose tissue of obese mice that was not seen in lean mice. ATMs from lean mice expressed many \ngenes characteristic of M2 or \u201calternatively activated\u201d macrophages, including Ym1, arginase 1, and Il10. Diet-\ninduced obesity decreased expression of these genes in ATMs while increasing expression of genes such as \nthose encoding TNF-\u03b1 and iNOS that are characteristic of M1 or \u201cclassically activated\u201d macrophages. Interest-\ningly, ATMs from obese C-C motif chemokine receptor 2\u2013KO (Ccr2-KO) mice express M2 markers at levels similar \nto those from lean mice. The antiinflammatory cytokine IL-10, which was overexpressed in ATMs from lean \nmice, protected adipocytes from TNF-\u03b1\u2013induced insulin resistance. Thus, diet-induced obesity leads to a shift \nin the activation state of ATMs from an M2-polarized state in lean animals that may protect adipocytes from \ninflammation to an M1 proinflammatory state that contributes to insulin resistance.\nIntroduction\nRecent investigations suggest that obesity gives rise to a state \nof chronic, low-grade inflammation that contributes to insulin \nresistance and type 2 diabetes (1, 2). Although the tissues and cell \ntypes involved in this inflammatory response are not fully under-\nstood, there is significant interest in the role of adipose tissue \nmacrophages (ATMs) in the inflammatory changes characteristic \nof obesity (3). In both humans and rodents, ATMs accumulate \nin adipose tissue with increasing body weight and their quantity \ncorrelates with measures of insulin resistance (4\u20136). In obese sub-\njects, ATM content is higher in visceral than subcutaneous adi-\npose tissue, consistent with the hypothesis that visceral fat plays \na more prominent role in insulin resistance (7). Moreover, weight \nloss leads to a reduction in both inflammatory markers and ATM \ncontent (4, 7). ATMs are a prominent source of proinflammatory \ncytokines such as TNF-\u03b1 and IL-6 that can block insulin action in \nadipocytes, providing a potential link between inflammation and \ninsulin resistance (6, 8).\nMouse models have demonstrated that ATMs are both neces-\nsary and sufficient for the development of insulin resistance with \nobesity. Mice with targeted deletions in the genes for monocyte \nchemoattractant protein\u20131 (Mcp1/Ccl2) and its receptor C-C motif \nchemokine receptor 2 (Ccr2) both have decreased ATM content, \ndecreased inflammation in fat, and protection from high-fat \ndiet\u2013induced (HFD-induced) insulin resistance (9, 10). Converse-\nly, mice overexpressing MCP-1 have increased numbers of ATMs \nalong with increased insulin resistance (9, 11). Moreover, myeloid-\nspecific KO of I\u03baB kinase \u03b2 (Ikbkb) produced mice with improved \ninsulin sensitivity on HFD (12). Together, these data suggest that \nboth the recruitment and proinflammatory activation of ATMs \nare required for the development of diabetes with obesity.\nWhile quantitative changes in ATM content with obesity and \ndiabetes are well supported, little is known about the range of \nATM function and how this may change with obesity. ATMs are \npresent in moderate quantities in adipose tissue of lean mice \nin which inflammatory signals are low or nonexistent (5, 6), \nand their role there is unclear. While Ccr2-KO (CCR2KO) and \nMcp1-KO mice have lower inflammatory cytokine expression \nin fat, they retain significant macrophage content within adi-\npose tissue (9, 10). This suggests that factors both dependent \nand independent of the MCP-1/CCR2 axis are involved in mac-\nrophage recruitment to fat and, further, that not all ATMs are \nprogrammed for proinflammatory signaling.\nMacrophages show significant heterogeneity in function, as local \nenvironmental factors shape their properties and activation state \n(13, 14). Different stimuli activate macrophages to express distinct \npatterns of chemokines, surface markers, and metabolic enzymes \nthat ultimately generate the diversity of macrophage function seen \nin inflammatory and noninflammatory settings. Macrophage acti-\nvation has been operationally defined across 2 separate polarization \nstates, M1 and M2 (13, 14). These states have largely been defined \nin vitro, and tissue macrophages are likely activated along a con-\ntinuum between these states in vivo. M1 or \u201cclassically activated\u201d \nmacrophages are induced by proinflammatory mediators such as \nLPS and IFN-\u03b3. M1 macrophages have enhanced proinflammatory \ncytokine production (TNF-\u03b1, IL-6, IL-12) and generate reactive oxy-\ngen species such as NO via activation of iNOS (Nos2).\nM2 or \u201calternatively activated\u201d macrophages are generated in \nvitro by exposure to IL-4 and IL-13 (15). M2 macrophages have \nlow proinflammatory cytokine expression and instead generate \nhigh levels of antiinflammatory cytokines IL-10 and IL-1 decoy \nreceptor. Additionally, arginase production is increased in M2-\npolarized macrophages. This enzyme blocks iNOS activity by a \nvariety of mechanisms, including competing for the arginine sub-\nstrate that is required for NO production (16). Overall, M2 mac-\nNonstandard abbreviations used: ATM, adipose tissue macrophage; CCR2, C-C \nmotif chemokine receptor 2; CCR2KO mouse, Ccr2-KO mouse; HFD, high-fat diet; \nIRS, insulin receptor substrate; MCP-1, monocyte chemoattractant protein\u20131; ND, \nnormal diet; SVF, stromal vascular fraction.\nConflict of interest: The authors have declared that no conflict of interest exists.\nCitation for this article: J. Clin. Invest. 117:175\u2013184 (2007). doi:10.1172/JCI29881.\nRelated Commentary, page 89  \nresearch article\n176 \nThe Journal of Clinical Investigation\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 http://www.jci.org\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Volume 117\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Number 1\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 January 2007\nrophages are believed to participate in the blockade of inflam-\nmatory responses and in the promotion of tissue repair (13). M2 \npolarization can occur in the absence of IL-4 or IL-13, suggesting \nthat this state may be induced by several different factors (17). \nMoreover, recent studies have shown that IL-4\u2013mediated M2 \npolarization is associated with the activation of transcription fac-\ntors involved in lipid oxidative metabolism that include PPAR\u03b3 \nand PPAR\u03b3 coactivator 1\u03b2 (PGC-1\u03b2) (18).\nIn mice, distinct monocyte subsets contribute to tissue inflam-\nmatory responses (13, 19). Noninflamed tissues are populated \nwith macrophages derived from CX3CR1hiCCR2\u2013 monocytes \n(20). In contrast, acute inflammation increases the levels of \nCX3CR1loCCR2+Ly-6Chi monocytes, which have a higher capac-\nity for migration into inflamed tissues compared with other \nmonocyte populations (21). This model is consistent with obser-\nvations that CCR2KO mice have decreased ATM content (10), \npresumably due to deficient recruitment of CX3CR1loCCR2+ \nmonocytes with retention of the trafficking of CX3CR1hiCCR2\u2013 \nmonocytes into adipose tissue.\nThe qualitative differences between these monocyte/macrophage \nsubtypes in ATMs and obesity are unknown but may be impor-\ntant in understanding the biology of these unique cells and their \ncontribution to diabetes. In this regard, we show here that ATMs \nundergo a phenotypic switch from an antiinflammatory M2 polar-\nization state to a proinflammatory M1 polarization state upon \nhigh-fat feeding, in the process losing their protective capacity.\nResults\nF4/80+CD11b+CD11c+ macrophages accumulate in fat with diet-induced \nobesity. As the majority of previous studies have used F4/80 expres-\nsion as a single marker to identify ATMs, we sought to examine \nATM heterogeneity in lean and obese mice using additional known \nmacrophage markers. Epididymal fat tissue plays a significant role \nin overall metabolism in rodents (22). We thus isolated stromal \nvascular fraction (SVF) cells from epididymal fat pads excised from \nmale mice fed a normal diet (ND) or HFD and analyzed cells by \nflow cytometry. ATMs from both lean and obese mice coexpressed \nF4/80 and CD11b, and the majority of the F4/80+CD11b+ cells \nalso expressed Mac-3 (data not shown). However, there was varia-\ntion in the amount of CD11c expression within the F4/80+CD11b+ \nATMs. The SVF from lean mice contained 17.8% F4/80+ cells, con-\nsistent with other reports (5). Only a small percentage of these cells \ncoexpressed CD11c (9.3% \u00b1 7.5%; n = 3 pools of mice) (Figure 1A). \nIn contrast, obese mice contained increased F4/80+ cell content \nwithin the SVF, with a significant increase in the percentage of \nF4/80+CD11c+ cells (38.4% \u00b1 15% of F4/80+ cells; P = 0.04 versus \nlean mice). These cells also expressed CD11b. Similar results were \nseen in leptin-deficient ob/ob mice, with 74% of the F4/80+ cells \ncoexpressing CD11c (data not shown).\nThe total number of both F4/80+CD11c+ cells (4.52 \u00b1 1.1 \u00d7 106 \ncells/mouse versus 0.196 \u00b1 0.16 \u00d7 106 cells/mouse; P = 0.021) \nand F4/80+CD11c\u2013 cells (1.98 \u00b1 0.42 \u00d7 106 cells/mouse versus \n9.69 \u00b1 8.2 \u00d7 106 cells/mouse; P = 0.24) isolated from epididymal \nFigure 1\nAccumulation of F4/80+CD11c+ ATMs in adipose \ntissue in obese mice. Normalizing this data to fat pad weight indicated \nthat there was a 5.5-fold increase in the content of F4/80+CD11c+ \ncells in adipose tissue from HFD-fed compared with ND mice \n(Figure 1C). In contrast, there was no significant change in the \nquantity of F4/80+CD11c\u2013 cells in adipose tissue per milligram \nfat weight between ND and HFD mice. This demonstrates that \nF4/80+CD11c+ cells are a specific population of ATMs recruited \nto fat tissue upon HFD exposure.\nPrevious studies indicated that targeted deletion of the Ccr2 gene \nresults in decreased macrophage content in adipose tissue and \nimproved insulin sensitivity (10). Thus, CCR2KO mice were also \nexamined for CD11c expression as a complementary mouse model. \nHFD-fed CCR2KO mice demonstrated a reduction in the content \nof F4/80+CD11c+ cells in the SVF compared with wild-type obese \nmice, with 14.4% \u00b1 9.2% of the F4/80+ cells coexpressing CD11c \n(P = 0.08 versus HFD C57BL/6) (Figure 1D). Normalizing for cell \nnumber and fat weight indicated that there was a greater than 50% \nreduction in the level of F4/80+CD11c+ ATMs in the CCR2KO mice \n(HFD C57BL/6, 2.4 \u00b1 0.46 \u00d7 103 cells/mg versus HFD CCR2KO, \n0.88 \u00b1 0.98 \u00d7 103 cells/mg) (Figure 1C). The content of total \nF4/80+CD11c+ cells in fat pads from HFD CCR2KO mice was also \nlower than in obese controls after normalization to cell number \n(Figure 1B). Similar to what was observed previously (10), adipo-\ncyte size was increased in HFD CCR2KO mice compared with con-\ntrol HFD mice (mean 7,933 \u00b1 2,754 \u03bcm2 versus 6,704 \u00b1 2,961 \u03bcm2, \u2002\nP = 0.041) and HFD CCR2KO mice were protected from hepatic \nsteatosis (data not shown). Contrary to these observations, how-\never, we noted increased fat pad weight in HFD CCR2KO mice \u2002\n(2.83 \u00b1 0.57 g versus control, 1.41 \u00b1 0.25 g; P = 0.011).\nImmunofluorescence microscopy confirmed the flow cytometry \nresults; ND SVF cultures contained only F4/80+CD11c\u2013 cells (Fig-\nure 2A). SVF cells from HFD mice showed a mix of F4/80+CD11c+ \nand F4/80+CD11c\u2013 cells. Immunohistochemistry on epididymal \nfat pads from obese mice localized CD11c+ cells in macrophage \nclusters surrounding adipocytes (Figure 2B). The CD11c antibody \nstained a subset of cells in these crownlike structures, while F4/80 \nstained nearly all of the cells in these clusters. Scattered individual \nCD11c+ ATMs were observed surrounding adipocytes in what may \nhave been early ATM clusters (Figure 2C). Rare CD11c+ cells were \nseen in adipose tissue sections from lean mice.\nIncreased inflammatory gene expression in F4/80+CD11c+ ATMs. \nBecause CD11c+ cells appear to accumulate in adipose tissue after \nhigh-fat feeding, we assessed expression of inflammatory genes in \nF4/80+CD11c+ ATMs compared with F4/80+CD11c\u2013 ATMs from \nobese mice.
