Sections were \ncounterstained with hematoxylin (blue) and images taken at low (\u00d7200) \nand high magnification (\u00d71,000). (C) In obese mice, CD11c+ cells were \nalso detected surrounding normal-appearing adipocytes in the absence \nof crownlike macrophage clusters (\u00d71,000 magnification).\nresearch article\n178 \nThe Journal of Clinical Investigation\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 http://www.jci.org\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Volume 117\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Number 1\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 January 2007\nmacrophages (15, 23). ATMs from lean animals showed increased \nexpression of M2-specific genes Il10 (IL-10), Arg1 (arginase I), Mrc2 \n(mannose receptor, C type 2), Ym1/Chi3l3 (Ym1/chitinase 3\u2013like 3),  \nand Mgl1/2 (macrophage galactose N-acetyl-galactosamine\u2013spe-\ncific lectins 1 and 2) compared with the ATMs isolated from HFD \nmice (Figure 4A). In contrast, expression of proinflammatory \ngenes such as Tnfa and Nos2 was considerably lower in ND ATMs \ncompared with ATMs from obese animals (Figure 4B).\nAs macrophages make up only a portion of the stromal cells in \nadipose tissue, we examined expression of some of these genes in \nunsorted SVF isolates. Similar patterns of gene expression were \nseen in RNA prepared from SVF cells from lean and obese mice \n(Figure 4, C and D), with increased Ym1 and Il10 expression in ND \nmice and increased Tnfa and Nos2 expression in HFD mice.\nSince inflammatory macrophage recruitment into fat tissue \nappears to be partially dependent on CCR2 (10), we hypothesized \nthat ATMs in obese CCR2KO mice might retain properties of \nM2-polarized macrophages and thus evaluated gene expression \nin these cells. Indeed, ATMs isolated from obese CCR2KO mice \nexpressed alternatively activated macrophage markers at levels that \nwere similar to those seen in ATMs from lean mice. Furthermore, \nthese were significantly elevated compared with levels in ATMs \nfrom obese mice (Figure 4A).\nWe confirmed gene expression data by examining protein lev-\nels in the ATMs under study. Consistent with the RNA expression \ndata, Ym1 was increased in SVF samples from lean compared with \nobese mice (Figure 4E). Additionally, purification of CD11b+ ATMs \nfrom SVF samples indicated that Ym1 is predominantly expressed \nin ATMs compared with non-macrophage CD11b\u2013 cells.\nAnother characteristic of the alternative macrophage activa-\ntion state is increased arginase activity (15). Arginase activity was \nassessed in SVF and adipocyte samples from lean and obese mice. \nWhile the activity of this enzyme did not differ between the iso-\nlated adipocytes from lean and obese mice, arginase activity was \nsignificantly diminished in the SVF fraction after HFD exposure \n(Figure 4F). This indicates that the arginase/iNOS balance in \nATMs from lean animals is skewed toward an immunosuppres-\nsive state that changes to a proinflammatory state with obesity \n(elevated iNOS and repressed arginase activity).\nIL-10 protects adipocytes from the deleterious effects of TNF-\u03b1. The \nobservation that the expression of Il10 is higher in the SVF and \nATMs from lean compared with obese mice led us to examine the \neffects of the cytokine on adipocyte function. To explore the cellu-\nlar effects of IL-10, we first examined the expression of its receptor. \nThe IL-10 receptor \u03b1 (IL-10R\u03b1) was detected in adipose tissue by \nimmunoblotting (Figure 5A). Separation of the SVF from adipo-\ncytes in lean and obese animals indicated that the IL-10 receptor \nwas expressed primarily in adipocytes, with minimal expression \nin the SVF (Figure 5B). No significant differences were seen in \u2002\nIL-10R\u03b1 expression between lean and obese mice.\nWe next examined IL-10 signaling in differentiated 3T3-L1 adi-\npocytes. STAT3 phosphorylation by the IL-10 receptor has been \nshown to be required for its antiinflammatory effects (24). Treat-\nment of adipocytes with IL-10 led to the tyrosine phosphorylation \nof STAT3 within 5 minutes. This effect peaked at 10 minutes and \ndeclined thereafter (Figure 5C). As IL-10 as been shown to activate \nthe PI3K pathway via insulin receptor substrate (IRS) proteins (25), \nwe examined phosphorylation of Akt in response to IL-10. IL-10 \ntreatment of adipocytes produced the rapid serine phosphoryla-\ntion of Akt (Figure 5C).\nIL-10 has a variety of antiinflammatory effects in macrophages \nand other cell types that includes the antagonism of the actions of \nTNF-\u03b1 (26). To examine this in adipocytes, we first analyzed the \neffect of IL-10 on the secretion of the chemokine MCP-1, thought \nto be a major attractant for macrophages in states of obesity (9, \n11, 27). IL-10 treatment for 16 hours decreased MCP-1 secretion \nfrom adipocytes (Figure 6A). As reports suggest that IL-10 may \nmediate its antiinflammatory effects by antagonizing activation \nof NF-\u03baB\u2013mediated gene transcription (28), we examined the \neffects of IL-10 on TNF-\u03b1\u2013stimulated NF-\u03baB activity using an \nNF-\u03baB\u2013responsive luciferase reporter gene. While TNF-\u03b1 induced \nreporter gene expression, IL-10 had no effect upon this activation \n(data not shown). This is consistent with other reports that show \nthat IL-10 can alter the transcriptional rate of inflammatory genes \nindependent of NF-\u03baB activation (29).\nWe next examined the effects of IL-10 on insulin signal \ntransduction in adipocytes in concert with TNF-\u03b1. Treatment \nof cells with TNF-\u03b1 for 6 hours dramatically reduced the levels \nof glucose transporter 4 (GLUT4) protein, with a smaller reduc-\ntion in the level of insulin receptor expression, similar to what has \nbeen reported previously (30). IL-10 pretreatment prevented the \nTNF-\u03b1\u2013induced downregulation of both proteins (Figure 6B). \nAdditionally, insulin-stimulated IRS1 tyrosine phosphorylation \nwas decreased with TNF-\u03b1 treatment. This inhibitory effect was \nprevented by pretreatment with IL-10 (Figure 6C). IL-10 treat-\nment produced no significant changes in TNF-\u03b1\u2013stimulated IRS1 \nphosphorylation at Ser307, suggesting that the antagonism of \u2002\nTNF-\u03b1 action by IL-10 occurs either downstream of or in parallel \nto reduced tyrosine phosphorylation of IRS1.\nTo determine whether IL-10 protects adipocytes from the physi-\nological effects of TNF-\u03b1, we examined insulin-stimulated glucose \nuptake in 3T3-L1 adipocytes with and without IL-10 pretreatment. \nTreatment of cells with TNF-\u03b1 for 3 hours produced a significant, \n30%\u201340% inhibition of insulin-stimulated glucose uptake. Pre-\ntreatment of the cells with IL-10 for 24 hours blocked these acute \ninhibitory effects of TNF-\u03b1 (Figure 7A). Prolonged (72-hour), low-\ndose TNF-\u03b1 treatment increased basal glucose uptake but had no \neffect on insulin-stimulated levels, consistent with a dramatic \nupregulation of the glucose transporter GLUT1 under these con-\nFigure 3\nIncreased inflammatory gene expression in F4/80+CD11c+ ATMs. SVF \ncells were isolated from HFD-fed male C57BL/6 mice (n = 3) and stained \nfor F4/80 and CD11c. F4/80+CD11c+ and F4/80+CD11c\u2013 cells were iso-\nlated by FACS and total RNA isolated. Expression of Itgax (CD11c), \nTnfa (TNF-\u03b1), Il6 (IL-6), Nos2 (iNOS), and Apoe (apoE) was analyzed \nby real-time RT-PCR in F4/80+CD11c+ (white bars) and F4/80+CD11c\u2013 \n(black bars) ATMs. Data are expressed as mean \u00b1 SD. *P < 0.05.\nresearch article\n \nThe Journal of Clinical Investigation\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 http://www.jci.org\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Volume 117\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Number 1\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 January 2007\t\n179\nditions (31). IL-10 blocked these effects of TNF-\u03b1 and maintained \ncells in an insulin-sensitive state (Figure 7B). Moreover, insulin-\nstimulated glucose uptake was dramatically enhanced in cells \nchronically treated with IL-10 compared with untreated cells.\nDiscussion\nRecent data suggest that obesity may represent a state of chron-\nic, low-grade inflammation and that overnutrition is associated \nwith the infiltration of adipose tissue by inflammatory cells (2). \nAlthough the precise cell types involved in this process remain \nuncertain, evidence is mounting that implicates ATMs as a sig-\nnificant contributor to inflammation in obesity and a mediator \nof insulin resistance (3, 9, 32). Because the properties of ATMs are \nnot well characterized, we performed a detailed examination of \nATM subtypes and their gene expression in obese and lean mice. \nBased on the wide range of functions that macrophages display in \nnormal and inflamed tissues (33), we hypothesized that ATMs are \ndifferentially activated depending on the degree of adiposity and, \nfurther, that in addition to quantitative differences, qualitative \ndifferences exist between ATMs in lean and obese animals.\nWe report here that ATMs isolated from white adipose tissue \nfrom lean animals express hallmarks of polarization toward an \nalternatively activated state (M2), suggesting a potentially ben-\neficial function of these cells. M2 polarization has been described \nin tumor-associated macrophages and parasitic infections and is \nbelieved to regulate tissue repair and prevent excess inflammation \n(15, 34). The markers of M2-polarized macrophages are still being \ndescribed but include expression of the chitinase family member \nYm1, the antiinflammatory cytokine IL-10, arginase, and surface \nlectins Mgl1 and Mgl2 (15, 23). The genes encoding all of these pro-\nteins were overexpressed in ATMs from lean compared with obese \nmice. Moreover, ATMs from obese CCR2KO mice, which display \nsignificantly lower inflammatory gene expression compared with \ntheir wild-type counterparts, express M2 markers at levels compa-\nrable to those in lean mice. This observation is consistent with the \nevidence that resident tissue macrophages in normal conditions \nare derived from CCR2\u2013 monocytes, while macrophages recruited \nto sites of inflammation are derived from CCR2+ monocytes (20).\nIn the current paradigm of macrophage polarization, the prop-\nerties of M2 macrophages contrast with the proinflammatory \nactivities of classically activated M1 macrophages. One important \ndifference between these polarization states involves the balance \nbetween arginase and iNOS activities. Arginase and iNOS both uti-\nlize l-arginine as a substrate. However, while iNOS generates reac-\ntive NO species with microbicidal and proinflammatory effects \nimportant in immune responses, arginase competes with iNOS for \narginine as a substrate and generates l-ornithine, an important \nprecursor for proline that enhances collagen biosynthesis (16). \nFigure 4\nIncreased expression of markers of alternatively activated (M2) macrophages in ATMs from lean ND-fed mice. (A and B) Gene expression in \nATMs from ND and HFD mice. F4/80+CD11b+ ATMs were isolated from ND C57BL/6 (white bars), HFD C57BL/6 (black bars), and HFD CCR2KO \nmice (gray bars) (n = 3 pools of mice for each) and analyzed by real-time RT-PCR for expression of M2 macrophage\u2013specific genes (A) and \nproinflammatory genes (B). Data are expressed as mean \u00b1 SD. *P < 0.05. (C and D) SVF was isolated from ND (white bars) and HFD (black \nbars) mice (n = 2\u20133 mice per condition) and analyzed by real-time RT-PCR for expression of M2 macrophage markers (C) and proinflamma-\ntory genes (D). (E) Ym1 protein expression in the SVF. Lysates from SVF isolated from ND and HFD mice were immunoblotted for Ym1 (left). \nCD11b+ ATMs were separated from CD11b\u2013 cells in the SVF and lysates prepared for immunoblotting, which demonstrated Ym1 expression in \nthe macrophage fraction (right). Macrophage marker CD68 controlled for the purification protocol. Similar results were obtained in a duplicate \nexperiment. (F) Arginase activity in adipose tissue from ND and HFD mice. Epididymal fat pads from ND- (white bars) and HFD-fed (black bars) \nmice were separated into adipocyte and SVF fractions and lysates prepared. Arginase activity was assessed by an assay of urea production \nfrom arginine substrate and was normalized to protein concentration. Reactions were performed in triplicate. Data are expressed as mean \u00b1 SD. \n*P < 0.05. Similar results were obtained for 3 separate sets of mice.\nresearch article\n180 \nThe Journal of Clinical Investigation\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 http://www.jci.org\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Volume 117\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Number 1\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 January 2007\nBased both on gene expression analysis and direct measurement \nof activity, ATMs from lean mice exhibit enhanced arginase activ-\nity compared with obese mice. This balance in favor of arginase \nmay play a critical role in repressing the generation of NO and \nother reactive oxygen species by iNOS and thus maintain adipo-\ncyte function and promote tissue repair and remodeling.\nThe dramatic differences in IL-10 expression in lean compared \nwith obese ATMs imply an important role for this cytokine as a \nhomeostatic regulator in insulin sensitivity. Acute IL-10 infusion \nwas shown to improve insulin sensitivity in whole animals (35), \nsuggesting that this molecule may balance the effects of proin-\nflammatory cytokines such as TNF-\u03b1. In humans, circulating IL-10 \u2002\nlevels correlate with markers of improved insulin sensitivity (36), \nand IL-10 levels increase along with insulin sensitivity after exer-\ncise (37). Polymorphisms in the IL-10 promoter associated with low \nIL-10 expression are correlated with increased obesity and insulin \nresistance (38). Additionally, adiponectin has been shown to induce \u2002\nIL-10 expression in human leukocytes (39). Studies have also shown \nthat in obese humans and rodents, both adipocyte and SVF com-\npartments from adipose tissue are significant sources of IL-10 (40). \nAs levels of proinflammatory cytokines are increased in obesity, \nthis observation is consistent with the hypothesis that a balance \nexists between proinflammatory and antiinflamma-\ntory factors that governs adipocyte function.\nIn vitro studies described here show that IL-10 \nprotects against TNF-\u03b1\u2013dependent insulin resis-\ntance in adipocytes. The mechanism underlying \nthis effect remains uncertain. In macrophages, \u2002\nIL-10 attenuates TNF-\u03b1 inflammatory signals via \nactivation of STAT3 (24) and modulation of inflam-\nmatory gene transcription rates (29). We have not \nobserved changes in TNF-\u03b1\u2013stimulated NF-\u03baB acti-\nvation with IL-10 in adipocytes, although we did \nobserve increased PI3K signaling with the cytokine. \nThis observation agrees with previous reports that \nIL-10 can activate PI3K pathways via IRS (25) and \nsuggests a possible mechanism by which IL-10 can \nantagonize the deleterious effects of TNF-\u03b1 on \ninsulin signaling in adipocytes.\nObesity leads to a shift in ATM phenotype exem-\nplified by increased Tnfa and Nos2 expression, \nboth characteristically activated in classically acti-\nvated M1 macrophages (4\u20136). We have identified a \nunique subset of ATMs present only in obese animals that express \nF4/80+CD11b+CD11c+. These cells overexpress inflammatory \ngenes compared with F4/80+CD11b+CD11c\u2013 ATMs and are the \nmajor ATM population that accumulates in fat with diet-induced \nobesity. These studies indicate a previously uncharacterized diver-\nsity within the ATM population in obese mice that may have \nimportant functional consequences.\nCD11c is a marker for DCs, which primarily function in \nphagocytosis, immune surveillance, and antigen presentation. \nF4/80+CD11c+ DCs have been termed interstitial dendritic cells; \nthey were recently described in a kidney network that is believed \nto participate in immune surveillance (41). How these DCs par-\nticipate in inflammatory signals in adipose tissue is unknown. \nIt is possible that DC activation is critical to the coordination of \ninflammatory events within fat tissue. An important role for DCs \nin obese adipose tissue is supported by the decreased expression of \nMHC class II genes in CCR2KO mice relative to controls (10). More-\nFigure 5\nIL-10 signaling in adipocytes. (A) Expression of IL-10 receptor in adipose tissue. \nImmunoblots of lysates from adipose tissue (Ad), lung (Lu), and spleen (Sp) from mice \nprobed with IL-10 receptor \u03b1 (IL-10R\u03b1) antibodies. (B) Expression of IL-10 receptor \nin adipocytes and not the SVF from adipose tissue. Epididymal fat pads from ND- and \nHFD-fed mice were collected and separated into SVF and adipocyte fractions. Lysates \nwere prepared and immunoblotted with anti\u2013IL-10 receptor antibodies and loading \ncontrols. (C) IL-10 treatment of adipocytes activates STAT3 and Akt. Differentiated \n3T3-L1 adipocytes were stimulated with IL-10 (20 ng/ml) for the indicated times and \nlysates prepared. Immunoblots were probed with antibodies against phosphoY705-\nSTAT3 and phosphoS473-Akt and STAT3 and Akt as loading controls. Experiments \nwere repeated twice, and results of a representative experiment are shown.\nFigure 6\nIL-10 prevents the effects of TNF-\u03b1 on adipocytes. (A) IL-10 decreas-\nes MCP-1 secretion by adipocytes. 3T3-L1 adipocytes were treated \nwith media with or without IL-10 (20 ng/ml) for 16 hours. Conditioned \nmedia was then removed and assayed for MCP-1 levels by ELISA.  \nn = 5 independent samples per condition. Data are expressed as \nmean \u00b1 SD. (B) IL-10 protects adipocytes from TNF-\u03b1\u2013induced \ndownregulation of insulin receptor and glucose transporter 4 \n(GLUT4) expression. 3T3-L1 cells were treated with or without  \nIL-10 for 24 hours prior to treatment with or without TNF-\u03b1 (17 ng/ml \nfor 6 hours). Lysates were prepared and immunoblots probed with \nantibodies against the insulin receptor (IR) and GLUT4. (C) IL-10 \nmaintains IRS levels despite treatment with TNF-\u03b1. Adipocytes were \ntreated as described for B and lysates examined for IRS1 tyrosine \nphosphorylation induced by insulin (INS; 100 nM for 5 minutes) after \nimmunoprecipitation of IRS1. IRS serine phosphorylation at Ser307 \nwas evaluated using specific antibodies.\nresearch article\n \nThe Journal of Clinical Investigation\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 http://www.jci.org\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Volume 117\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Number 1\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 January 2007\t\n181\nover, we have observed an increased expression of MHC class II \u2002\ngenes in ATMs specifically recruited to adipose tissue with HFD \n(42). These data suggest that DC-coordinated immunity may be \ncrucial to the inflammatory events in adipose tissue that occur \nwith obesity. Why such DCs are activated and what antigens they \nrespond to is currently unknown.\nExamining ATM infiltration into adipose tissue in the context \nof monocyte and macrophage heterogeneity leads us to propose \na model for ATM biology that incorporates the diversity of these \ncells (Figure 8). In lean animals, resident macrophages are polar-\nized toward an M2 state (high IL-10 and arginase levels) derived \nfrom CCR2\u2013 monocytes that help maintain normal adipocyte \nfunction, perhaps by promoting tissue repair and angiogenesis in \nadipose tissue. Nutrient excess leads to adipocyte expansion, with \nincreased secretion of monocyte chemoattractants that recruit \ninflammatory type CCR2+ monocytes to fat, where they differen-\ntiate into M1-polarized activated macrophages and CD11c+ DCs. \nAlternatively activated M2 macrophages may be able to partially \nprevent the activation and accumulation of these classically acti-\nvated M1 macrophages (43, 44), and the secretion of IL-10 helps \nprotect adipocytes against the deleterious effects of TNF-\u03b1 and \nrelated cytokines. However, with increasing adiposity, increased \nproinflammatory signals, continued recruitment of M1-polarized \nCCR2+ monocytes, and accumulation of CD11c+ ATMs all con-\ntribute to overwhelm the protective effects of M2 macrophages, \nleading to a dominant role for M1-polarized, classically activated \nmacrophages that generate high TNF-\u03b1, IL-6, and NO production. \nThis model explains observations in obese CCR2KO and Mcp1/\nCcl2-KO mice that retain a population of ATMs with decreased \ninflammatory capacity (9, 10). We suspect that these KOs are \ndeficient in the recruitment of CCR2+ monocytes during inflam-\nmation in fat tissue, while the trafficking of CCR2\u2013 monocytes \nwith M2 polarization remains intact. Studies aimed at determin-\ning whether enhancing M2 polarization in ATMs can block diet-\ninduced insulin resistance will be required in order to test this \nmodel. One limitation of the data leading to this model is that \nthey are largely based on flow cytometric analysis of isolated SVF \npopulations after collagenase digestion. This method of separa-\ntion is an efficient one but may not fully capture all stromal cells \nfrom adipose tissue (5).\nHow diet-induced obesity leads to a change from M2 to M1 \npolarization is currently unknown, but the mechanism is likely \nmultifactorial. Our data suggest that the MCP-1/CCR2 axis con-\ntributes to this polarization. We propose 2 potential models for \nthis qualitative change in ATM activation: (a) Obesity may lead \nto an increase in the level of Ly-6ChiCCR2+ circulating monocytes \nthat are primed for activation along an M1 polarization pattern. \nFactors such as MCP-1, TNF-\u03b1, and free fatty acids that activate \nTLR4 (45) may combine to influence this activation pattern as \nthese monocytes enter adipose tissue. This model is supported \nby observations that obesity is associated with changes in acti-\nvation state of circulating monocytes toward a more proinflam-\nmatory phenotype (46, 47). (b) Alternatively, obesity may change \nATMs in adipose tissue from an M2 toward an M1 phenotype. \nMacrophages are reported to have the potential to switch from \none polarization state to another depending upon environmental \nstimuli (48). However, this model depends upon a slow turnover \nof ATMs. Studies involving pulse labeling macrophages in vivo \nindicated that ATMs are largely replaced by 8 weeks in HFD-fed \nmice (42). Additionally, we have observed that the ATMs recruit-\ned to adipose tissue in HFD-fed mice overexpress Ccr2 and other \nproinflammatory mediators. These observations are consistent \nwith the first hypothesis, according to which obesity leads to the \nrecruitment of M1-polarized macrophages that gradually replace \nM2-polarized cells, which represents the default pathway of acti-\nvation under lean conditions.\nOur study frames ATM biology within the context of other \nknown models of inflammation and macrophage recruitment. It \nmay be possible to decrease inflammatory signals in adipose tis-\nsue by modifying ATMs to retain an M2 polarization or by con-\nverting M1 polarized macrophages to M2. Increasing IL-10 levels \nmay represent one mechanism through which this could occur, \nsince chronic IL-10 secretion can suppress classically activated M1 \nmacrophages (49). For immunoblots, anti-phosphotyrosine (4G10) and \nIRS1 antibodies were purchased from Upstate USA Inc. \u03b2-Actin monoclo-\nnal antibody was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. GLUT4 antibodies were \nobtained from Alpha Diagnostics International. STAT3, phosphotyrosine-\nSTAT3, Akt, and phospho-Akt antibodies were purchased from Cell Signal-\ning Technology. Mouse recombinant TNF-\u03b1 and IL-10 were obtained from \nSigma-Aldrich. Anti-CD68, anti\u2013IL-10 receptor \u03b1 antibodies, and MCP-1 \u2002\nELISA kits were purchased from R&D Systems. Anti-F4/80 antibodies \nwere from Abcam. Alexa Fluor 488\u2013conjugated CD11b and unconjugated \nCD11c and CD11b antibodies were from AbD Serotec. PE-conjugated \nanti\u2013Mac-3, PE/Cy5-conjugated anti-F4/80, APC-conjugated anti-CD11c, \nand isotype antibodies were purchased from eBioscience. Anti-Ym1 anti-\nbodies were purchased from StemCell Technologies.\nAnimals and animal care. Male C57BL/6 mice were rendered insulin resis-\ntant by feeding an HFD consisting of 45% of calories from fat (D12451; \nResearch Diets Inc.) starting at 8 weeks of age for 20 weeks or indicated \ntimes. Control mice were fed a standard diet consisting of 4.5% fat (5002; \nLabDiet). ob/obJ mice were obtained from The Jackson Laboratory. \nCCR2KO mice on a C57BL/6 background were kindly provided by S. Kun-\nkel (University of Michigan). Animals were housed in a specific pathogen\u2013\nfree facility with a 12-hour light/12-hour dark cycle and given free access \nto food and water. All animal use was in compliance with the Institute of \nLaboratory Animal Research Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory \nAnimals and approved by the University Committee on Use and Care of \nAnimals at the University of Michigan.\nCell culture. 3T3-L1 fibroblasts were propagated and differentiated into \nadipocytes as described previously (50). Adipocytes were used in experi-\nments 8\u201310 days after differentiation. Adherent SVF cells were cultured on \nplastic or glass coverslips in DMEM supplemented with 10% endotoxin-\nfree FBS. For signaling experiments, the cells were starved overnight in \n0.5% serum media prior to stimulation with IL-10. For chronic treatment \nwith IL-10 (20 ng/ml) and TNF-\u03b1 (3 ng/mL), adipocyte media was replaced \nwith fresh media every 24 hours.\nSVF isolation and ATM purification. Epididymal fat pads from male \nC57BL/6 mice fed an ND or HFD were excised and minced in PBS with \ncalcium chloride and 0.5% BSA. Tissue suspensions were centrifuged \nat 500 g for 5 minutes to remove erythrocytes and free leukocytes. Col-\nlagenase (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to 1 mg/ml and incubated at 37\u00b0C \nfor 20 minutes with shaking. The cell suspension was filtered through a \u2002\n100-\u03bcm filter and then spun at 300 g for 5 minutes to separate floating \nadipocytes from the SVF pellet. To ensure proper isolation, adipocyte frac-\ntions were examined by microscopy before and after plating on plastic to \ndetect adherent cells. Samples were digested until adipocyte fractions were \nfree of adherent cells by these 2 quality-control methods to ensure recovery \nof the majority of the SVF population.\nFor cell culture, the pellet containing the SVF cells was resuspended in \ngrowth media for further experiments. For flow cytometry, the SVF pellet \nwas resuspended in 0.5 ml RBC Lysis Buffer (eBioscience) and incubated \nfor 5 minutes prior to resuspension in sorting buffer (PBS with 0.5% endo-\ntoxin-free FBS, 2 mM EDTA, and 25 mM HEPES) at a concentration of \n107 cells/ml. Cells were incubated with Fc Block (BD Biosciences) prior to \nstaining with conjugated antibodies for 15 minutes at 4\u00b0C followed by 2 \nwashes in 10\u00d7 excess of sorting buffer. Cells were resuspended in sorting \nbuffer supplemented with DAPI and then analyzed by FACS (FACSAria; BD \nBiosciences). Viable cells were sorted directly into RNA lysis buffer for RNA \nextraction. ATMs were identified by coexpression of F4/80 and CD11b.\nIsolation of CD11b+ cells from SVF isolates was performed by magnetic \nimmunoaffinity isolation with anti-CD11b antibodies conjugated to \nmagnetic beads (MACS; Miltenyi Biotec). Cells were isolated using positive \nselection columns prior to preparation of whole-cell lysates.\nImmunofluorescence staining. For immunofluorescence, SVF cells were plat-\ned onto glass coverslips for 2 hours, and nonadherent cells were removed by \n3 washes with PBS. After 24 hours, the cells were fixed by incubation with \nFigure 8\nProposed model for ATM polarization and its function in adipose tissue with progressive obesity. In lean, insulin-sensitive states, ATMs are polar-\nized toward an M2 state with IL-10 and arginase expression. Early during HFD treatment, adipocytes undergo hypertrophy, releasing chemokines \nthat induce recruitment of M1-polarized ATMs with low IL-10 expression and increased iNOS and TNF-\u03b1 production. In these early stages of mild \nobesity with retained insulin sensitivity, M2-polarized resident ATMs are able to partially protect adipocytes from these inflammatory factors and \nmay block M1 polarization. With increased adiposity, recruited CCR2+ ATMs form crownlike structures (CLS) and overwhelm the protective effects \nof M2 macrophages, leading to a dominant role for TNF-\u03b1 and iNOS. These factors generate insulin resistance in adipocytes, activate JNK and \nNF-\u03baB, alter adipokine secretion, and lead to excess circulating levels of free fatty acids due to adipocyte lipolysis and impaired lipogenesis.\nresearch article\n \nThe Journal of Clinical Investigation\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 http://www.jci.org\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Volume 117\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 Number 1\u2002 \u2002 \u2002 January 2007\t\n183\n10% formalin for 20 minutes at room temperature. Cells were blocked in \n2% BSA in PBS and incubated with primary antibodies diluted in blocking \nbuffer. Alexa Fluor 488\u2013conjugated secondary antibodies were incubated \nat a concentration of 2 mg/ml. Coverslips were mounted on slides with \nVECTASHIELD (Vector Laboratories) and imaged on a confocal fluores-\ncence microscope (Olympus FV300).\nReal-time RT-PCR. RNA extraction was performed with an RNeasy kit \n(Qiagen). RT reactions were performed using standard methods (Strat-\nagene) and real-time PCR analysis was performed using SYBR Green \nnormalized to GAPDH (ABI Prism 7200 Sequence Detection System; \nApplied Biosystems). PCR primers used were: Apoe For, 5\u2032-CTGACAG-\nGATGCCTAGCCG-3\u2032; Apoe Rev, 5\u2032-CGCAGGTAATCCCAGAAGC-3\u2032; Arg1 \nFor, 5\u2032-CTCCAAGCCAAAGTCCTTAGAG-3\u2032; Arg1 Rev, 5\u2032-AGGAGCTGT-\nCATTAGGGACATC-3\u2032; Chi3l3 For, 5\u2032-AGAAGGGAGTTTCAAACCT-\nGGT-3\u2032; Chi3l3 Rev, 5\u2032-GTCTTGCTCATGTGTGTAAGTGA-3\u2032; Gapdh \nFor, 5\u2032-TGAAGCAGGCATCTGAGGG-3\u2032; Gapdh Rev, 5\u2032-CGAAGGT-\nGGAAGAGTGGGAG-3\u2032; Il10 For, 5\u2032-GCTCTTACTGACTGGCAT-\nGAG-3\u2032; Il10 Rev, 5\u2032-CGCAGCTCTAGGAGCATGTG-3\u2032; Itgax For, \n5\u2032-CTGGATAGCCTTTCTTCTGCTG-3\u2032; Itgax Rev, 5\u2032-GCACACTGTGTCC-\nGAACTC-3\u2032; Mgl1 For, 5\u2032-TGAGAAAGGCTTTAAGAACTGGG-3\u2032; Mgl1 \nRev, 5\u2032-GACCACCTGTAGTGATGTGGG-3\u2032; Mrc2 For, 5\u2032-TACAGCTC-\nCACGCTATGGATT-3\u2032; Mrc2 Rev, 5\u2032-CACTCTCCCAGTTGAGGTACT-3\u2032; \nMgl2 For, 5\u2032-TTAGCCAATGTGCTTAGCTGG-3\u2032; Mgl2 Rev, 5\u2032-GGCCTC-\nCAATTCTTGAAACCT-3\u2032; Nos2 For, 5\u2032-CCAAGCCCTCACCTACTTCC-3\u2032; \nNos2 Rev, 5\u2032-CTCTGAGGGCTGACACAAGG-3\u2032; Pparg For, 5\u2032-GGAAGAC-\nCACTCGCATTCCTT-3\u2032; Pparg Rev, 5\u2032-TCGCACTTTGGTATTCTT-\nGGAG-3\u2032; Tnfa For, 5\u2032-ACGGCATGGATCTCAAAGAC-3\u2032; Tnfa Rev, \u2002\n5\u2032-AGATAGCAAATCGGCTGACG-3\u2032. Relative expression was assessed by \nthe comparative CT method correcting for amplification efficiency of the \nprimers and performed in triplicate.\nImmunoblotting and immunoprecipitation. Cell lysates were prepared \nby the addition of lysis buffer (150 mM sodium chloride, 50 mM Tris \npH 8, 1% NP-40, 0.1% SDS, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 1 mM EDTA, \n10 mM sodium fluoride, 1 mM sodium pyrophosphate, 1 mM sodium \northovanadate, and protease inhibitors [complete Mini tablets; Roche \nApplied Science]). Cells were lysed at 4\u00b0C for 30 minutes and clarified by \ncentrifugation. For immunoprecipitations, lysates were incubated with \n1 \u03bcg of anti-IRS1 antibodies overnight at 4\u00b0C and immune complexes \nprecipitated with Protein A/G\u2013conjugated beads (Santa Cruz Biotechnol-\nogy Inc.). Beads were washed with lysis buffer and resuspended in sample \nbuffer. Lysates and immune complexes were separated by SDS-PAGE, \ntransferred to nitrocellulose, and immunoblotted with primary antibod-\nies followed by species-specific HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies. \nHRP activity was detected by chemiluminescence.\nImmunohistochemistry. Formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded adipose tissue \nsections were deparaffinized and rehydrated prior to antigen unmasking \nby boiling in 10 mM sodium citrate, pH 6.0, with 0.05% Tween-20 for 30 \nminutes. Sections were blocked in normal serum and incubated with pri-\nmary antibodies for durations of 1 hour to overnight. Endogenous HRP \nactivity was quenched with incubation with 3% hydrogen peroxide for 10 \nminutes. Secondary antibody staining was performed using the Vecta-\nstain ABC kit (Vector Laboratories) and detected with 3,3\u2032-diaminoben-\nzidine (DAB). Sections were counterstained with hematoxylin prior to \ndehydration and coverslip placement.\n2-Deoxyglucose uptake assay. Adipocytes were starved in low-glucose \nDMEM with 0.5% serum for 3 hours prior to insulin stimulation. 2-Deoxy-\nglucose uptake assays were performed as previously described (51).\nArginase assay. Arginase activity assays were performed as previously \ndescribed (52). Briefly, cells were lysed in 0.1% Triton X-100. Tris-HCl was \nadded to 12.5-mM and MnCl2 added to 1-mM final concentration. Argi-\nnase was activated by heating for 10 minutes at 56\u00b0C, and l-arginine sub-\nstrate was added to 250-mM final concentration. Reactions were incubated \nat 37\u00b0C for 30 minutes and stopped by the addition of H2SO4/H3PO4. \nAfter addition of \u03b1-isonitrosopropiophenone and heating for 30 minutes \nat 95\u00b0C, urea production was measured by absorbance at 540 nm and nor-\nmalized to total protein content.\nNF-\u03baB activation assay. 3T3-L1 adipocytes were transfected with lucifer-\nase reporter plasmid pBIIX-luc (containing 2 tandemly repeated NF-\u03baB \nbinding sites) along with Renilla luciferase control (100:1; Promega) as \npreviously described (51). Twenty-four hours after transfection, cells were \ntreated with vehicle or TNF-\u03b1 (1 nM) with or without IL-10 (20 ng/ml) for \n16 hours prior to lysis and analysis using the Dual-Luciferase Reporter \nAssay System (Promega). Values were normalized to Renilla activities.\nStatistics. Results are presented as the mean \u00b1 1 SD. Statistical analyses \nwere conducted using an unpaired 2-tailed Student\u2019s t test, with signifi-\ncance set at a P value of less than 0.05.\nAcknowledgments\nWe thank the University of Michigan Immunology Core for help \nwith ELISA assays and the University of Michigan Flow Cytometry \nCore for their assistance with FACS analysis. Here, we\ncomprehensively characterize the recently identified claudin-low tumor subtype.\nMethods: The clinical, pathological and biological features of claudin-low tumors were compared to the other\ntumor subtypes using an updated human tumor database and multiple independent data sets. These main\nfeatures of claudin-low tumors were also evaluated in a panel of breast cancer cell lines and genetically\nengineered mouse models.\nResults: Claudin-low tumors are characterized by the low to absent expression of luminal differentiation markers,\nhigh enrichment for epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition markers, immune response genes and cancer stem cell-\nlike features. Clinically, the majority of claudin-low tumors are poor prognosis estrogen receptor (ER)-negative,\nprogesterone receptor (PR)-negative, and epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-negative (triple negative)\ninvasive ductal carcinomas with a high frequency of metaplastic and medullary differentiation. They also have a\nresponse rate to standard preoperative chemotherapy that is intermediate between that of basal-like and luminal\ntumors. Interestingly, we show that a group of highly utilized breast cancer cell lines, and several genetically\nengineered mouse models, express the claudin-low phenotype. Finally, we confirm that a prognostically relevant\ndifferentiation hierarchy exists across all breast cancers in which the claudin-low subtype most closely resembles\nthe mammary epithelial stem cell.\nConclusions: These results should help to improve our understanding of the biologic heterogeneity of breast\ncancer and provide tools for the further evaluation of the unique biology of claudin-low tumors and cell lines.\nIntroduction\nGenomic studies have established four major breast can-\ncer intrinsic subtypes (luminal A, Luminal B, HER2-\nenriched, basal-like) and a normal breast-like group that\nshow significant differences in incidence, survival and\nresponse to therapy [1-3]. However, as gene expression\nstudies evolve, further subclassification of breast tumors\ninto new molecular entities is expected to occur. In 2007,\nwe identified a new molecular subtype, referred to as\nclaudin-low, using 13 samples [5]. These distinct tumors\nwere found in both human and murine breast tumor data\nsets and were characterized by the low gene expression of\ntight junction proteins claudin 3, 4 and 7 and E-cadherin,\na calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion glycoprotein.\nMore recently, a tumor initiating cell (TIC) genomic sig-\nnature derived from CD44+/CD24-/low-sorted cells and\nmammospheres obtained from primary human breast\ntumors was found to be exclusively enriched by gene\nexpression in the claudin-low subtype [6,7], and the\nexpression of this CD44+/CD24-/low/claudin-low profile\nincreased in posttreatment samples after neoadjuvant\nchemotherapy or hormone therapy [7]. Overall, these\nstudies suggest that the claudin-low tumor subtype lacks\ncommon epithelial cell features and is enriched for TIC\nfeatures.\nIn this study, we comprehensively characterize the\nclaudin-low subtype using an updated human tumor\n* Correspondence: cperou@med.unc.edu\n\u2020 Contributed equally\n1Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center, University of North Carolina, 450\nWest Drive, Chapel Hill, 27599, USA\nFull list of author information is available at the end of the article\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\n\u00a9 2010 Prat et al.; licensee BioMed Central Ltd. This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons\nAttribution License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in\nany medium, provided the original work is properly cited.\ndatabase and multiple independent data sets and present\nthe pathological and chemotherapy response characteris-\ntics of this subtype of \u201ctriple negative\u201d breast cancers. In\ncontrast to the basal-like subtype, we provide evidence\nthat claudin-low tumors are more enriched in epithelial-\nto-mesenchymal transition (EMT) features, immune\nsystem responses, and stem cell-associated biological\nprocesses. The molecular characterization of the clau-\ndin-low intrinsic subtype in tumors and cell lines reveals\na breast cancer differentiation hierarchy that resembles\nthe normal epithelial mammary developmental cascade.\nMaterials and methods\nHuman breast tumor microarray data sets\nAll human tumor and normal tissue samples were col-\nlected using Institutional Review Board (IRB)-approved\nprotocols and were obtained from fresh frozen invasive\nbreast carcinomas that were profiled as described pre-\nviously using oligo microarrays (Agilent Technologies,\nSanta Clara, CA, USA) [8]; we used all the microarrays\nfrom Herschkowitz et al. [5], Parker et al. [9] and Hen-\nnessy et al. [6], plus 39 new additional samples pre-\nsented here. All microarray and patient clinical data are\navailable in the University of North Carolina (UNC)\nMicroarray Database [10] and have been deposited in\nthe Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) under the acces-\nsion number GEO:GSE18229 (referred to here as the\nUNC337 set). The probes or genes for all analyses were\nfiltered by requiring the lowest normalized intensity\nvalues in both sample and control to be > 10. The nor-\nmalized log2 ratios (Cy5 sample/Cy3 control) of probes\nmapping to the same gene (Entrez ID as defined by the\nmanufacturer) were averaged to generate independent\nexpression estimates. In the resulting UNC337 matrix,\nno significant batch effects were observed. We also used\npublicly available microarray and patient clinical data\nfrom the following breast cancer data sets: NKI295\n[11,12],\nMDACC133\n[13]\nand\nNKI113\n[14].\nIn\nMDACC133, raw data were normalized using the robust\nmultiarray analysis (RMA) normalization approach. In\nall data sets, genes were median-centered within each\ndata set and samples were standardized to zero mean\nand unit variance before other analyses were performed.\nGene expression signatures\nWe analyzed the mean expression of multiple previously\npublished gene signatures [7,15-19]. Briefly, these signa-\ntures include leukocyte-related signatures from Palmer\net al. [17]: CD8 (n = 10 genes), B_Cell (n = 286), T_Cell\n(n = 178), and GRANS (n = 353). Stromal-related signa-\ntures were obtained from West et al. [16] (n = 402; DTF\nand SFT signatures combined) and Beck et al. [19] (n =\n174). Genes enriched more than twofold in mammo-\nsphere-derived cells compared with differentiated cells\nwere obtained from Dontu et al. [15] (n = 58). From Shi-\npitsin et al. [18], we calculated the mean expression of\nthe upregulated (n = 357) and downregulated (n = 353)\ngenes from CD44+ versus CD24+ breast cancer cells from\nmetastatic pleural effusions. From Creighton et al. [7], we\ncalculated the mean expression of the CD44+/CD24-/low/\nmammosphere signature reported (n = 119 upregulated\ngenes; n = 279 downregulated genes). Finally, the prolif-\neration and luminal gene cluster signatures were hand-\npicked (node correlation > 0.75) from the unsupervised\nintrinsic hierarchical clustering of the UNC337 using the\nintrinsic list of Parker et al. [9] and average linkage clus-\ntering using Cluster v2.12 (M. Eisen) [20] as shown in\nFigure S1 in Additional file 1. Gene lists from all genomic\nsignatures are displayed in Supplemental Data in Addi-\ntional file 2.\nBreast cancer cell line microarray data set\nWe analyzed a data set that included Affymetrix U133A\ngene expression microarrays of 52 breast cancer cell lines\n[21]. Raw data were normalized using RMA, and genes\nwere median-centered before analyses. Among the 52\nbreast cancer cell lines analyzed, DU4475, HCC1008 and\nHCC1599 cell lines were not included in Neve et al. [21].\nMouse breast tumor microarray data set\nAll mouse samples from the UNC were collected from\nfresh frozen invasive breast carcinomas as described pre-\nviously [5] using Agilent mouse oligo microarrays. Data\nnormalization and preprocessing were identical to that\ndescribed for the UNC337 data set. We used only sam-\nples (n = 104) from our previous publication that were\nincluded in 1 of the 10 mouse classes [5].\nClaudin-low and normal breast Euclidian centroid-based\npredictors\nTo robustly identify claudin-low samples, we built two\npredictors on the basis of either our human tumor data\nor the cell line data of Neve et al. [21]. To build a predic-\ntor, we first selected those genes that were significantly\ndifferentially expressed between claudin-low tumors\ndefined by SigClust [22] (or cell lines) and all other sub-\ntypes using a two-class, unpaired SAM, with < 5% false\ndiscovery rate (FDR). Then we used these gene lists and\ncalculated a claudin-low centroid and an \u201cothers\u201d cen-\ntroid from the training data. For every sample, we calcu-\nlated the Euclidean distances to the two centroids and\nassigned the class of the nearest centroid. Using the same\nmethodology, we also built a normal breast predictor by\nselecting those genes that were significantly differentially\nexpressed between normal breast tissues and breast\ntumors using a two-class, unpaired SAM, with 0% FDR.\nNote that these gene lists are also included in Supple-\nmental Data in Additional file 2.\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 2 of 18\nIntrinsic subtype classification\nFor all human breast tumor studies, intrinsic subtype\nclassification was performed using the PAM50 predictor\n[9]. Human claudin-low tumor samples were identified\nusing either SigClust [22] or the nine-cell line claudin-\nlow predictor. Samples identified by SigClust [22] or the\nnine-cell line claudin-low predictor were called claudin-\nlow, regardless of the PAM50 call. For breast cancer cell\nlines, the claudin-low subtype classification was based\non unsupervised hierarchical clustering using the intrin-\nsic list of Parker et al. [9] and the node identified in\nFigure S4 in Additional file 1. The complete gene list of\nthe nine-cell line claudin-low predictor can be found in\nSupplemental Data in Additional file 2.\nMammary developmental analyses\nPublic data sets from Raouf et al. [23] and Lim et al. [24]\nwere downloaded from GEO and assigned NCBI Entrez\ngene identifiers as available in GEO. Samples were scaled\nto mean zero and variance of 1. Features were then col-\nlapsed to the mean of each gene identifiers. In Lim et al.\n[24], three epithelial cell-enriched subpopulations were\nprofiled on DNA microarrays: mammary stem cells\n(MaSC), luminal progenitors (pL) and mature luminal\ncells (mL). We created a differentiation predictor for\neach sample as a measure of any sample\u2019s position along\na MaSC \u00ae pL \u00ae mL axis as defined by gene expression.\nDistance-weighted discrimination (DWD) was used to\ndetermine the direction of greatest variation from MaSC\nto pL and pL to mL. To map a sample onto this axis of\ndifferentiation, the pL centroid was set as the origin, and\nthe MaSC and mL centroids were transformed to length\n1 (sum of squares equals 1) to map a sample onto this\naxis of differentiation. Before mapping a sample onto this\naxis, it is assumed that the test data set covers the range\nof differentiation, which allows median centering of\ngenes to correct for platform bias. Test samples are then\nadjusted using the parameters for placing pL at the origin\nand are transformed to length 1. Each sample is then\nprojected onto the MaSC \u00ae pL axis and the pL \u00ae mL\naxis by calculating the inner product of the sample and\nthe MaSC or mL vectors identified by DWD. The differ-\nence of the two projected positions of each sample along\nthe MaSC \u00ae pL \u00ae mL axis is referred to as the differen-\ntiation score. In the UNC microarray database web site\n[10], we have provided the detailed R commands and\nfiles regarding the differentiation predictor.\nMammospheres from normal breast tissues\nFourteen normal breast tissues were dissociated mechani-\ncally and enzymatically as described in Stingl et al. [25].\nThe samples were procured and used according to\napproved IRB protocols for research in human subjects.\nMammospheres were cultured according to Dontu et al.\n[15], and single cells were plated onto ultralow attachment\nplates (Corning) at a density of 20,000 viable cells/ml.\nRNA was purified using RNeasy Mini kit (Qiagen) after 14\nto 20 days in primary culture (first passage), and microar-\nrays were performed as described above.\nImmunohistochemistry\nFormalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue sections\n(~5 \u03bcm thick) were processed using standard immuno-\nhistochemistry methods as previously described [26].\nThe sections were incubated for 60 min at room tem-\nperature with primary antibody to claudin 3 (dilution\n1:100; Invitrogen, Catalog No. 18-7340) or E-cadherin\n(Clone No. ECH-6, pre-diluted; Cell Marque). The slides\nwere incubated for 45 min with diluted biotinylated sec-\nondary antibody (1:250 dilution) for 30 min with Vectas-\ntain Elite ABC reagent (Vector Laboratories). Sections\nwere incubated in peroxidase substrate solution for\nvisualization. Slides were counterstained with hematoxy-\nlin and examined by light microscopy. Tumor immunor-\neactivity was scored in a blinded fashion by two\ninvestigators (JIH and XH) into two categories: negative/\nweak positive and moderate/strong positive.\nImmunofluorescence\nFormalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded sections (~5 \u03bcm\nthick) were processed using standard immunostaining\nmethods as previously described [5]. The primary anti-\nbodies and their dilution were vimentin (mouse anti-\nvimentin IgG1-\u0001, dilution 1:100; Invitrogen, Catalog No.\n18-0052), keratin 5 (rabbit anti-human, dilution 1:500;\nAbcam, Catalog No. ab24647), and keratin 19 (Abcam,\nCatalog No. ab7754, mouse anti-human IgG2a; dilution\n1:200). Secondary antibodies for immunofluorescence\nwere conjugated with Alexa Fluor-568 (Red, keratin 5\nand 19) or Alexa Fluor-488 (Green, vimentin) fluoro-\nphores (1:200; Molecular Probes, Invitrogen). Dual posi-\ntivity was scored in a blinded fashion by XH into two\ncategories: negative meaning no dual positive cells and\npositive meaning the presence of dual positive cells.\nCell lines\nSUM159PT cells (Asterand) were maintained in Ham\u2019s\nF-12 medium with 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS), insulin\n(5 \u03bcg/ml), and hydrocortisone (1 \u03bcg/ml). MCF-7 was\ncultured in RPMI with 10% FBS [27], and SUM149PT\nwas maintained in HuMEC media with supplements\n(Gibco) with and without 5% FBS [28]. All cell lines\nwere grown at 37\u00b0C and 5% carbon dioxide.\nFluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) and\nmicroarray analysis\nNonconfluent cell cultures were trypsinized and filtered\nto produce single cell suspension, counted, washed with\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 3 of 18\nHanks\u2019 balanced salt solution (Stem Cell Technologies)\ncontaining 2% FBS and stained with antibodies specific\nfor human cell surface markers: EPCAM-fluorescein iso-\nthiocyanate (Stem Cell Technologies) and CD49f-\nphycoerythrin (BD Pharmingen). A total of 500,000 cells\nwere incubated with antibodies for 30 min at 4\u00b0C. Cells\nwere washed from unbound antibodies and immediately\nanalyzed using Beckman-Coulter (Dako) CyAn ADP or\nsorted using BD FACScan. RNA was purified from\nsorted cells using the RNeasy Mini kit, and microarrays\nwere performed as described above.\nStatistical analyses\nAll microarray cluster analyses were displayed using Java\nTreeview version 1.1.3. Average linkage hierarchical\nclustering was performed using Cluster v2.12 [20]. Bio-\nlogic analysis of microarray data was performed with the\nDAVID annotation tool [29]. ANOVA and Student\u2019s\nt-tests for gene expression data, Fisher\u2019s exact test for\nneoadjuvant clinical data, c2 tests for pathological data,\nand the Cox model were performed using R [30]. Survi-\nval curves were calculated by the Kaplan-Meier method\nand compared by the log-rank test using WinStat\nv2007.1. Reported P values are two-sided.\nResults\nMolecular characterization of the claudin-low breast\ntumor subtype\nTo identify the molecular characteristics of claudin-low\ntumors, we created a large genomic data set by com-\nbining three of our previously published data sets\n[5,6,9] and included 37 new tumor samples (n = 337;\nUNC337, GEO series GSE18229). Hierarchical cluster-\ning analysis of this data set using the ~1,900 intrinsic\ngene list of Parker et al. [9] identified the major intrin-\nsic molecular subtypes, including the claudin-low sub-\ntype (Figure S1 in Additional file 1). The validity of\nthe claudin-low sample cluster was confirmed by par-\nsing the dendogram with SigClust [22] (P < 0.001);\nnotably, this clustering analysis placed the claudin-low\ntumors in close proximity to the basal-like subtype and\nwas composed of 32 arrays, representing 32 patients\n(~12% of all patients). Compared to the luminal A,\nluminal B, HER2-enriched, and basal-like subtypes,\nclaudin-low tumors showed inconsistent expression of\nbasal keratins (keratins 5, 14 and 17) and low expres-\nsion of HER2 and luminal markers such as ER, PR,\nGATA3, keratins 18 and 19 and the luminal gene clus-\nter (Figure 1a). Despite the apparent similarity to\nbasal-like tumors, claudin-low tumors as a group did\nnot show high expression of proliferation genes and\nthus are likely slower-cycling tumors. Indeed, signifi-\ncantly lower messenger RNA (mRNA) expression of\nthe cell cycle gene Ki67 was observed in claudin-low\ntumors when compared with basal-like tumors (P <\n0.0001, Student\u2019s t-test; Figure S2 and Table S1 in\nAdditional file 1).\nTo better characterize the claudin-low molecular sub-\ntype, we identified those genes differentially expressed in\nclaudin-low tumors compared with other tumors or\nsubtypes. We found 1,308 and 359 genes significantly\nhigher and lower in expression in claudin-low tumors,\nrespectively (Table S2 in Additional file 1). Overall, clau-\ndin-low tumors highly expressed genes involved in\nimmune system response (i.e. CD79b, CD14 and vav1),\ncell communication (chemokine [C-X-C motif] ligand\n12), extracellular matrix (vimentin, fibroblast growth\nfactor 7), cell differentiation (Kr\u00fcppel-like factor 2,\ninterleukin 6), cell migration (integrin a5, moesin) and\nangiogenesis (vascular endothelial growth factor C,\nmatrix metallopeptidase 9) [29]. Conversely, expression\nof various epithelial cell-cell adhesion genes such as\nclaudin 3, claudin 4, claudin 7, occludin and E-cadherin\nwas significantly lower as previously reported [5] (Figure\n1b). Further immunohistochemical analysis of 103 breast\ntumors of the UNC337 data set revealed that compared\nto the basal-like subtype, the claudin-low tumor subtype\nhad a preponderance for low to absent expression of\nE-cadherin and claudin 3 (45% vs. 11% for E-cadherin,\nP < 0.05; 59% vs. 11% for claudin 3, P < 0.005; c2 test).\nSimilarly, when compared to all other tumors (basal-\nlike, HER2-enriched, luminal A, luminal B and normal\nbreast-like) as a single group, the claudin-low tumor\nsubtype maintained its characteristic for low to absent\nexpression of E-cadherin and claudin 3 (45% vs. 15% for\nE-cadherin, P < 0.005; 59% vs. 22% for claudin 3, P <\n0.001; c2 test) (Figure S3 in Additional file 1).\nConcordant with the expression of markers of\nmesenchyme and immunity, we observed high expres-\nsion of stromal-specific and lymphocyte- or granulocyte-\nspecific gene signatures in claudin-low tumors compared\nto the other intrinsic subtypes [16,17,19] (Figure 1b,\nFigure S2 in Additional file 1). These findings, together\nwith the low expression of epithelial cell-cell adhesion\nmolecules such as E-cadherin, are consistent with an\nEMT (changes in cell phenotype between epithelial and\nmesenchymal states) [31] in claudin-low tumors and a\npotential recruitment of multiple types of leukocytes\ninto these tumors.\nWe next explored the mRNA expression of the TIC\ngene markers CD44 and CD24 and cell surface markers\nof epithelial differentiation such as MUC1, CD49f, and\nepithelial cell adhesion molecule (EpCAM) across the\nintrinsic subtypes (basal-like, claudin-low, luminal A,\nluminal B, HER2-enriched) and the normal breast-like\ngroup to determine their differentiation status. Overall,\nclaudin-low tumors showed low mRNA expression of\ndifferentiated luminal cell surface markers (CD24,\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 4 of 18\nEpCAM and MUC1), while markers CD44 and CD49f\nwere higher when compared to differentiated luminal\ntumors (P < 0.05, Student\u2019s t-test; Figure 1c, Figure S2\nin Additional file 1). The expression pattern of these\ngene markers is concordant with CD44+/CD24-/low and\nCD49f+/EpCAM-/low antigenic phenotypes, which have\nbeen previously shown to be enriched in breast TICs\n[32,33] and mammary stem cells (MaSCs) [24]. Second,\nwe observed that claudin-low tumors compared to the\nother tumor subtypes, except for the normal breast-like\ngroup, showed the highest mRNA expression of\nALDH1A1, which has recently been proposed to be\nanother marker of breast stem cells and TICs [34] but\nalso noted in stromal cells [24,34,35]. Conversely, basal-\nlike tumors did not show significantly lower expression\nof CD24 as a group, nor did they show high mRNA\nexpression of ALDH1A1 (Figure 1b and Figure S2 in\nAdditional file 1). This contrasts with other studies that\nhave linked the basal-like subtype with stem cell- or\nembryonic cell-like features [36,37]; however, these\nFigure 1 Average expression of important genes and gene signatures across the intrinsic breast cancer subtypes. (a) Classical markers\nused to characterize breast tumors are shown for mRNA expression levels for basal markers (keratins 5 [KRT5], 14 [KRT14] and 17 [KRT17]),\nluminal markers (keratins 18 [KRT18] and 19 [KRT19]), ER (ESR1), PR, GATA3 and HER2 (ERBB2). Right: Box-and-whisker plot for expression of the\nluminal and proliferation gene signatures. (b) Markers of EMT (vimentin [VIM], Snail-1 [SNAI1], Snail-2 [SNAI2], TWIST1, TWIST2, ZEB1, ZEB2,\nE-cadherin [CDH1], and claudins 3 [CLDN3], 4 [CLDN4] and 7 [CLDN7]). Right: expression of stromal- and immune-related signatures [16,17]. (c)\nMarkers of stem cells/TICs/epithelial differentiation (CD44, CD24, EpCAM, CD10, CD49f, CD29, MUC1, THY1, and ALDH1A1). Right: Previously\npublished stem cell-like signature [7]. Each colored square on the left side represents the relative mean transcript abundance (in log2 space) for\neach subtype with highest expression being red, average expression being black, and lowest expression being green. BL, basal-like; CL, claudin-\nlow defined by SigClust [22]; H2, HER2-enriched; LA, luminal A; LB, luminal B; NBL, normal breast-like. P values shown were calculated by\ncomparing gene expression means across all subtypes.\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 5 of 18\nother studies did not examine claudin-low tumors as a\nseparate group, and in the absence of a claudin-low pre-\ndictor, claudin-low tumors are typically classified as\nbasal-like (or normal breast-like) by the PAM50 gene\nexpression assay [9].\nTo further explore the potential enrichment for breast\nstem cells and TIC features, we evaluated the expression\nof three breast stem cell-like signatures [7,15,18] across\nthe different subtypes. All signatures were highly\nenriched (P < 0.0001, Student\u2019s t-test; Supplementary\nMaterial in Additional file 2) in the claudin-low subtype\ndespite the various derivations used of each signature\n(Figure 1c, Figure S2 in Additional file 1). Interestingly,\nthese three stem cell-like signatures were representative\nof distinct gene expression subsets, among which < 10%\nof the genes overlapped. These data suggest that differ-\nent biological processes associated with TICs converge\nin the claudin-low tumor subtype.\nIdentification of the claudin-low profile in a panel of\nbreast cancer cell lines\nTo investigate if potential in vitro counterparts for these\ntumors exist, we analyzed a data set of 52 breast cancer\ncell lines [21] by hierarchical cluster analysis using our\nmost recent human breast tumor intrinsic classification\nlist [9]. The three major subgroups (luminal, basal B\nand basal A) identified previously by Neve et al. [21]\nwere evident, with nine basal B cell lines clustering\ntogether with a node correlation of 0.59 (Figure S4 in\nAdditional file 1). These cell lines showed low expres-\nsion of the ER, HER2 and claudin 3, claudin 4 and clau-\ndin 7 (Figure S4 in Additional file 1). We identified\nthose genes whose expression distinguished each human\ntumor subtype using significance analysis of microarrays\n(SAM) in our UNC337 tumor database, including a list\ndefining the normal breast-like group (Figure 2a). These\nnine cell lines (MDA-MB-435, MDA-MB-436, Hs578T,\nBT549, MDA-MB-231, MDA-MB-157, SUM1315MO2,\nSUM159PT and HBL100) showed a gene expression\npattern similar to the claudin-low tumor subtype with\nthe lowest expression of genes involved in epithelial\ncell-cell adhesion (i.e., E-cadherin and claudins 3, 4 and\n7), luminal differentiation (i.e., CD24, EpCAM) and high\nvalues for the CD44/CD24 and CD49f/EpCAM mRNA\nratios (Figure S4, Table S3 in Additional file 1). To com-\nplement these clustering analyses, we developed a clau-\ndin-low centroid-based predictor using the UNC337\ntumor data set and the SigClust-defined claudin-low\ngroup versus all others, and objectively classified the 52\ncell lines as claudin-low or not; as expected, the human\nFigure 2 Identification of the claudin-low subtype in a panel of breast cancer cell lines. Gene clusters that characterize each primary\nhuman tumor subtype are shown in the human and cell line gene expression data sets. In both data sets, array trees have been derived by\nunsupervised hierarchical clustering using the intrinsic list from Parker et al. [9] as shown in Figure S1A and S4A in Additional file 1. (a) The top\n50 upregulated genes associated with each molecular subtype, including the top 50 downregulated genes in claudin-low tumors, are shown in\nthe UNC337 database. Top genes were selected after performing a two-class SAM (FDR = 0%) between each molecular subtype versus others.\nLuminal A and B subtypes were combined into the luminal subtype. In the tree, the yellow node denotes the claudin-low tumors defined by\nSigClust [22]. (b) Gene clusters characteristic of each tumor molecular subtype are shown in 52 breast cancer cell lines from Neve et al. [21].\nMissing genes have been omitted. In the tree, the yellow node denotes the most highly correlated cell lines that best resemble the claudin-low\nsubtype. 1 (yellow), claudin-low gene cluster of upregulated and downregulated genes; 2 (red), basal-like gene cluster; 3 (pink), HER2-enriched\ngene cluster; 4 (green), normal breast-like gene cluster; 5 (blue), luminal gene cluster.\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 6 of 18\ntumor-based claudin-low predictor identified these nine\ncell lines as claudin-low (Figure S5 in Additional file 1).\nThe gene cluster that identifies the in vivo defined\nnormal\nbreast-like\ngroup\nwas\nnot\ndifferentially\nexpressed by any of the 52 cell lines, suggesting overall\nthat none of these cell lines show a normal breast-like\nphenotype (Figure 2b). The normal breast-like group of\nprimary specimens is usually composed of actual nor-\nmal breast samples and a small number of primary\ntumors [9,38], the latter of which we believe show the\nhigh expression of true normal tissue genes due to sig-\nnificant normal breast contamination [9]. In cell culture,\nhowever, there is no such contamination by normal\nepithelial or nonepithelial cells, and thus this lack of\ncontamination may explain why normal breast-like\ntumor cell lines are not identified as such by the clus-\ntering. To be more objective, we applied a normal\nbreast centroid-based predictor (normal breast versus all\ntumors using the UNC337 database) to the cell line\ndata, and no cell line was classified as normal breast\n(Figure S5 in Additional file 1). Contamination with\nother tissues or cells is not uncommon in other tumor\nsubtypes [1]. For example, within the top highly\nexpressed genes in claudin-low tumors versus all others,\nthere are several wound response-related genes (i.e.,\nCD28, CD52) that are not expressed by the breast can-\ncer cell lines (Figure 2b), potentially due to significant\nimmune or stromal cell content in the tumor. Overall,\nthese data suggest that the nine previously described\nbreast cancer cell lines are most similar to claudin-low\ntumors in in vivo specimens.\nBuilding a Cell-line claudin-low centroid-based predictor\nBecause primary human claudin-low tumors are highly\nenriched for immune system genes (and lymphocytes)\nwhen supervised analyses are performed, the expression\nof nonepithelial cell genes would likely increase the false\npositivity of the human claudin-low predictor when\napplied to other tumor data sets, because, for instance,\ntumors would be called claudin-low or not based upon\nthe high expression of immune cell genes. Therefore, we\ndeveloped a claudin-low centroid-based predictor using\nthe cell line database of Neve et al. [21]. First, we evalu-\nated its accuracy by applying the predictor onto our\nhuman tumor database (UNC337). The nine-cell line\nclaudin-low predictor identified 37 samples (~11%) as\nclaudin-low, including the 28 claudin-low samples pre-\nviously identified by hierarchical clustering. The remain-\ning nine samples identified by the predictor were\npreviously called basal-like (n = 7), normal breast-like (n\n= 1) and HER2-enriched (n = 1) by the PAM50 predic-\ntor [9]. Overall, the nine-cell line claudin-low predictor\nshowed 87.5% sensitivity, 97.0% specificity, and 75.7%\nand 98.7% positive and negative predictive values,\nrespectively, if the SigClust-defined claudin-low group is\nconsidered the gold standard.\nWe then used the nine-cell line claudin-low predic-\ntor to identify this subtype in a mouse tumor database\n[5], which represents 13 different mouse models\ngrouped in 10 different classes on the basis of their\ngene expression profiles (Groups I to X). Interestingly,\nall claudin-low samples identified by the centroid pre-\ndictor (n = 9) were included in Group II, which we\npreviously highlighted for its mesenchymal features\n(i.e., spindle-shaped cells). These nine murine claudin-\nlow tumor samples were derived from six different\nmouse models (Brca1Co/Co;TgMMTV-Cre;p53+/-,\nDMBA-induced,\np53-/-\ntransplant,\np53+/-\nIR,\nTgMMTV-Neu and TgWAP-T121) and overall showed\nsimilar enrichment for EMT markers and human\nmesenchymal and stem cell-like signatures, including\ndecreased expression of proliferative- and luminal-\nassociated genes (Figure S6 in Additional file 1). No\nmurine normal mammary tissue sample was classified\nas claudin-low. These analyses suggest that a cell line\ncentroid-based approach, by focusing on genes\nexpressed in epithelial cells only, might give more\naccurate classification of tumors, which could be evalu-\nated in future studies focused on tumor subtyping.\nClinical-pathological characteristics of claudin-low\nbreast tumors\nTo determine for the first time the clinical-pathological\ncharacteristics of human claudin-low breast tumors, we\nevaluated our breast cancer patient database (UNC337)\nand two independent gene expression data sets (NKI295\nand MDACC133) [11-13] using the nine-cell line clau-\ndin-low predictor and the previously published PAM50\nsubtype predictor (Figure 3a) because these two objec-\ntive centroid predictors have been demonstrated to be\nthe most robust to classify breast tumors into discrete\nsubtypes. Across all three databases, claudin-low tumors\nshowed a prevalence of 7 to 14%, and were mostly ER-/\nPR-/HER2- (also known as triple-negative tumors, 61 to\n71%). Conversely, the majority of triple-negative tumors\nwere either basal-like (39 to 54%) or claudin-low (25 to\n39%), followed by HER2-enriched (7 to 14%), luminal B\n(4 to 7%), luminal A (4 to 5%) and normal breast-like\n(1%). In terms of prognosis, Kaplan-Meier survival ana-\nlysis revealed that claudin-low tumors have a worse\nprognosis compared to luminal A tumors in both the\nUNC337 (hazard ratio [HR] of 2.83 and 5.66 for\nrelapse-free survival [RFS] and overall survival [OS],\nrespectively; P < 0.05) and NKI295 data sets (HR of 4.71\nand 17.98 for RFS and OS, respectively; P < 0.001). Con-\nversely, similar survival curves were observed between\nclaudin-low tumors and the other poor prognosis sub-\ntypes such as luminal B, HER2-enriched and basal-like\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 7 of 18\ntumors (Figure 3b). Normal breast-like samples were\nomitted from survival analyses because they are likely\nsignificantly contaminated by normal breast tissue, and\nthus their true tumor biology is masked.\nWe also evaluated the potential association between\nclaudin-low tumors and treatment response by using the\nMDACC breast cancer patient data set (133 pretreated\nsamples) of tumors treated with neoadjuvant anthracy-\ncline/taxane-based chemotherapy [13]. Notably, claudin-\nlow tumors showed a lower pathological complete\nresponse (pCR) rate after anthracycline/taxane-based\nchemotherapy compared to basal-like tumors (38.9% vs.\n73.3% pCR rates; P = 0.08, Fisher\u2019s exact test), but their\npCR rate was higher than luminal A or B tumors;\ninterestingly, the apparent pCR rate of the basal-like\ntumors increased from 59% (reported in Parker et al. [9])\nto ~73% when the claudin-low subtype was included,\nbecause among 18 claudin-low tumors identified in this\nset, 12 (67%) of 18 of them were previously identified as\nbasal-like and the response rate of this subgroup of\npatients was 41.7%. These findings suggest that claudin-\nlow tumors show some chemotherapy sensitivity but\noverall have a poor prognosis and may not be managed\neffectively with existing chemotherapy regimens.\nTwenty-one claudin-low samples were examined his-\ntologically by a pathologist (CL; Table S4 in Additional\nfile 1) to further clinically characterize claudin-low\ntumors. Among the samples evaluated, 9 (43%) of 21\nFigure 3 Clinical and pathological characteristics and prognosis of all intrinsic subtypes, including claudin-low tumors, across three\nindependent breast cancer data sets. (a) Percentages of the different clinical-pathological characteristics in the UNC337 data set and two\npublicly available data sets (NKI295 and MDACC133). ER/PR/HER2 scores of the UNC337 database were based on clinically validated methods.\n(b) Survival data of the different molecular subtypes are shown for the UNC337 database and NKI295. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 8 of 18\nhad noteworthy histological differentiation patterns,\nincluding medullary-like features (5/21, 24%) such as\npushing margins and brisk tumor lymphocytic infiltra-\ntion, two samples (2 of 21, 10%) showed metaplastic dif-\nferentiation, one sample showed mixed ductal/lobular\nfeatures, and one sample was a pure micropapillary car-\ncinoma. The remaining 12 samples (12 of 21, 57%) were\ninvasive ductal carcinomas not otherwise specified.\nOverall, lymphoid infiltration was evident in a total of\nseven samples (total of 7 of 19, 37%), which might\nexplain the high mRNA expression of immune response\ngenes present in these tumors. Among the other clau-\ndin-low samples that could not be examined histologi-\ncally (n = 16), 50% (8/16) had a previous diagnosis of\nmetaplastic tumors. It is interesting to note that two\nclaudin-low cell lines, Hs578T and MDA-MB-157, were\nderived from metaplastic [39] and medullary [40]\ncarcinomas.\nSince the pathological examination of claudin-low\ntumors identified special histological features, we applied\nthe nine-cell line claudin-low predictor to a publicly\navailable database of histologically diverse subtypes of\nbreast cancer (n = 113, NKI113) [14], which includes 10\nmedullary carcinomas, 20 metaplastic carcinomas and\n22 invasive lobular carcinomas (ILC). Indeed, 8 (57%) of\n14 and 2 (14%) of 14 claudin-low samples were identi-\nfied as metaplastic and medullary carcinomas, respec-\ntively (Figure 4f and Table S5 in Additional file 1).\nConversely, only 2 of a total of 22 ILCs were identified\nas claudin-low despite the lack of E-cadherin expression\nin lobular tumors [41].\nClaudin-low subtype resembles the MaSC profile\nWe hypothesized, as did Lim et al. [24], that a mam-\nmary differentiation program starting from a MaSC \u00ae\nluminal progenitor (pL) \u00ae mature luminal cells (mLs)\nexists, and therefore we built a differentiation model\nusing data from Lim et al. [24]. For this predictor,\nhigher scores represent greater differentiation status\nalong this axis that culminates in ER+ mLs (Figure 4a).\nFirst, we applied this predictor onto similar subpopula-\ntions of purified human mammary epithelial cells that\nwere separated by fluorescence-activated cell sorting\n(FACS) and profiled as part of the independent study\nof Raouf et al. [23] using different surface makers (Fig-\nure S7 in Additional file 1). The differentiation predic-\ntor showed 100% (8 of 8) accuracy with the bipotent\nprogenitor subpopulation from Raouf et al. [23]\nFigure 4 Epithelial differentiation score analysis of normal mammary tissue, human breast tumors, human cell lines and mouse\nmammary tumors. (a) Differentiation axis based on Lim et al. [24] data. (b) Mammospheres (MMS; n = 14) derived from normal breast tissue.\nYellow crosses identify claudin-low MMS (n = 6, 43%) as defined by the nine-cell line claudin-low predictor. (c) Tumors and the normal breast-\nlike group from the UNC337 database. (d) Breast cancer cell lines. Except for the nine claudin-low cell lines, we used the subtype calls (luminal\n[L] and basal [B]) as reported in Neve et al. [21]. (e) Mouse tumors from Herschkowitz et al. [5]. (f) Histological special types of breast cancer\nobtained from the NKI113 database [14]. Colored dots or boxes denote the subtype cells. IDC with OGC, invasive ductal carcinoma with\nosteoclastic giant cells; ILC, invasive lobular carcinoma; BL (red), basal-like; CL (yellow), claudin-low defined by the nine-cell line claudin-low\npredictor; H2 (pink), HER2-enriched; LA (dark blue), luminal A; LB (light blue), luminal B; NBL (green), normal breast-like. *P < 0.0001.\nPrat et al. Breast Cancer Research 2010, 12:R68\nhttp://breast-cancer-research.com/content/12/5/R68\nPage 9 of 18\n[CD49f+(MUC1/CD133)-(CD10/THY1)+] showing the\nlowest differentiation score (and thus most similar to\nthe MaSC fraction of Lim et al. [24]), followed by the\nluminal-restricted progenitor [CD49f+(MUC1/CD133)\n+(CD10/THY1)-] and then the mLs [CD49f-(MUC1/\nCD133)+(CD10/THY1)-]. In addition, we established\nand\nexpression-profiled\nmammosphere\ncultures\nobtained from 14 different normal breast tissues\nbecause these cultures enrich for cells with stem or\nself-renewal capacity [15]. As expected, mammospheres\nshowed a low differentiation score close to the MaSC\nprofile (Figure 4b).\nNotably, and as shown by Lim et al. [24], the breast\ncancer subtypes segregate along the normal mammary\nepithelial differentiation hierarchy starting with undif-\nferentiated claudin-low tumors, followed by basal-like,\nthen HER2-enriched tumors, and finally both luminal\ntumor subtypes (Figure 4c). As expected, we observed\nthe same pattern using the breast cancer cell line data\n[21] (Figure 4d). Conversely, the nine-cell line claudin-\nlow predictor identified the MaSC and stromal\n(CD49flow/EpCAM-) subpopulations of Lim et al. [24]\nas claudin-low, and as expected, both subpopulations\nshowed the highest and lowest expression of the up-\nand downregulated genes that define the nine-cell line\nclaudin-low predictor (Figure S8 in Additional file 1).\nMoreover, we applied the differentiation predictor to\nthe mouse data set of Herschkowitz et al. [5] (Figure\n4e) and observed that the previously identified claudin-\nlow murine samples scored the lowest, while the\nMMTV-Neu and MMTV-PyMT models, which are\nknown luminal mammary adenocarcinoma models,\nscored the highest. In addition, among 113 histological\nspecial types of breast cancer [14], medullary, adenoid\ncystic and metaplastic tumors showed the lowest score\nin the differentiation axis (Figure 4f), which is consis-\ntent with our previous reports of commonalities\nbetween metaplastic carcinomas, claudin-low tumors\nand breast cancer TICs [6].\nFinally, we evaluated the prognostic ability of the\ndifferentiation predictor in the UNC337 and NKI295\nbreast cancer patient data sets. Low differentiation\nscores were statistically significantly associated with\npoorer RFS and OS in univariate (Figure 5a) and mul-\ntivariate analyses after adjusting for the main clinical-\npathological parameters (i.e., size, grade, node and ER\nstatus), including tumor subtype (Figure 5b). These\ndata suggest that tumors with an undifferentiated\nphenotype similar to the normal MaSC and/or early\nprogenitors have a poorer prognosis compared to\ntumors with a more mature luminal phenotype, and\nthis association is independent of the luminal B and\nHER2-enriched subtypes and the common clinical\nvariables.\nClaudin-low and basal-like tumors are enriched with\nundifferentiated or mesenchymal cells\nNext, we sought to determine whether tumor cells with\nundifferentiated or mesenchymal features (as defined by\nimmunofluorescence) exist within the different breast\ncancer intrinsic subtypes, similar to that performed by\nCreighton et al. [7]. Eighty-six breast tumors and one\nnormal breast sample from the UNC337 database,\nincluding 20 claudin-low tumors, were evaluated using\ndual immunofluorescence (IF) staining with epithelial\n(keratin 5/19) and mesenchymal (vimentin) markers.\nStaining of the normal breast sample revealed that the\nantibody to vimentin stains the mesenchyme or stroma,\nwhereas the antibody to keratin 5/19 stains the ducts,\nand no dual positive cells were seen (Figure 6). Conver-\nsely, 33% (28 of 86) of all tumor samples showed some\ndegree of dual positivity, but 89% (25 of 28) of all sam-\nples with dual immunofluorescence positivity were\neither claudin-low (n = 11) or basal-like (n = 14). The\nremaining dual positive samples were identified in the\nHER2-enriched (n = 1) and luminal A subtypes (n = 2).\nClaudin-low tumors showed higher percentages of dual\npositive tumors than the other tumor subtypes when\nthese are considered as a group (55% vs. 26%; P = 0.014,\nc2 test); however, no statistically significant differences\nin dual positivity were observed between claudin-low\nand basal-like tumors (55% vs. 78%; P = 0.14, c2 test).\nThese data show that some epithelial tumor cells\nexpress mesenchymal features, these features are not\ndue to contamination by adjacent stromal cells and\nalmost all tumors with these features are basal-like or\nclaudin-low tumors.\nWe attempted to identify undifferentiated/mesenchy-\nmal epithelial cells within breast cancer cell lines. First,\nwe analyzed the expression of surface markers CD49f\nand EpCAM (chosen based upon the studies of Lim et\nal. [24]) in three different cell lines: MCF-7 (luminal),\nSUM149PT (basal-like) and SUM159PT (claudin-low)\n(Figure 7). As expected on the basis of our previous\ngenomic analysis of the differentiation status of these\ncell lines, virtually all claudin-low SUM159PT cells\nshowed a stromal or MaSC antigenic phenotype (CD49f\n+/EpCAM-), ~98% of MCF-7 cells showed a mL pheno-\ntype (CD49f-/low/EpCAM+), and ~83% of SUM149PT\ncells showed a pL phenotype (CD49f+/EpCAM+/high).\nAbout 10% and ~2% of cells from SUM149PT and\nMCF-7 cell lines, respectively, showed low expression of\nEpCAM, suggesting that some cells within basal-like\nand luminal cell lines might have a more undifferen-\ntiated state. However, a clear EpCAM-/low subpopulation\nwas identified only in the SUM149PT cell line.\nTo further determine the differentiation status of the\nvarious cell subpopulations within MCF-7 (CD49f-/\nEpCAM+, CD49f+/EpCAM+, and CD49f-/lowEpCAM-/low),\nPrat et al. The\nEpCAM-/low cells derived from MCF-7 or SUM149PT\nlines showed a statistically significant undifferentiated\nstate when compared with their EpCAM+/high cell counter-\nparts (Figure 7b); however, for MCF-7 cells, the EpCAM-/\nlow cells still showed high differentiation scores. Conver-\nsely, the CD49f+/EpCAM-/low cells from the basal-like\nSUM149PT cell line showed the presence of a mesenchy-\nmal/claudin-low-like gene expression profile, with\nFigure 7 FACS of breast cancer cell lines and characterization of their differentiation status.
